title: 2012 Subaru Tribeca
subTitle: Subaru’s not-so-little-engine-that-could doesn’t look like it can and may be on its last leg…or wheel
promoTeaserSmall: 2012 Subaru Tribeca
promoTeaser: 2012 Subaru Tribeca
metaTitle: 2012 Subaru Tribeca Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2012 Subaru Tribeca here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: For all the redesigns that Subaru has made to its other vehicles, it seems that the Tribeca has been left behind to stand on its merits during the time it has left as a viable member of the Subaru lineup. Based on the Outback, the only changes that have been made in the Tribeca’s seven-year history are a new head-restraint design and a new addition to the paint palette. It’s unfortunate, because the Tribeca is a pretty well-appointed car. As with all Subarus, it comes standard with all-wheel drive and has a passenger volume similar to its more popular sibling. Like the Outback, it’s also good for hauling any sort of equipment that you find yourself transporting; the Tribeca has a cargo area under the rear floors in addition to flat folding second- and third-row seats. The up-to-date audio system and a rear-seat entertainment system will keep both you and your little passengers entertained. Heated front seats come standard for your driving comfort and an auxiliary air conditioning system to keep all your backseat passengers cool on hot, sunny days. The car’s only shortcomings are a tight third-row and a fuel economy that doesn’t compare to that of its competitors.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Traverse
2. Dodge Durango
3. Honda Pilot
4. Mazda CX-9

Cool Tech Items:
1. Rear vision camera.
2. Reverse assist sensors.

Looks:
1. Eighteen-inch alloy wheels.
2. Tinted glass on rear sides and liftgate.
3. Ambient illumination in footwells and on doors.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz GLK-CLass
subTitle: The smallest Mercedes SUV calls time out for a thorough makeover and returns much improved.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mercedes-Benz GLK-CLass
promoTeaser: 2013 Mercedes-Benz GLK-CLass
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz GLK-CLass Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz GLK-CLass Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Standing tall and looking boxy, the GLK-Class is notably different from its chief competitors at Audi and BMW. While being somewhat roomier and offering better outward visibility, it hadn’t been as much fun to drive. Did Mercedes stand around and pout over it? No, they sought to improve the GLK for 2013. The exterior is refreshed with LED daytime running lights, a new grille, and bolder-looking bumpers. New LED taillights brighten the rear. Inside, the driver looks at a colorful instrument display and everyone can enjoy the optional, multi-color ambient lighting. The latest “mbrace” telematics system connects vehicle and smartphone. Of course the GLK offers a host of features for driver assistance and active safety. The biggest news, though, is that the GLK350 is fitted with a 3.5-liter V-6 that benefits from the addition of direct injection and makes 302 horsepower. It includes automatic stop/start, a fuel economy feature, which shuts off the engine when the car sits at a stoplight, then refires it when the driver releases the brake. Rear-wheel drive is available, or you get all-wheel drive with the GLK350 4Matic. The turbo-diesel-powered GLK250 Bluetec joins the lineup early in 2013. So now there’s something for everybody.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. BMW X3
2. Audi Q5
3. Infiniti EX35

Cool Tech:
1. For rear passengers, an iPad dock is included.
2. Active curve illumination lets headlamps sense an oncoming turn and swivel, directing the beam into the corner.
3. The coming 2.1-liter turbo-diesel engine far outdoes the larger gas V-6 in torque output, a key measure of engine performance in city traffic and highway passing maneuvers.

Looks
1. AMG styling package adds unique wheels, lower-body panels, and aluminum roof rails.
2. Panorama roof is option.
3. Twenty-inch wheels are optional.

New for 2013
1. Refreshed exterior styling with new headlamps, bumpers, and grille for a bolder look.
2. The 3.5-liter V-6 benefits from the addition of direct injection, making 302 horsepower.
3. Brushed aluminum accents and more expansive wood trim highlight the interior.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SL-Class
subTitle: Lighter in weight, bursting with power, and trimmed to a fare-thee-well, the SL is all-new for 2013
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SL-Class
promoTeaser: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SL-Class
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SL-Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SL-Class Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: In creating a new-generation SL-Class, Mercedes engineers devoted an inordinate amount of effort to making the car lighter. The aluminum body weighs 275 pounds less yet provides better crash protection and is stiffer than the previous steel body, which results in superior ride and handling characteristics. That’s like finding a pair of lightweight shoes that are comfortable and good-looking. The SL is a hardtop coupe and open-top roadster with a power top that folds away in twenty seconds, but when it’s up, the optional Magic Sky Control lets occupants control the darkness of the glass panel’s tint. For top-down comfort, vents in the seats deliver heat around your neck during the fall color tour. As beautiful as the SL is on the outside, it’s every bit as alluring and voluptuous inside. The seats are heated and actively ventilated (optional) for comfort. Nearly every driver assist and active safety feature you could think of except incoming missile avoidance is included. Under the long, creased hood is the SL550’s turbocharged 4.6-liter V-8 making 429 horsepower; this is outfitted with automatic stop/start for fuel economy purposes. Pusillanimous V-8 and V-12 units are in the two AMG models. A seven-speed automatic harnesses the output of all three engines.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Aston Martin V8 Vantage
2. Jaguar XK
3. Maserati GranTurismo

Cool Tech:
1. Two FM radio antennas are embedded in the windshield, while two other antennas receive signals for AM band, GPS, phone, and mbrace2 telematics system.
2. Windshield wiper fluid only sprays on downstroke when the top is lowered.
3. SL63 AMG has Racestart launch control feature for maximum efficiency on takeoff.

Looks
1. Nineteen- and twenty-inch wheels are optional.
2. Sport steering wheel with perforated grips is optional.
3. Perforated rear brake discs, showing your degree of seriousness, are optional.

New for 2013
1. Hands-free access to the trunk is achieved by kicking through a field at the rear bumper.
2. Mbrace2 telematics system adds Internet and remote access capabilities.
3. SL65 AMG with 612-horsepower V-12 engine now uses seven-speed automatic transmission.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SLK-Class
subTitle: The small coupe-roadster has many virtues to offer, brutal acceleration among them, and a style all its own
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SLK-Class
promoTeaser: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SLK-Class
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SLK-Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz SLK-Class Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The SLK shows how Mercedes-Benz has refined the luxury roadster experience. It’s available with three powertrains, which emphasize characteristics ranging from frugality to brutality. Yes, just like a trip to Walmart! The lowest-priced SLK250 has a turbocharged four-cylinder and standard six-speed manual transmission that yields 31 mpg highway. On the other hand, the SLK55 AMG must be gagging on the huge 5.5-liter V-8 under its hood: the 415-horsepower car roars from 0 to 60 mph in just 4.5 seconds. Of course the V-8, being equipped with cylinder deactivation and automatic stop/start, tries its best to achieve polite fuel economy. In between, a 3.5-liter V-6 makes 302 horsepower and sends the SLK350 off with a nice growl. The V-6 and V-8 are paired with a seven-speed automatic. The SLK plays twin roles as a suave hardtop coupe and sporty roadster thanks to the power-foldaway top. The optional Airscarf--vents in the seats--delivers warm air around your neck on cool rides. The SLK is as beautiful as other Mercedes-Benzes on the inside when optional wood trim is added. Now add the mbrace2 telematics feature to a host of safety and driver assist features, and techno-wizardry joins other existing characteristics.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. BMW Z4
2. Porsche Boxster
3. Audi TT

Cool Tech:
1. The retractable hard top has the optional Magic Sky Control that lets occupants vary the opacity of the glass panel’s tint.
2. Mbrace2 telematics system adds Internet and remote access capabilities.
3. Adaptive-beam headlights give a better look down the road.

Looks
1. Eighteen-inch wheels are optional on the SLK250 and SLK350.
2. Optional ash or walnut trim replaces standard aluminum in the SLK250 and SLK350.
3. Panorama roof and Magic Sky Control, the variable opacity glass, are optional.

New for 2013
1. The cruise control switches are redesigned.
2. Mbrace2 telematics system adds Internet capability and remote access capability.
3. Adaptive high-beams are options.

title: 2013 Rolls-Royce Phantom
subTitle: The ultimate in roving comfort
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Rolls-Royce Phantom
promoTeaser: 2013 Rolls-Royce Phantom
metaTitle: 2013 Rolls-Royce Phantom Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Rolls-Royce Phantom here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: For the price of a large-ish house (depending on where you live) you could own a single, opulent automobile. The Rolls-Royce Phantom is the car for the person who has everything they’ve ever wanted and much, much more. With a beautiful interior and no shortage of space in the back for adult passengers (even Shaq would be comfortable with the Extended Wheelbase version), the car can be customized endlessly, and most buyers choose to take advantage of Rolls-Royce’s bespoke design team. One option turns the Phantom into a theatre, with two rear monitors and a six-disc changer in the glove box. The four-passenger version has room in the backseat for a drink cabinet or cigar humidor. The Phantom is a little slower to 60 mph than the smaller Ghost, but still makes it in under six seconds while preserving Rolls-Royce’s characteristic smooth, quiet ride. Rolls likens the experience of being driven in a Phantom to a  “magic carpet ride.” The Phantom’s recent update brings a new eight-speed automatic transmission, LED lights, and slightly improved fuel consumption. Although, lets face it, if you’re driving around in this thing, you’re not worried about the price of gas.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competition:
1. Bentley Mulsanne

Cool Tech:
1. Headlights automatically adjust light patterns in reaction to driving conditions.
2. Navigation system hides behind an analog clock.

Looks:
1. Exterior design is unmistakably Rolls-Royce.
2. Sumptuous leather interior.
3. Available customization.

New for 2013:
1. Redesigned bumpers.
2. New eight-speed automatic transmission.
3. Improved fuel consumption.

title: 2013 Mini Cooper Roadster
subTitle: All the fun of the Mini Coupe, now with the wind in your hair
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mini Cooper Roadster
promoTeaser: 2013 Mini Cooper Roadster
metaTitle: 2013 Mini Cooper Roadster Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mini Cooper Roadster Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Mini Roadster was all new for 2012, and adding a droptop option to the Coupe was a good move on Mini’s part. Featuring much of the same construction and technology as the Coupe, the Roadster distinguishes itself by losing the somewhat clunky hard top roof of its predecessor and serving up all the undeniable fun of a convertible. The John Cooper Works model is the most powerful, but no matter which engine model you choose the Roadster will deliver. The folding soft-top means the Roadster has even less cargo space than the Coupe and the interior can feel cramped, but the sporty-versus-space tradeoff is typical of convertibles, and the Roadster holds up well to its competition. The bold interior is almost identical to other Minis, with the large central speedometer and navigation system, toggle switches, and sport seats.  The 2013 Roadster will improve upon an already strong base by making the semi-automatic roof and rear windscreen standard, though of course this all comes at a price – specifically, a $1,200 bump from 2012. However, the Mini model of providing affordable performance automobiles rings true, and the Roadster still won’t break the bank.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competition:
1. Audi TT
2. Mazda MX-5 Miata
3. Volkswagen Eos

Cool Tech:
1. Available Sirius Satellite Radio.
2. Available center armrest with built-in iPhone cable.
3. Available Harmon-Kardon premium sound system.

Looks:
1. Many color combinations, racing stripes.
2. Distinctive Mini interior.
3. Attractive sport seats.

New for 2013:
1. Standard semi-automatic roof.
2. Standard rear windscreen.
3. Standard Bluetooth connectivity.

title: 2012 Mitsubishi I
subTitle: No one will think you’re weird if you hatch from an egg at the next social gathering-as long as the egg is a Mitsubishi i
promoTeaserSmall: 2012 Mitsubishi I
promoTeaser: 2012 Mitsubishi I
metaTitle: 2012 Mitsubishi I Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2012 Mitsubishi I Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Your convenience is a key factor to consider when buying a car and with the Mitsubishi i, those dreaded stops at the gas station when you’re running late in the morning are a thing of the past. With a combined driving range of 62 miles per battery charge, this little electric car is ideal for the city dweller whose daily travels consist of driving to the office and the grocery store. Since bigger is synonymous with better here in the States, the American i is longer and wider than its Japanese and European counterparts, but still manages to fit into cramped parking spaces with ease and, with the Rear Park Assist Sensors, is perfect for parallel parking on busy streets. Since the car is 100 percent electric, it does have to be charged on a regular basis. The lithium-ion battery found in your i can be charged overnight using a 120-volt portable charger, but if you’re impatient, you have the option of having a 240-volt charging system installed in your home to charge your car in seven hours. In some areas, it may even be possible to charge your car in less than half an hour at public vehicle charging stations.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Volt
2. Nissan Leaf
3. Smart ForTwo ED

Cool Tech:
1. Rear park assist sensors.
2. FUSE hands-free link system.

Looks:
1. Raspberry (purple) is available as an exterior color.
2. Floor carpet, instrument panel, and door trim made from recycled materials.

New for 2013:
None. Car won’t be in showrooms nationwide until early 2013.

title: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander
subTitle: The minivan of the Mitsubishi family, the Outlander is not to be confused with its similarly-named crossover cousin
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander
promoTeaser: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander
metaTitle: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: If you want the passenger volume of a minivan, but prefer the off-road capability of a truck or SUV, look no further. The Mitsubishi Outlander (not to be confused with the Outlander Sport) seats five comfortably, but is also available with seating for two additional passengers in the third row. As you chauffeur your children and their friends to and from school and extra-curricular activities, they can enjoy movies in the backseat, thanks to the new Entertainment Package on the Outlander. Meanwhile, you can drive with peace of mind knowing that you’re doing something to help the environment by driving a certified Low Emission Vehicle. You’ll also be giving your wallet a break, since the car gets a combined gas mileage of up to 25 mpg with the basic, 2.4-liter 4-cylinder engine that powers the Outlander ES and SE. It’s a perfectly fine engine, but if you’re a speed demon, it won’t let this 3,400-pound car accelerate very much. By upgrading to a GT model, not only do you get a V-6 engine, but your car will also come equipped with SiriusXM satellite radio, all-wheel control, hill start assist, and Mitsubishi’s FUSE hands-free link system.
Fun-O-Meter: 4

Competitors:
1. Dodge Journey
2. Hyundai Santa Fe
3. Subaru Outback

Cool Tech:
1. Micron air filtration system.
2. Rain-sensing windshield wipers.

Looks:
1. Exterior bears close resemblance to Lancer Evolution.
2. Exterior Package includes rear spoiler and “GT” badge.

New for 2013:
1. Heated side mirror now on ever Outlander at no extra cost.
2. Four new options packages.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The Kia Sorento SX AWD you see here is the absolute top-of-the-line Kia SUV. That's okay; if you are going to the back forty of the wilderness or the back forty rows of the opera house parking lot, it will work either way. But the SX AWD is $10,250 more expensive than the base 2013 Kia Sorento LX, which starts at $23,950 including destination.

The Kia Sorento SX AWD made its debut in 2011 and is aimed at giving the Sorento an edgier attitude, according to Kia.
The chief competition for the Sorento comes from the Toyota Venza, the Lexus RX350, and the Ford Edge.

EPA fuel economy on this Sorento SX AWD is 18 mpg in the city and 24 mpg on the highway with the V-6 engine and six-speed automatic transmission. Standard safety features include anti-lock brakes, stability control, and downhill brake control, and there are six air bags.

The Sorento sometimes gets lumped into the crossover/minivan category, but it is an SUV nonetheless. However, it's an SUV with plenty of upgrades to make it stand out in the carpool lane at school, including Infinity surround sound with ten speakers, LED taillights, chrome roof rails, and a set of eighteen-inch mirror finish wheels. The kids in said carpool will appreciate the rear A/C, too.

subTitle: New, second-generation GL keeps the luxury, gains more efficient engines and advanced safety systems.
promoTeaserSmall: New, second-generation GL keeps the luxury, gains more efficient engines and advanced safety systems.
promoTeaser: New, second-generation GL keeps the luxury, gains more efficient engines and advanced safety systems.
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz GL-Class Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Mercedes-Benz GL-Class here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The second-generation GL-class hitting showrooms in September has a greater number of luxurious appointments than ever while also catching up to the competition in terms of powertrain efficiency. By the time the GL63 AMG arrives in early 2013 as the last of the GL models to debut, buyers will choose from among four engines. A favorite is the turbo-diesel V-6 that makes 240 horsepower, but torque is what you feel first and at 455 lb-ft., it’s making fistfuls of it. The 4.6-liter V-8 is tuned for 362 horsepower in the GL450 4Matic and 429 horsepower in the GL550 4Matic. A seven-speed automatic transmission is common to all models. All-wheel drive is standard throughout the line. The GL gains slightly in length, width, and height. LED daytime running lights and tail lights accent the exterior, which has sleeker bumpers and a new grille. Inside, the driver looks at a colorful instrument display and everyone can enjoy the optional multi-color ambient lighting. Safety is seen to by the inclusion or availability of every sort of electronic abracadabra for lane keeping, curve-hugging, and close-to-curb parking. The standard power liftgate and power-folding third-row seats, with power-folding second row being optional, are desirable conveniences.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. BMW X5
2. Audi Q7
3. Infiniti QX56

Cool Tech Items:
1. Active parking assist scans the curbside for adequate space, guides the vehicle into place, and also has an automatic exit feature.
2. Active curve assist uses an electronically controlled hydraulic system to counteract the body’s tendency to roll on curves.
3. Optional push button capability for offroad driving.

Looks:
1. Panorama sunroof is optional.
2. Optional multi-color ambient lighting graces the interior.
3. LED technology is used for daytime running lights and taillights.

New for 2013:
1. Power-folding second-row seats ease third-row entry and power liftgate eases everyday tasks.
2. Colorful new instrument display is pleasing to driver.
3. New family of engines helps the GL to hold its own against competition.

title: 2013 GMC Sierra
subTitle: A very good truck that’s about to be replaced by an even better one.
promoTeaserSmall: A very good truck that’s about to be replaced by an even better one.
promoTeaser: A very good truck that’s about to be replaced by an even better one.
metaTitle: 2013 GMC Sierra Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 GMC Sierra here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: GMC is poised to launch an all-new Sierra pickup in 2013, information about which was not available at the time of this writing. In the meantime, dealers have stockpiled many 2012 Sierras that they may be eager to move. Among them should be a few “Heritage Edition” models rolling on chunky six-spoke, twenty-inch wheels, with rear fender liners, chrome trim bits, rear park assist, rear camera, adjustable pedals, and commemorative embroidery. Hybrid Sierras will continue through the 2013 model year using the current body style, still achieving 33 percent better city fuel economy than the standard Sierra and 23 percent better mileage overall. Heavy-duty Sierras, which also continue relatively unchanged through 2013, gain a new “bi-fuel” version of the 6.0-liter V-8 that allows them to run on compressed natural gas (if available), or gasoline. GM’s venerable 6.6-liter Duramax V-8 is on the options list, too, in case you have any houses that need to be towed somewhere. And as before, gussied-up Denali models of both light- and heavy-duty Sierras have been offered for people who want to live it up while hauling a load. All that said, while the Sierra is a fine truck, it’s not the freshest anymore. Watch this space for more information on the next-generation Sierras in coming months, with next-gen HD models expected to arrive within a year of the standard model’s arrival.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Nissan Titan
2. Toyota Tundra
3. Ford F-Series

Cool Tech Items:
1. New “bi-fuel” 6.0-liter V-8 compatible with gasoline and compressed natural gas.
2. Eighty-gig hard drive-based infotainment system with navigation available on HD models.

Looks:
1. Chrome-drenched Denali crew cab models offered on both standard and HD.
2. Larger grille and tall, louvered hood on HD model.
3. Embroidered seats, twenty-inch wheels, chrome trim, convenience items on 2012 Heritage Edition (light-duty models).

New for 2013:
1. Bi-fuel CNG-compatible 6.0-liter V-8 (HD models only).
2. Heritage Edition (late 2012 models).
3. Sonoma Red and Heritage Blue exterior colors (n/a on Denali).

pageElements.text: The Chevrolet Traverse is not your everyday seven- to eight-passenger SUV. Its attractively curvaceous body style and well-appointed interior set it apart from the basic family vehicle, and it’s priced starting at $31,000, so for a vehicle of its size and type, it’s attractive financially, too. For 2013, the Traverse gets a mild makeover inside and out. Part of the newness includes chrome accents and an updated center stack, as well as eight-way passenger seats and adjustable headrests. There’s also—first on the market—a front center air bag to protect people in the front seat in the event of a side collision. The third row of seats is split folding and is best left to the kids. In the second row, you can elect to have a bench seat to increase total seating capacity to eight. SUV-style options include a rear-view camera, Bose sound, a power liftgate, and a navigation system. Do any of those really sound like things you could live without? In this kind of vehicle, maybe not!
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Ford Expedition
2. GMC Yukon
3. Nissan Armada
4. Toyota Sequoia

Cool Tech Items:
1. Second row has SmartSlide that allows ease of access to third row with one hand—even by children.

Looks:
1. Upgraded interior with soft-touch instrument panel and door surfaces.
2. Ambient cabin lighting (optional).

New for 2013:
1. Revised appearance with “power dome hood,” chrome accents, redesigned taillamps and liftgate.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Silverado HD
subTitle: Nothing says “Yes, we can” like this kind of heavy-duty work truck.
promoTeaserSmall: Nothing says “Yes, we can” like this kind of heavy-duty work truck.
promoTeaser: Nothing says “Yes, we can” like this kind of heavy-duty work truck.

pageElements.text: Duramax twin-turbocharged diesel 6.6-liter V-8 power: it’s every bit as macho as it sounds, and that’s what powers the Chevrolet Silverado HD work truck. We at Jean Knows Cars don’t generally give a lot of thought to the finer points of torque, but consider the Silverado HD’s 765 pound-feet of torque, which is what gives this engine its massively competent trailer-toting strength. It’s also the reason that this truck gets a heavy-duty Allison automatic transmission—which can be shifted manually by the driver when the going gets dicey. In addition to that 397-horsepower V-8 diesel, there’s a choice of bi-fuel compatible or standard V-8 power, still nothing to sneeze at. There are even heavier-duty 2500HD and 3500HD versions, three-quarter-ton and one-ton, respectively. If you are interested in a truck that can run on compressed natural gas (CNG), get the extended-cab version of the 2500HD. Like its more normal-sized sibling, the regular Silverado, the HD comes in Ruby Red and Blue Topaz metallic exterior paint for 2013. But this truck is all about strength, not beauty: you can tow up to 23,100 pounds, depending on the model. Now that’s empowerment.
Fun-O-Meter: 3

Competitors:

pageElements.text: The Chevrolet Cruze name may not have the historical cachet in the small-car segment that is enjoyed by such competitors as the Honda Civic, but it has a lot going for it. For one thing, it’s peppy, with good highway smoothness and well-designed suspension. You can get it with a turbocharged 1.4-liter engine or a 1.8-liter engine with variable valve timing that makes 138 horsepower and yields 36 mpg on the highway. Beating that is the Cruze Eco model, which has lighter suspension parts and low-rolling-resistance tires, taking top honors for a non-hybrid at 42 mpg highway for the manual-transmission model. Chevrolet has also upped the technology ante on what was already a pretty great interior. Chevy’s MyLink information and entertainment system is standard on most versions, offering Bluetooth streaming audio and voice recognition. There are also two new audio systems on offer, including one with GPS navigation and a seven-inch color touchscreen. Perhaps the most appreciated 2013 addition is an optional Enhanced Safety package with park assist, blind-spot alert, and rear cross-traffic alert systems. To dress up your Cruze, there’s an RS appearance package with a rear spoiler, rocker moldings, an upgraded fascia, and chrome instrument panel accents instead of the standard silver. Top it off with a sliding power sunroof on LT and LTZ trim levels.

pageElements.text: Lincoln knows luxury, and if you are looking for luxury in size XXL, the Navigator might be the vehicle for you. This full-size SUV seats seven and comes in standard and extended-length forms and in rear- or all-wheel-drive versions. All are powered by a 5.4-liter V-8 that makes 310 horsepower, teamed with a smooth-shifting six-speed automatic transmission. Its towing capacity is a very capable 9,000 pounds, and it holds 128.2 cubic feet of stuff if you fold down the second row of seats. But practicality is only part of the story with the Navigator. Let’s start with the “responsibly harvested” walnut interior trim and go on upscale from there. A voice-activated touchscreen navigation system is standard, along with Sync AppLink that interacts with your smartphone, and the standard audio system is a THX II surround-sound system with fourteen (count 'em) speakers. The front seats are heated and cooled, the running boards are power deployed, and the pedals are adjustable. Safety equipment includes roll stability control with the added benefit of curve control, which maintains your hold on the Navigator when taking this big boy around curves quickly. Forward and reverse sensing systems both keep you apprised when you’re getting too close to objects. Here Lincoln gives a nod to “the full-size reality of the Navigator.”  No doubt about that! This is one large and in charge luxury vehicle for those who want to live the same way. Don’t expect favors at the gas pump, though: the Navigator tops out at 14 mpg city and 20 mpg highway for the rear-wheel-drive version, which is lowered to 13 mpg city and 18 mpg highway with all-wheel drive.

title: Dealer vs. Mechanic
subTitle: Some pros and cons for you
promoTeaserSmall: When your car breaks down, where should you take it?
promoTeaser: When your car breaks down, where should you take it?
metaTitle: Dealer vs. Mechanic - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Dealer vs. Mechanic: How do you decide whether it's better to take your car to the dealership or a mechanic when it needs to be serviced? Here are some pros and cons. The story is on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Despite the fact that I grew up just outside of Detroit, I was never particularly infatuated with cars. It wasn't until I headed to Washington, D.C., and began working for an environmental trade journal that I got an up close and personal look at what it takes to design an automobile. My first articles focused on efforts by legislators to make once heavily polluting cars run cleaner. When I moved back to Michigan, that became my focus as I contributed extensively to the Detroit bureaus of both the New York Times and Newsweek. I became fascinated by how the automobile impacts so many aspects of our lives and reflects our styles and preferences. Over the past two dozen years as a freelancer, I've covered the auto industry for a wide variety of publications, including Popular Mechanics, Scientific American, iVillage, Automotive News, Ad Age, Hemispheres, Technology Review, and AARP. I've also contributed pieces on air to public radio. My coverage has focused on such issues as the ways domestic automakers will respond to increasingly tough mandates for fuel-efficient cars while still designing vehicles that appeal to consumers, and my firsthand—and slightly scary—experience driving an autonomous car. But my stories are less about the vehicle than the person driving it. I'm most intrigued by the way people shape cars and cars shape those who drive them.

pageElements.text: When Nancy Baum and her husband were in the market for a new car, one of the most important criteria was "whether it could be serviced by Joe." Joe is Joe Bird, the owner of Japanese Auto Professional Service, Ltd., an independent repair shop in Ann Arbor, Michigan, where Baum and her husband have been taking their Hondas and Toyotas for ten years. Their interest in buying local caused them to consider purchasing their first American car, a Ford Fusion. "But then we realized Joe's only does Japanese cars,” Baum said. So, just before Labor Day weekend, they bought a 2012 Toyota Camry Hybrid instead. Baum says that Bird is the kind of neighborhood mechanic who is incredibly honest, vetoing repairs that aren't essential. She estimates he charged "hundreds of dollars less" for services than the dealer.

Finding an honest place to take your car for service and repairs can be daunting. While Baum's story resonates with the many who have found the perfect local independent mechanic, others wouldn't think of leaving their car with anyone but a trusted dealer technician. Still, some find the technician who can promptly and effectively handle a repair and charge a reasonable price elusive.

So how can you find an honest technician who performs high-quality work? Not surprisingly, dealers believe they're best equipped to provide service. “We want to take really good care of our customers so they continue to want to buy vehicles from us,” says Annette Sykora, owner of Smith South Plains dealership in Levelland, Texas. She said factory training for dealer technicians is extensive, so customers can be certain they’re getting someone who is qualified to do the job. She said that she, and most all dealers, surveys the landscape constantly to ensure she's competitively priced.

Independent service shop owners feel they're more than equipped to do any job. Bill Moss, owner of Ferris EuroService in Warrenton, Virginia, and a board member of the Automotive Service Association, says at independent shops, consumers will likely speak to an owner who has a stake in the service experience. The average ASA member consists of companies with under five employees. He also says he has less overhead than the dealer: "I'm not paying for all the tinted glass and marble floors," he says, so his prices tend to be ten percent less. Nikki Ayers, owner of Ayers Automotive Repair in Santa Barbara, California and executive director of The Independent Automotive Professional Association, which represents over 100 independent shops, said there's "nothing that an independent mechanic can't do."

But a March 2012 U.S. Customer Service Index by J.D. Power and Associates found that vehicle owners who visit dealers for service are far more satisfied than those who went to independent facilities. Customers of dealer facilities found satisfaction with the overall dealer experience was 38 points higher on a 1,000-point scale compared with non-dealer facilities. "Manufacturers and dealers have put a lot of investment into the customer experience in the past few years and we see that reflected in the scores," said Chris Sutton, senior director of J.D. Power's automotive retail practice.

Tricia Hecker, head of marketing at Mopar, Chrysler's service arm, says that dealers are well qualified to perform whatever type of service you need. "We make sure that if you come in for a brake job, you'll get a technician certified to perform one," she said. "If you go to an independent repair shop, there's no guarantee," since the smaller shops may not be equipped to service all the types of jobs that come through their door. She said there's such a range in the independent sector, it's hard to know the quality you're getting, while at the dealer, you can be assured the service is top-notch. She also says there's no significant difference in cost, despite the commonly held perception that dealer service is higher and customers are assured use of original equipment manufacturer parts, which are typically of higher quality.

Ayers acknowledges that the quality could vary significantly among independent shops. One key to look for, she says, is Automotive Service Excellence certifications. She has seven master technicians certified at her shop in the required eight areas: Engine Repair; Automatic Transmission/Transaxle; Manual Drive Train & Transaxle; Suspension & Steering; Brakes;  Electrical/Electronic Systems;  Heating & Air Conditioning;  and Engine Performance. The ASE certification is the gold standard, designed to provide a yardstick for consumers to be able to identify the individuals that have the knowledge necessary to repair their vehicles properly the first time, says Tony Molla, a spokesman for The National Institute for Automotive Service Excellence, the organization providing the certifications. He says over 370,000 technicians working in both dealerships and independent repair shops have this certification. While dealers represent only 30 percent of the repair business, a larger proportion of dealer technicians are certified. He said, though, that independent shops are typically less expensive and consumers find it to be a less intimidating experience than going to a dealer. But "both segments do an outstanding job servicing the vehicle fleet," he said.
Even so, there are some instances where it might make sense to go either to a dealer or independent repair shop.

If your car is under a factory warranty and you have a repair that falls under the warranty, only an authorized dealer can perform the repairs free of charge. The same goes for factory recalls, which can only be performed for free at dealerships.
There are some jobs that independents won't do, and if they're honest, they'll recommend you go to a dealership, Molla says.
For older cars, over ten years old, an independent mechanic who has more experience with these types of vehicles may be better suited to service them, Molla says.
For higher end cars, customers may prefer to the dealerships, though there are some "talented independent repair shops" that specialize in certain car models, he says.
Tips for Selecting a High Quality Service Facility Here's a checklist of measures you can take to find the facility -- be it independent mechanic or dealer -- that's right for you.

Check to make sure technicians are ASE certified and make sure they have the certification in the area of expertise that your car requires. Certificates may be posted in the waiting area that also lists when it expires, since technicians have to re-qualify every five years. There may also be a sign in front. If not, you can ask.
See if they're part of an industry trade group, like ASA or whether they're approved by AAA.
Check with the Better Business Bureau to see if the facility has been subject to any complaints.
Check out the reviews on the Internet. That's a "huge, third party indicator of people's experience," Moss says.

Look for professionals with good customer service skills. Make sure you're treated well. Also, do you feel comfortable asking questions about issues you don't understand? The technician should be able to communicate the service being performed and how much it will cost clearly and should be receptive to any questions you have. "Handling female customers is the constant source of seminars," Moss says. If the technician is condescending or sexist, go elsewhere. Molla points out that only one percent of technicians are female, so chances are you'll be dealing with a male.

Is the shop clean and well organized? This matters more to some than others. Nancy Baum was willing to overlook the disheveled waiting area in her favorite repair shop. "It feels very earnest to me. There's a bunch of people working hard and not putting a lot of money into having a fancy waiting room." But if you're seeking a clean, spacious waiting room to wait for your car, the facility ambience will be more important.

Ask your friends, neighbors and co-workers for their advice. Rich White, executive director of The Car Care Council, which oversees the Be Car Care Aware campaign that educates consumers on the benefits of regular vehicle maintenance and repair, says you can get tips from those you know and respect the most, asking where they take their car and if they're happy with the service.

Check out the cars in the parking lot and those being serviced, to see if they're similar to yours. "If you've got a Honda, you don't want to go to a place specializing in domestic vehicles," White says.
Try out a facility with simpler repairs like oil changes or tire rotations so you'll have a sense of whether you like them before you need a major repair.
For more ideas on what to look for in a repair shop, go to carcare.org
A list of repair facilities can also be found on CARQUEST's TechNet site: www.techauto.com

pageElements.text: Lexus has a slew of hybrids in its fleet, and most unique of the bunch is the funky CT200h hatchback. Six grand less expensive than the next-cheapest Lexu-brid, the ES300h sedan, the CT200h blends Lexus luxury, value, and high fuel economy together in equal measure. While its overall rating of 42 miles per gallon is nowhere near that of Toyota’s iconic Prius, it represents a far more comfortable and sexy way to get your green on, with its nicely padded interior rendered in premium materials and the slew of available premium upgrades such as LED headlamps, radar-based cruise control, and an updated navigation system operated by Lexus’s innovative “Remote Touch” interface. Lexus calls the CT200h fun to drive, and for a hybrid, it kinda is, so long as your notion of “fun to drive” does not make acceleration a big priority. Even with the gas pedal pushed to the floor, getting up to highway speeds is a leisurely and noisy affair. The CT200h does have somewhat lively handling (again, for a hybrid), particularly with the tighter F-Sport package, which adds a snug suspension, sportier wheels, a mesh grille, metal pedals, and available black leather seats with white perforations. And the seats are decidedly sporty in the way they cup one’s bum. Still, the CT200h is for hybrid shoppers more interested in gaining access to Lexus-grade luxury and cachet than sportiness or hypermiling.

pageElements.text: Lexus’s luxo-ute middle-child is the big-boned GX460. Truckier than the slinky RX crossover, but not quite as grandiose as the ginormous LX570, the GX460 is nearly as comfortable on the interstate as a full-size luxury car while offering nearly as much off-road dexterity as a Land Rover LR4, not that many GX460s (or Land Rovers, for that matter) are destined to venture off-road—ever. The GX seats up to seven in leather-lined luxury, though you might want to think twice before you stick your boss in the tight third-row seat. On non-carpool days, the power third-row seat folds flat to open up some much-needed cubes of cargo space, and that space becomes even greater with the second-row seats folded nice and flat. The throaty, 4.6-liter V-8 has sufficient power, but the big news for 2013 is the installment of Lexus’ new, somewhat redundantly named Kinetic Dynamic Suspension System, designed to counteract body lean both on the road and off. That’s a good thing, considering how top-heavy the GX460 is. But style-wise, the GX remains one of the only Lexuses not to feature the company’s new form vocabulary; hence, it suddenly looks old. Still, the GX460 offers a luxo-ute experience which offers as much ruggedness as comfort, all assembled with the exquisite execution for which Lexus has become famous.

pageElements.text: If you called your mother and told her you bought a new Toyota, she’d no doubt be pleased. “Oh, how responsible you’ve become,” she’d say. “You’re all grown up!” Now imagine her face when you pull up in an FJ Cruiser. More Hummer than Camry, the FJ Cruiser features cartoonish, Tonka toy (Tonka Toyota?) styling, making it something of a life-sized version of the knobby-tired toy trucks you may have played with in the sandbox as a youngster. Its most direct competitor is the Jeep Wrangler, to give you an idea of the FJ’s overall attitude, and with its locking rear differential, awesome ground clearance, and torquey, 260-horsepower V-6, the FJ is suitably fantastic off-road. (Side note: why Toyota never made a topless version of the FJ is simply beyond us.) On-road, it’s somewhat less at home, with horrendous blind spots, bump-a-long ride quality, and a slim, wide windshield that requires three wipers to clear. For an SUV, it also isn’t the most practical, thanks to its rear-hinged rear doors and modicum of cargo space. And don’t get us started on its fuel economy. That said, even though the FJ Cruiser is getting up there in years, we still love the way it looks. And best of all, it’s still an actual Toyota, which means that Mom will still approve.

title: Bosch Car Clinic
subTitle: First JKC ride-and-drive event earns our young journalist her wings.
promoTeaserSmall: JKC's first official participation in a ride-and-drive event earns our young journalist her wings.
promoTeaser: JKC's first official participation in a ride-and-drive event earns our young journalist her wings.
metaTitle: Bosch Car Clinic--JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Bosch Car Clinic: Find out about Bosch's technology work for automakers, as shown during a ride-and-drive event. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: If you’ve ever wondered what it’s like to be an auto journalist, well, that makes two of us. Most of my experience lies in reading public policy studies and sifting through zoning codes to unearth de jure injustices, so the fact that my job requires me to spend the whole day thinking about cars is still novel. Just don’t ask my bosses why they hired me, or they might change their minds.

After a few weeks getting my sea legs, I was thrown to the sharks at a ride-and-drive event at the extensive proving ground of Robert Bosch, LLC, in beautiful Flat Rock, Michigan. (People kept saying that to me as a joke, but I want to clarify that Flat Rock actually is beautiful, in a very Michigan sort of way: two-lane roads lined with judgmental cows and that sort of thing.)
When I got the assignment, I really wasn’t sure what to expect, but I did know that I might get to drive a few cars, which, in my book, is a good enough reason to go anywhere.

If you think of Bosch as a supplier of dishwashers and stereos, you’re missing a huge part of the picture. The company is sprawling, but a large part of what it does is research, develop, and sell technology to auto manufacturers. This company is behind the windshield wipers on the Ford Focus and the information and entertainment system in Cadillacs. Bosch is also at the forefront in developing fuel-saving and safety technologies. The company also helps make Bombardier’s seriously cool three-wheeled Spyder safer from rollovers.

When I walked through the door, after parking my war-weary Chevy among the shiny, comparatively expensive automobiles that filled the rest of the parking lot, I knew some of this, but not all of it. I was interested in Bosch’s involvement in clean diesel technology (you should be, too), and I’m not ashamed to say I was really, really excited to drive some cars.

The first order of the day was breakfast, which was really just built-in networking time. It became immediately clear to me that most of the people in the room had not only met before, but in many cases had been working in the same industry for years or even decades. I had been working in this industry for approximately six weeks, but luckily my new colleagues have proven to be a kind and welcoming bunch. I got a lot of questions about Jean Knows Cars, which almost no one had heard of, since we were still deep in the task of launching at the time. One man looked at my name tag a little skeptically, then said, “I’ve never read any of your stuff.” He laughed when I told him that no one had yet.

images.caption: Flat Rock, MI
Flat Rock, MI
Flat Rock, MI
Flat Rock, MI

pageElements.text: Next was the meat and potatoes: eight stations, rotating counterclockwise, with technical experts explaining some of their coolest, most innovative technology. Some of this was right up my alley: I’d done research on start/stop technology, I’d used Cadillac Cue, and I was familiar with emergency braking systems. In other areas, I was woefully out of my depth. DC/DC converters? I’m pretty sure they have something to do with electricity. Alternators? Might be related to the engine? The different operating modes of internal-combustion engines? Yeah, no. I tried to soak it all in, and I took comfort knowing that many of the rest of my cohorts were just as confused as I was. We were liberal arts majors all around, as far as I could tell: the type of people who were just smart enough to figure out they weren’t smart enough to engineer drivetrains.

I actually learned a lot. Mostly, I learned that engineers are well aware that most consumers want to lower their fuel consumption without giving up any driving enjoyment, and luckily for us, they have a lot of ideas about how to make that happen.

Bosch is poised to benefit from new fuel regulations that will require passenger vehicles to average 31.6 miles per gallon by 2013, with a huge jump to 54.5 miles per gallon in 2025. Bosch believes that its start/stop technology, which allows a vehicle’s engine to turn off while the car is stopped and then seamlessly re-engage when the gas is depressed, can lead to fuel savings of up to 15 percent in city traffic.

Bosch is also involved in bringing diesel technology to the North American market, and the company is determined to recast diesel’s negative image in the United States. Diesel engines in lightweight vehicles (not the pickups and semis we’re used to seeing them in) can add up to 200 miles to the life of a tank of gas, according to the preliminary results of a study Bosch cited from the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute.  The technology is spreading from luxury manufacturers like Audi and BMW to other makes, including Volkswagen, Mazda, Jeep, and Chevrolet. Bosch says that there will be more than twenty diesel launches in 2013--with fifty-four diesel launches scheduled between now and 2017.

Bosch also works on products designed to make the driving experience safer, like forward collision mitigation, which can slow a car down ahead of a collision to reduce damage, and adaptive cruise control to maintain an automatic safe following distance from the vehicle ahead. If there is danger of a front collision, the technology can give a visual or auditory warning and briefly apply the brakes to make sure the driver is paying attention. Kay Stepper, director of driver assistance engineering, said the company has a “vision of accident-free driving” and hopes that technology like this can reduce the number of crashes--currently up to 90 percent--that are due to driver error.

After a lunch break came the driving. Much of my young life has been spent practically begging people with nicer cars than me for their keys. I have occasionally invented minor car trouble for a seat behind the wheel of my father’s Volkswagen (“I hear a weird ticking noise under the passenger seat… Will you trade cars with me?”). The idea that I could just walk up to any car I wanted and drive it around what essentially amounts to a small racetrack was almost too much to believe. I kept thinking, “Don’t these people realize they’ve just turned the car over to a total fiend?”

Apparently not, because even after I giggled a little while behind the wheel of a turbo-diesel Volkswagen Beetle, they just kept opening the doors. I also drove a surprisingly sprightly turbocharged Ford Escape, two different Mercedes-Benzes with impressive start/stop technology, a Ford Focus with fancy windshield wipers, and a Peugeot 3008 HYbrid4. (When I was coming around the track’s banked curve in the Peugeot, the engineer in the passenger seat said, “Now slowly accelerate up to 50.” Then he realized I was already going almost 60 mph. Whoops.)
All in all, it wasn’t a bad way to spend the morning. I would encourage the rest of you to become automotive writers, but I don’t want the secret to get out.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: This You Auto Know video could be subtitled "government sites that are actually useful." Safercar.gov is a site belonging to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, also known as NHTSA, and it has a lot of information you can use every day. Use it to find government crash test safety ratings and recall notices, but come back to it for a wealth of other information. From car seat installation details to clear explanations of rollover protection technology, you probably need it, and Safercar.gov probably has it.

contributors.bio:
I’m a jazz aficionado, a car geek, a food lover, and a goofy mom. I'm lucky enough--or foolish enough--to be able to turn most of my avocations into something resembling a vocation. Except for motherhood, but that's its own reward, right?

I was a record store geek back when there were record stores, and worked at the venerable (and late, lamented) Schoolkids' Records in Ann Arbor through college, while spinning jazz records at WEMU to the taxi drivers, barflies and night owls who listened during the wee hours. I then spent a dozen years as the corporate jazz buyer for the Borders Books & Music chain, a job that even in hindsight seems too good to be true.  After the music business--and Borders-imploded, I pursued another passion and joined the staff of AnnArbor.com as a food writer and community content coordinator. I spend a lot of time cooking, eating and writing, which also often feels too good to be true.
 
And now cars. I’ve been a car geek since I could walk. I caught the bug from my dad, who saved up the paychecks he earned pumping gas as a teen in western New York until he could afford a gorgeous vintage 1939 Oldsmobile. My first car was my parents’ old Dodge Spirit--an innocuous-looking car that hid a turbocharged V6 under the hood. That car took me all over the country--and fast. If I shoved a Kleenex in the tape player to stop the rattling, I could easily cruise at 120 mph, a thought that now--as a mom--strikes fear in my heart.

pageElements.text: I remember the afternoon we got sent home from the hospital with our new baby. No one checked to make sure that we weren’t too clumsy to hold him without dropping him.  There was no task force sent out to make sure we had bought a proper crib. We didn’t have to pass a swaddling test.
“Don’t you even want to follow us out to make sure we’ve got the car seat in right?” I asked the nurse.

“No, I’m sure you’ve got it just fine,” she assured us with a smile that let us know that we weren’t the first new parents to worry that we weren’t quite ready to be trusted with such an important bundle.
A few months into parenthood and the kid was still thriving, so I began to think that maybe we did have the skills to keep him alive. But I never stopped worrying about car seats.

There are all kinds of statistics to show us what kind of potential we parents have to screw it all up.  Vehicle crashes are the number one killers of children ages three to fourteen. Three out of four car seats are installed or used incorrectly.  It’s a wonder any kids make it to puberty.

For us, the biggest questions centered on when it was time to move to the next type of car seat. Each transition was anxiety inducing. Yeah, his legs are way too long to remain in the rear-facing seat, but are his neck muscles strong enough to hold that giant head up if we get in a collision? Yes, his five-point harness barely fits, but is he really ready for a booster seat?

When we finally decided that he was ready for a booster, I was ready to celebrate. Infant and convertible seats are expensive. Too expensive to buy for each car and each set of grandparents. So every time you switch cars, or send him off with Grandma for the day, you have to move the car seat over and reinstall it, all the while remembering that statistic about poorly installed car seats.

Boosters are awesome. Inexpensive. Easy to install. Someone else is taking your kid home from school? Just send him in with his own booster seat. There would be days when I’d see half a dozen boosters lining the hall at daycare, each labeled with the kid’s name in masking tape.

My son is ten now. We’re solidly in the post-car-seat years. I’ve handed them down or thrown them all away at this point. I’ve got six good years now. Six years when I don’t have to worry if I’m using the wrong car seat. Six years until I have to worry about him driving. God help me.

contributors.bio:
Robert Cumberford is a designer who became a writer by accident. His race report on the 12 Hours of Sebring was published when he was an eighteen-year-old Art Center student in 1954. Subsequently he has published thousands of articles on cars and airplanes, in American, Asian, English, European, and South American magazines. He contributed to several books, including the entire text of the well-reviewed Auto Legends, now available in five translated editions -- French, German, Spanish, Italian, and Polish in addition to the original English version. In 1985, Automobile Magazine founder David E. Davis, Jr., invited him to be one of two executive editors when Automobile was in the planning stages. Cumberford demurred, saying he knew nothing about magazine production and claims he still doesn’t, except that it’s important to meet deadlines. He contributed features from the beginning and began his popular “By Design” column in the sixth issue, September 1986.

In car design, Cumberford was even more a youthful prodigy. He sketched the body for the first car ever built to his designs when he was a fifteen-year-old Los Angeles high-school student. That car, the Parkinson Jaguar Special, is still active in historic racing sixty years after it was created. Hired directly by General Motors’ legendary Vice President of Design, Harley J. Earl, Cumberford became a professional car designer at nineteen. Leaving Detroit, he returned to California to attend UCLA to study philosophy. He rejoined the automotive world in the early 1960s and has continued to create new automotive shapes since then, always as an independent design consultant. He has lived and worked in six of the fifty United States and in France, Mexico, and Switzerland. The range of his design projects includes both racing and touring cars, trucks, aircraft, boats, hovercraft, and even ecological architecture.

He is known worldwide for strong opinions but is well-respected in the design world because it is known that he is always completely honest in his views, with no agenda other than respect for good design and good designers. “There’s no ad hominem,” he says, “I judge the design, not the designers. There are designers I really like personally who’ve been credited with designs I heartily dislike -- for reasons I always state very clearly -- and designs I love done by people with whom I have absolutely no affinity. Except that we both like their work.”

pageElements.text: There is undoubted romance to cars, never better expressed than by Ned Jordan’s classic advertisement for his Twenties Playboy roadster saying “Somewhere west of Laramie there’s a bronco-busting, steer-roping girl…” There’s romance to pianos, too, beautifully explained in Thad Carhart’s The Piano Shop on the Left Bank, subtitled “Discovering a Forgotten Passion in a Paris Atelier.”

Despite that similarity, if you try to draw a link between automobiles and pianos — or vehicles and any musical instrument, for that matter — most people cannot see any possible connection. In fact, there have been quite a few surprising associations, beginning in the nineteenth century and continuing to the very latest international motor show, the Mondial de l’Automobile in Paris this month. Along with an exotic concept car, Peugeot showed a prototype piano conceived with the aid of the venerable piano maker Maison Pleyel, which, like Peugeot itself, was founded more than 200 years ago. Pleyel is the oldest piano maker in the world, and although it is not as well known as Baldwin, Bechstein, Bosendorfer, or Steinway and Sons, it is highly respected by musicians everywhere.

The Steinway-Daimler Connection

The first automobile-piano connection was between the Steinway piano company and Gottlieb Daimler. In 1888, when the American piano manufacturer William Steinway was traveling in Europe, he heard of Daimler’s motorized quadricycle. Intrigued, he went to Cannstatt, a district in Stuttgart, Germany, to experience the vehicle for himself. He was impressed enough by his “cross country” ride that he undertook a license to build Daimler’s engines, used first for boats and streetcars and then for trucks. That led to the New York City manufacture under license of a few Mercedes-Benz cars in 1905, a venture stopped by a factory fire in 1907.

The Pleyel-Chopin Connection

Ignaz Pleyel, a student of Joseph Haydn and, in his own right, an accomplished musician and composer (forty-one symphonies, hundreds of string quartets and quintets), established his piano works in 1807 as an adjunct to his musical publishing house, Maison Pleyel. His purpose was to create instruments that enhanced the capabilities of musicians, including the virtuoso Chopin. Pleyel was a constant innovator and the first to make pianos with metal frames, as opposed to the all-wood structures used previously. That history of creation and change was one of the inspirations for the collaboration of the firm he founded with today’s Peugeot Design Lab, an ancillary part of the car company’s design operation dedicated to work for clients outside the automotive group.

2005: BMW 507 Designer Tries Hand at Steinway Type A

In recent years, there have been other exercises wherein car designers have tackled piano design. For the 125th anniversary of the Steinway’s Hamburg, Germany, operation in 2005, Albrecht, Count Goertz, a German-born American industrial designer best known for his masterpiece BMW 507 sports car, and for having imagined the Datsun 240Z, a great commercial success, was commissioned to create a baby grand piano. It was classical in appearance and very beautiful, with different textures and shades of black finish, but it broke no new technical ground. As the model A-188, it is available today at an unchanged price, $77,400.

2007: Porsche Design's Bosendorfer Grand Piano

Two years later, F.A. Porsche Design proposed another classically shaped grand piano for German piano maker Bosendorfer, this time with some functional changes from the concert grand piano pattern established in 1875 by Henry Englehard Steinway. The lid was made of a honeycomb-core material, lightweight but stiff enough to reflect sounds into the concert hall. The price is $120,000, about the same as a well-equipped Porsche 911 Carrera coupe, and it looks to weigh about the same as well.

2009: Audi Design's Bauhaus-Inspired Bosendorfer

Then, in 2009, Audi Design stylists did another Bosendorfer, this time taking the backboard almost all the way to the floor. The form was clearly inspired by Bauhaus concepts from the 1920s, with carefully delineated discrete shapes for each distinct component of the whole, including the keyboard and its cover, the pedal lyre in aluminum, and the pedals themselves. Apart from the fact that the lid is hinged below the upper perimeter of the piano, there are few changes from the classical form. This piano is commercially available for about $140,000 — again, comparable to the prices of top Audi car models.

2012: Peugeot and Pleyel Advance the Art

But, as shown in the photos above, none of the efforts in the time since William Steinway went into the car business have so completely altered the idea of what a grand piano should be as the Peugeot-Pleyel project. True to Ignaz Pleyel’s open mind in moving piano design forward, the new design incorporates advanced materials — carbon-fiber-reinforced plastics, principally — with a radical repositioning and reproportioning of the technical elements of the piano. The entire sound-producing set of strings has been lowered so that it is on a level with the keyboard. Thus, the pianist’s hands can be seen by the audience, and the artist himself or herself benefits from a better sound experience.

Instead of three legs, the piano is supported by a single pedestal formed of an aerodynamically styled carbon fiber molding. To avoid any resonance of the hollow cantilever, it is filled with foam to make it acoustically inert. The soundboard and main body are made of wood according to traditional practice, giving a rich sound available with no other material. The lid is carbon fiber, but it does not require a prop to hold it open. Instead, gas struts and a clever mechanical linkage allow the lid to be opened and positioned by one hand.

Like the other three contemporary car-designer pianos, the Pleyel by Peugeot Design Lab is available for purchase. Priced at €165,000 (about $205,000), it is a science-fiction-like transformation of a well-known object. It maintains all the virtues of its ancestors while bringing a true advance in presenting the performer’s hands to concert goers for the first time since the concert grand was conceived.

pageElements.text: One of the things I do as editor of Automobile Magazine is go to auto shows all over the world. Paris isn’t usually the most important auto show, although this year it was crazy with dozens of world premieres. But even on the sleepier year, the Paris show is one of my favorites for one big reason: it’s in Paris. And it’s in Paris at the right time of the year, late September. It happens every other year (just to build my enthusiasm), alternating with the much less glamorous (but way more important) Frankfurt show.

I like to arrive in Paris a couple of days early to visit my favorite boutiques and perfume store. The show itself I can see in one good day. It’s dominated by the three big French manufacturers—Renault, Citroen, and Peugeot—which never fail to deliver gorgeous displays and wacky concept cars. There’s so much going on, I thought it would be fun to just capture the insanity of it all with my Flip camera, also known as the JeanCam. Not the most professional video you’ve ever seen, but I hope you’ll enjoy just a glimpse of all the different things I did when I was there. I’m working on my technique for next time.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/toIrFnxnGNI?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

My crazy trip included a test drive of the all-new Mazda 6, so there’s a Jean’s Driveway review right in the middle of this video, thanks to my temporary cameraman, Automobile Magazine senior editor Joe Lorio, who held the Flip steady while I sat in the car on the show stand.
For a more serious report on the Paris auto show, go to Automobilemag.com.

pageElements.text: Mercedes-Benz's first furniture collection is rolling out this month, as the German automaker continues to expand its brand beyond luxury cars. Mercedes-Benz's Style division, in collaboration with the Italian Formitalia Luxury Group, will be choosing U.S. outlets for the furnishings this fall, and they'll be available for purchase for as yet undisclosed prices. Formitalia Design Group also offers Aston Martin and Lamborghini interior furnishings.

You won’t find the iconic three-pointed-star hood ornament adorning these high-end pieces, which include a sofa, a chaise longue, a dining room table, chairs, a sideboard, an  integrated home theater system with seating area, a chest of drawers, and a bed. Mercedes-Benz Style and   opted for a streamlined, minimalist approach to furniture design. You'll have to look carefully to find the subtle Mercedes-Benz Style logo on the pieces.

The unmistakable link to the cars is there in many ways, from wooden chair backs inspired by the seat shells in current Mercedes-Benz research vehicles to the sofa’s aluminum frame, which reminds one of the company's car design aesthetic. The dining table uses a central aluminum beam as well, with legs designed to look like sculptured wheel spokes. The sideboard has a glass door with a surrounding bezel that looks like the air intake on a sports car.
The Home Theatre System is painted in original Indium Silver metallic paint and has three wing-shaped wooden shelves--an evocative concept for any Mercedes-Benz connoisseur, to be sure.

Some of the top Mercedes-Benz designers are at work at Villa Salazar, the Advanced Design Studio, in Como, Italy. There, the late fashion designer Gianni Versace once made neckties. Mercedes-Benz said the designers are charged with tracking interior trends for homes as well as cars.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: High fashion may not be the first thing that comes to mind when you think of the 2013 Malibu, but don’t tell that to the folks at Chevrolet. The brand has teamed up with designer Isaac Mizrahi to create a six-piece clothing collection designed with the Malibu in mind.

Chevrolet expects that women will be important to the new 2013 Malibu’s sales. Mary Kubitskey, advertising manager for the Malibu,  said that working with Mizrahi on the collection has helped Chevy “speak to women who embrace style, but still want a smart product to make their lives easier.” In a video for Chevrolet, Mizrahi said that he tries to create “beautiful, wonderfully indulgent things for smart women.”

If Chevy is looking to attract savvy buyers to its $23,150 Malibu, Isaac Mizrahi is the man to do it. Mizrahi has made a name for himself designing trendy clothes for the everyday buyer. He teamed up with Target for an affordable collection in the early 2000s before moving on to revamp the Liz Claiborne brand.

Mizrahi designed six pieces for the Malibu-inspired collection, which drew heavily on the car’s colors and textures. The blue pieces in the collection were born of the Malibu’s blue interior lighting, while red elements echo the Crystal Red Tintcoat exterior color (coincidence that Mizrahi chose to highlight an extra-cost paint color?). Available leather interior touches are showcased with a “buttery” leather coat and driving moccasins.

The items in the collection are priced from $70 to $300 and include red skinny jeans, a blue leather tote bag, a black leather jacket, an oversize watch, a robin’s-egg-blue blouse, and the aforementioned red leather driving moccasins. The items went on sale October 16 exclusively on LivingSocial, an online marketplace that posts deals on various items.
It may not be every girl who wants to color-match her sedan, but isn’t it nice to know you have the option?

pageElements.text: Maybe you haven’t thought of using your car as a tool for romance since high school, but even if you aren't feeling like a starry-eyed newlywed at the moment, you have to recognize that going for a ride in a car together can be very sexy.

It is in this spirit that Ford has teamed up with an unlikely companion to market the new 2013 Fusion: YourTango.com, a (rather salacious) online community “dedicated to helping women live their best love lives.” This fall, Ford partnered with the website on a poll that asked couples about their road trips together. Their conclusion? A road trip together might be the perfect way to reconnect with your significant other.
“With so many couples struggling with stress and looking for ways to stay connected, we can now offer a new, easy answer: try going on a road trip!” says YourTango CEO Andrea Miller.
According to the results of the poll, 91 percent of couples had taken a road trip together, and 84 percent said they felt the experience improved their bond.

The survey found this to be true even in spite of the landmine of difficulties presented by backseat driving. Despite the 27 percent who make helpful suggestions about directions, the majority of couples felt that their trip was “fun filled” and even “relaxing.”

Ford participated in this survey as part of its promotion of the mid-size 2013 Fusion. Now, perhaps mid-size sedans aren't the first type of vehicle you think about when you imagine a romantic outing. Personally, If I had to choose the perfect road trip mobile, I would choose a Volkswagen Westfalia (you can’t help rekindling romance when your car has a built-in mattress), but it’s hard to come by a Westy these days, so a Fusion might have to do the trick.
