title: Eating in the Car: Our Top Picks
promoTitle: Eating in the Car: Our Top Picks
promoTeaserSmall: Whether on a long trip or pressed for time, food happens in the car. Here's how we make it work.
promoTeaser: Whether on a long trip or pressed for time, food happens in the car. Here's how we make it work.
metaTitle: Eating in the Car: Our Top Picks - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Eating in the Car: Our Top Picks. Read the JeanKnowsCars.com staff's picks for best food to eat in the car. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: There are those who ban eating in their vehicles on the grounds that eating is messy, germy, and simply not a classy thing to do in the car. To those tasteful individuals, I say: Oh, please. Having snacks in the car makes a long drive more amusing, comforting, and sociable.  And there isn't a parent out there who hasn't needed to feed kids on the move because there wasn't enough time in the day.
If you carry healthy snacks that you pack ahead of time, over the long term you might be saving millions of calories and lots of cash that you might have spent on drive-through junk food.
Or, look at it another way: a drive can be made a lot more fun if you do hit the drive-through or the gas station shop for the kind of fun food you wouldn't deign to touch under normal circumstances.
I asked everybody here at Jean Knows Cars to share their favorite in-car food choices. But first, here are the three rules to follow when you're eating in the car.

image.caption: Gabrielle George keeps her eyes on the road and her hands on the wheel.

pageElements.text:
1. Don't let it be a distraction.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration identifies eating while driving as one of the major distracted-driving behaviors. Don't take your eyes off the road to deal with food, and whenever possible, eat only while you're a passenger or the car is not moving. Don't be the slob careening down the expressway at 80 mph with a cheeseburger in one hand and a soda in the other.

image.caption: Observe the neatness of videographer Scott Allen.

pageElements.text:
2. Don't let it trash your car.

It's not difficult to bring along napkins or, my personal favorite, a kitchen towel to put on your lap. It's even easier to have a plastic bag to store the trash and scraps from in-car dining. Wet wipes make life easier when children are the ones eating in the car; bring some of those.

3. Don't make it a substitute for real meals.

I once read a memorable article about a bulimic woman who said the only two places she ever ate were in bed and in the car. That's extreme, but it's easy (especially on a road trip) to go too far with the drive-through and picnic behavior. Stop at a roadside restaurant, or make your snacks light so you can get home and have a real dinner at the table.

My Picks

Keep in mind, I have been transporting my four kids in a minivan for two decades now, so no highbrow food choices for me. My standby is a cooler filled with juice, water bottles, peanut-butter-and-jelly sandwiches, crackers, and fruit for meals. I like it when everybody can have a snack when they want one, which cuts way down on crankiness. On road trips, I supplement by letting them get sunflower seeds, soda, chips, and Sour Patch Kids at gas stations. I am also perfectly willing to live off drive-through food for short periods. My favorite crunchy snack for everybody in the family is Bugles, because they satisfy salt cravings without being too greasy or crumbly.

As for myself, I am content if I have a never-ending supply of coffee and lots of chewing gum. For some reason, as long as I can chew gum, I can be alert and content while driving. My number-one banned substance is any kind of energy drink or supplement. If I'm too tired to perk up from coffee, I'm ready to stop driving.

image.caption: Jean Jennings tries to keep it healthy.

pageElements.text:
Jean Jennings's Picks

I plan ahead with a list of healthy food choices in the car: a bag of apples, oranges, bottles of water, baby carrots, Twizzlers (a giant bag), raw walnuts, pecans, almonds, and Brazil nuts mixed with dried cherries and cranberries.

I learned how to eat on road trips by doing the One Lap of America race three times. When it's a long road trip where we plan to spend some real hours in the car, we make it a point to eat one light meal, and we get out of the car and sit at a table to do it. We look for something like a Bob Evans, because they have really great salads and a healthy menu.

Actually what I really like in the car are gumdrops, jellybeans, M&M Peanuts, and full-fat Wheat Thins, but I'm a diabetic. And by the way, the Twizzlers are for my husband.

image.caption: Molly Jean goes for candy with high sugar value.

pageElements.text:
Molly Jean's Picks

I must have gum. For meals, Subway sandwiches and chips. If I have to eat fast food, Wendy's. It always grosses me out about two-thirds of the way through the burger, but I do love the fries. For treats, a bag of really sugary candy, like Sour Patch Kids, Good and Plenty, and Mike and Ikes.

My family's latest indulgence is fresh-popped popcorn (made before we leave the house); a nice, big glass of Coke in a Tervis tumbler full of ice; and plenty of napkins. Heaven! The popcorn travels in a large brown paper grocery bag.

image.caption: Neatness is prized in the Christina Lawson vehicle.

pageElements.text:
Christina Lawson's Picks

I generally don't like to eat in the car (it gets messy), but my one rule is that the food has to be as self-contained as possible. Nothing that requires peeling, nothing that crumbles, nothing that requires mixing, nothing that requires utensils.

Favorites: Grapes, pre-peeled oranges, blueberries, raspberries, hulled strawberries, prepackaged crunchy snacks like Cheez-Its (preferably reduced fat: no greasy residue on your hands) and pretzels, grapes, cherry tomatoes, carrots, celery, string cheese, pre-made peanut butter sandwiches (no jelly), and protein bars.

Least favorites: Anything with a pit, a core, or a peel; anything (like melon) that causes sticky fingers; pastries. I'm on the fence about things like cereal and trail mix. You never know when (not if) something is going to miss your mouth and land on the floor to get stepped on.
I believe in keeping a trash container in the car, as well as napkins, wipes, tissues, and hand sanitizer to clean up before and after eating.

Annie White's Picks

I've always felt strongly that there are times in life when attempts at healthy living must be abandoned in favor of eating and doing whatever you damn well please, because life is short and taste buds die. I apply this philosophy on holidays, birthdays, any day when I've spent more than two consecutive hours exercising, and, of course, during road trips. Healthy food for the car? No, thank you. Salty snacks, please, with a side of ice cream from the gas station.

I have a few go-to snacks that have been elevated to a place of honor in the road food hall of fame. Cheetos, Funyuns (gross, I know), pretzels, beef jerky, salted cashews, peanut butter M&Ms, and sour gummy worms are consistent favorites. Their only value is that I love eating them, and it's possible to do with eyes on the road and a hand on the wheel. I also keep apples and bananas on hand for when I get that horrible feeling that I get when I haven't consumed any valuable calories in days.

image.caption: Annie White knows that the good life involves an occasional burrito (left) or slice (right).

pageElements.text: When I'm lucky enough to be starting a road trip from Ann Arbor, I go to Zingerman's Deli and buy a fantastically expensive BLT to eat at a picnic table at a rest stop somewhere.  Worst road trip food: burritos. Because you will look like this (left) when you try to eat one while driving.

title: 6 Fun Car Social Media Destinations
promoTeaserSmall: Car companies are finding increasingly good ways to catch your eye, from games to charity programs.
promoTeaser: Car companies are finding increasingly good ways to catch your eye, from games to charity programs.
metaTitle: 6 Fun Car Social Media Destinations - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 6 Fun Car Social Media Destinations: Check out our list of six car companies' social media efforts that we deem fun to visit. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: When my sister-in-law, Emily Gilligan, had problems with her 2005 GMC Yukon's transmission, the first place she thought to connect with the auto company was General Motors' social media site. She asked if there were any recalls. "They got back to us within a week and said they were sorry to say that there were no open recalls on our model," she told me. "Of course, I wish they had paid for our repairs," which were just under $2,000, "but I was pleased that they did the research."

Getting in touch with the social media site was easier and quicker for Emily than Googling the problem. She's not alone: it's becoming more natural all the time to look to social media to interact with products and brands we like. The car companies are noticing, and now you can see them on Twitter, YouTube, Instagram, Facebook, and Pinterest. Why would you want to go to a car company's Instagram or Pinterest pages? In part, because the car companies have found ways to make it interesting, enjoyable, and profitable for you to spend time there.

Scott Monty, manager of digital and multimedia communications for Ford, told us that his company's social media goes beyond a straightforward advertisement for its products, looking to engage consumers on a whole different level. Ford uses social media to cover "our major pillars: green technology, fashion and design, parents, and more." As he said, these are all areas where "people aren't necessarily thinking about Ford.

"On average, people look at eighteen or nineteen pieces of research or sites before they make a car purchase," Monty said.  "We work hard to ensure that somewhere along the way they come across Ford content in a social context, because we know that people talk to friends, family members, and colleagues. Word of mouth matters, and our site supports that effort."

It's a clever strategy for the car companies, but beyond that, it means that there's a new, social dimension to your car-buying and car-owning experience now, if you choose to click on it. Here are six social media sites we appreciate, and you might, too:

1. Ford's Social Club

Ford Social began in 2008 as more of a political action site than a social play area. Originally, it was known as The Ford Story. "We developed it to help tell Ford's story when we were testifying in Congress during the financial crisis, as we needed to set ourselves apart from the other domestic automakers," Monty said.

The site has evolved into a combination news site, fan blog, and playground. Its Grab a Badge feature lets you choose icons that show up on your own Facebook page. "Built Ford Tough," anyone? Or how about "I (heart) Hybrids"? It features stories such as "Emerald with Envy," a photo gallery of Fords in various shades of green; readers' own articles about their first cars or their road trips; and a smartphone app called Motor Me that lets you take a picture of your car and make it talk using a message you record. Then you can share this silliness with others. On a more serious note, there's a place to make suggestions to Ford on how to improve its vehicles. There are also various real-life opportunities offered, such as joining Ford at auto shows as a citizen journalist or meeting company executives.

2. Toyota's Philanthropy

Toyota gave away 100 vehicles to nonprofits in both 2011 and 2012 in a program it called 100 Cars for Good. Rather than just issue a press release, it set up a Facebook page, a Twitter feed, and a YouTube channel to make the giveaway interactive. Nonprofit organizations got to apply, and then finalists were voted on via Facebook. You can go to the Facebook link to look at video clips from the winning organizations and look at stats on which Toyota vehicles the groups chose. (Not surprisingly, nearly half picked the versatile Sienna minivan, while nine showed their green credentials by picking the Camry Hybrid or the Prius v.) Plus, your Facebook friends who voted appear in icons on the page. If this page gives you a warmer feeling about Toyota, that's just what the company had in mind.

3. Honda's Owner Love

The band Monsters Calling Home, who recorded videos while riding around in Hondas, are a central part of the Honda Loves You Back Facebook page. Watch their videos, read about them, but also check out the Honda jack-o'-lanterns, the photo gallery of people's Honda logo manicures, and the VTEC logos they've had shaved into the back of their heads. Or, maybe, add your own.

4. Story Time with Volkswagen

Why VW is a storytelling platform that enables Volkswagen owners and enthusiasts to share their VW experiences and check out other people's tales. The company's social media presence has already reached nearly 90,000 followers since its launch last September.

"When we launched the Why VW stories, we partnered with the Poptent creative community to source videos from real-life Volkswagen owners and enthusiasts talking about their cars," explained Leigh Anne Sessions, who works in product and brand communications for Volkswagen of America. For example, "A Rabbit, A Farm, and A Story of Success" is a piece about Bob MacLeod and Steve Byckiewicz who founded a successful business with the use of a diesel-powered Rabbit in the early 1980s. Fast forward to 2013, and that business, Kiss My Face, is a multimillion-dollar natural healthcare company.

5. Fiat's E-zine

Fiat's Facebook page is set up more like a magazine than a mere fan page. There's a professionally filmed storytelling series called Alternate Routes, which makes for enjoyable viewing. Plus, you can upload your own story in the Story Booth, although this is a curated site; you have to wait and get chosen.

6. Under the Blue Arch with Chevrolet

Chevrolet's Under the Blue Arch is based around a fictional Chevrolet showroom. Watch the video, reminiscent of The Office, and select one of the (fictional) employees to watch his or her personal video. Take the quiz to find out which character you are. Download memes featuring the characters! It's all pretty ironic for a salt-of-the-earth brand like Chevrolet, which makes it that much more fun. On a more serious note, you can interact on the Facebook page in a variety of conversations about everything from what an aero grille is to truck talk.

It boils down to this: whether you are talking about friends, food, bars, or cars, social media is all about building and maintaining relationships. "Our primary motivator is to have fun, connect with our fans, and talk about the cars that they have invested a lot of time [and money] in," said VW's Sessions. If you want to connect with your car's parent company, or just see what other people have to say, these sites are good places to do that.

Marlene Dietrich

Before we totally leave crazy, uninhibited actresses and their even crazier families behind, let us note the absolute power exuded by two international superstars and their choices of cars, starting with the great Marlene Dietrich.

Absent fine car magazines for reference, the fan of the day frequently judged a car by its owner and vice versa. At the top of her game in this photo, the sultry, gender-bending German goddess Marlene Dietrich lounges with her ungodly 1934 Cadillac 452-D V-16 town cabriolet: a rare beast and a forbiddingly expensive one. But before she had a Cadillac, she had a green 1929 Rolls-Royce Phantom I, given to her on her arrival in Hollywood by Paramount in 1930. If you watch Morocco, her first American film, you'll be sure to see the car. Both the Cadillac and the Rolls-Royce are still in existence today. The Cadillac is housed in the Southward Car Museum in New Zealand, and the Rolls-Royce sold for $524,000 at auction in January 2012 to a private buyer.

Sonja Henie

Sonja Henie was a child athlete in Norway, skating in the first Olympic Winter Games in 1924; winning gold in 1928, 1932, and 1936 for figure skating; and ranking as Norway's third-best tennis player before she came to America to star on the silver screen.

If you think the outrageous and exceedingly avant-garde 1936 Cord 810 shown here was an unusual choice for young Sonja, you'd be interested to know that she also had another Cord back in Norway, an L-29. And that Tyrone Power had a black and white 810 convertible to match hers. And that she had an affair with Joe Louis. (These actresses and their boxers!) And that she sat in Hitler's lap.

pageElements.text:
What makes a woman crazy about an automobile? I can only speak for myself. I grew up in the country surrounded by a dairy farm and five brothers. To me, cars were freedom. When I was fourteen years old, as an exchange student in Ecuador, I learned how to drive in a Toyota Land Cruiser high in the Andes Mountains, where they mark driver error with small white crosses. My fifteen-year-old Ecuadorian brother was my instructor. I never wanted to get out of that car again.

Here's another in our series on women who have done great things with cars.

Elizabeth Junek

Everyone is born too late for something. I was born too late to see the teeny, tiny Madame Elizabeth Junek race the 1928 Targa Florio and almost beat Nuvolari, Divo, and Chiron, the greatest drivers of the day. But I was not born too late to meet her.

There is no doubt that Madame Junek, as she was commonly known, was the greatest woman driver of her era. Here's my column from the April 1994 issue of Automobile Magazine about the day I spent with Madame Junek late in her life.

Another of the Anciens Pilotes de Grand Prix goes to the great Nurburgring in the sky.

One of French Grand Prix driver Rene Dreyfus's oldest friends, and a racing colleague from pre-World War II Grand Prix and Targa Florio days, has joined him in passing from this life. Czechoslovakian hill-climb master in the 1920s. Winner of the 1927 Grand Prix of Germany in the 3,000-cc class. Contemporary of Dreyfus, Albert Divo, Louis Chiron, Tazio Nuvolari, Luigi Fagioli, and Giuseppe Campari, and their better in the grueling 335-mile Targa Florio, though never its winner. A tiny, little...woman.

Oh, she was beautiful, Eliska Junkova, and she was the darling of the Bugatti factory. Ettore Bugatti was stunned when she showed up without her banker husband Cenek to have some work done on the 1922 Grand Prix car she had modified for hill-climbs, having driven the 378 miles from Prague to Molsheim by herself in a rainstorm. "He asked, 'Where is your mechanic?' I said, 'He's at home. I drove myself!'"

I met Elizabeth Junek (as she was more commonly known in the West) when she was eighty-nine, on my way across central Europe six months after the Berlin Wall fell. Stirling Moss told me about her and insisted I stop and see her in Prague. I didn't have Madame Junek's address, but hers was the kind of fame and adoration that called for a mere name on an envelope and it would find its way to her. She was a national hero. The desk attendant at my hotel knew who she was, found her phone number, and arranged the meeting. I had perfume for her and bought her every flower I could find in Prague. The urbane Latvian and retired Porsche design chief Tony Lapine was with me as cultural attache. Our photographer, Maria Krajcirovic, is a Slovak, although she was living in Michigan at the time.
We cooled our heels as she donned dress, stockings, heels, scarf, and makeup. We pored through her racing scrapbooks, each carefully numbered, every photo captioned.

Madame Junek's doctor was just leaving her apartment in the Swedish embassy building. Madame Junek was a little disoriented but welcomed us in, and we were asked to wait in her drawing room until she could tidy up. She came no higher than my chest and looked so frail. I was worried that she wasn't up to the visit from strangers. Ha. She had us cool our heels for nearly an hour as she carefully donned dress, stockings, high heels, scarf, and full makeup. We pored through her racing scrapbooks, each carefully numbered, every photo captioned. The woman who eventually emerged from the bedroom looked much less ancient and closer to the stylish, laughing young woman in the fur-trimmed coat and racing goggles who starred in the yellowed news clippings we had been fingering. We leapt to our feet, and she addressed each of us: she spoke flawless English to me, German to Lapine, and Czech to Maria. "Do you mind if I stand?" she asked. "My legs..."

And so we all stood. For four hours. I asked her a single question about her racing days, and the story came forth without cease, a nonstop narrative in a lovely accented English. Her train travels across Europe with her sister as a young girl. Her first sighting of a car in the south of France before World War I. The banker who fell in love with her when she was a teller, and whom she eventually married. Their success on the hill-climb and Grand Prix circuits of Europe. The time her husband bought her a dress in Paris as a reward for winning a race. ("A supreme sacrifice for a man, to go to the dressmaker." She laughed.)

Madame Junek told her story rooted to that spot in the kitchen. She never moved the entire afternoon. Lapine wavered but never faltered from his respectful standing position next to her. Maria had collapsed into a chair after maybe the first two hours and a few rolls of film. My concern for Madame Junek's health eventually became concern for my own, but it was clear that this story had a beginning, a middle, and an end. An end she was nowhere near. I couldn't break the spell. She talked on.

Her first Targa Florio in 1927, and how she invented the now common practice of walking a course (Yes! She walked the sixty-seven-mile course with her husband) and mapping it out. (Her first practice run was a mere thirty minutes slower than the fastest lap of the 1926 race.) How Emilio Materassi, the Bugatti factory driver, taunted her diminutive physique, and how she flaunted her superior intelligence in his face. How she crashed out of the race on the second lap. The official reason: faulty steering. ("It was sabotage. They put a rock inside a turn just before I came through.")
Madame Junek started fourth in the Targa Florio in a supercharged 2.3-liter Bugatti Type 35B, two minutes behind the great Albert Divo in the same type of Bugatti.

Mostly, she talked of her return to Sicily in 1928, and her greatest drive. Madame Junek started fourth in the Targa Florio in a supercharged 2.3-liter Bugatti Type 35B, two minutes behind the great Albert Divo in the same type of Bugatti. By the end of the second lap, she was leading the race, a mere thirty seconds behind Divo on the road. At one point, she even passed Divo and held an amazing two-minute lead over him and Chiron, Dreyfus, Nuvolari, Campari, and Materassi behind him. Overheating problems dropped her back, but she was able to hold on to fifth place, less than nine minutes from winner Divo. Madame Junek also turned the second lap's fastest time.

Can you imagine what it was like for us to be transported so completely back in time by this tiny old woman who was not only there, but who was the main event? It was her life, those few years in the 1920s, a life that filled four huge scrapbooks with headlines and smiling photos. A life that filled her little apartment with medals and trophies and photos of our greatest racing heroes. That life ended two months after the 1928 Targa Florio, when Cenek Junek was killed in the Grand Prix of Germany. Eliska Junkova never raced again.

The spell was broken, and Madame Junek asked if we would have a drink with her. She fished around in her little refrigerator and came up with a nearly empty bottle of Johnnie Walker Red. She fished around in a cupboard and came up with three little liqueur glasses and one large snifter. She proceeded to pour. "A little one for you," she sang. "A little one for you. A little one for you. A big one for me." She half-filled the snifter, raised it to us, and smiled. "I have bigger," she said. And we drank.

I talked to her a couple of summers ago, and she sounded so far away, and so old. I saw her close friend Czech automotive journalist Milan Jozif at the Detroit show, and I asked him about her. "Eliska is very ill in the hospital. 'Life is beautiful,' she said to me. She fights to live." Jozif called me the next day. "I'm afraid Eliska is no longer with us. She died yesterday, maybe when we were talking about her. It was seven weeks exactly from her ninety-third birthday."
I will always remember her.

pageElements.text: If you could add any feature to a minivan, would you even have dreamed of having an actual vacuum cleaner permanently installed in the back?

As a longtime minivan owner, when I think about such a thing, I picture cherubs flying through the sky blowing on horns, elephants carrying banners, and ticker tape parades. But hey, they're ticker tape parades I could easily vacuum up with the help of the 2014 Honda Odyssey's built-in vacuum cleaner.

The HondaVac

Honda has just announced the new HondaVac in-vehicle vacuuming system at the New York auto show, where the 2014 model is making its debut. The HondaVac will be standard on the 2014 Odyssey's top Touring Elite model, which comes out this summer.

This One Has a Shop-Vac Pedigree

Now you may ask yourself (as I did), will this be some wimpy-ass vacuum that doesn't pick up anything? No, apparently not, because it was developed in conjunction with Shop-Vac, makers of industrial-strength vacuums that could just about pull your teeth out of your mouth. That's encouraging for those of us who have lived with unreachable piles of sunflower seed hulls, cookie crumbs, and worst of all, smushed French fries in our vans for years. I believe my current van has crumbs old enough to register for middle school.

Where Is This Wondrous Thing?

The HondaVac comes with a replaceable filter and canister bag, and it is permanently installed in a space on the driver's side of the rear cargo area. Lift the liftgate, select the nozzle accessories that you'll find there, and vacuum as obsessively as you wish. The HondaVac doesn't need to be plugged into an outlet, it never needs to be recharged, and it can operate continuously as long as the Odyssey's engine is running. In fact, you can keep vacuuming for up to eight minutes after shutting off the car, according to Honda.

And Why Am I So Excited It Exists?

I'm guessing everyone who is reading this would agree, it's nice not to have a dirty, crumb-filled car. What stops us from keeping it cleaned out? Mostly the fact that it's such a hassle to go to the plaza outside the car wash and wrestle with the giant hose, which either has no suction, is caked with other people's grime, or eats quarters at an alarming rate. Household vacuum cleaners, when dragged out to the garage or the street, aren't configured well for use in the nooks and crannies of your vehicle. The HondaVac is a no-brainer, seems to me. Can't wait to try it out and see if it works as well as it looks.

pageElements.text: Pat Moss was like the Tasmanian devil. She had a very graphic face, so she could look alternately really striking or formidable, depending on how she was dressed and what she was doing at the time.

Pat was the sister of Stirling Moss, the world's greatest living racing driver. She married Erik Carlsson, one of the most famous rally drivers of the day. She met him while she was rallying, but she didn't begin as a racing driver. In her teens, she was an Olympic-level equestrian. By then, her older brother, Stirling, was winning races all over Europe.

The early photos showed her in equestrian events. Then came a photograph set up by one of the London papers with her driving her brother's rally car, and Stirling riding her horse. It was just a total setup, but she turned out to be brilliant behind the wheel. She quickly turned to rallying, where she became without a doubt the most famous female rally driver until Michele Mouton took over from her in the late 1970s.

Racing History

Pat was a five-time European Ladies' Rally Championship winner. She and co-driver Anne Wisdom contested rallies all over Europe from the mid-1950s to the late '60s. Pat started in a Triumph TR2 that she bought herself and first distinguished herself with a 1958 win in the British RAC Rally in 1958, in a Morris Minor. She drove an Austin Healey 100-Six to fourth place in the Liege-Rome-Liege Rally, which she won outright in 1960. She was also winner of the 1962 Rallye Deutschland. After her marriage to Erik, she switched to the Saab factory team. They competed together in eleven international rallies in the mid-'60s.

Once, while she was dating Erik, she was ahead of him on the road in a rally, racing a Healey, and crashed her car and ended up upside down. The first thing Pat checked was if the side glass windows were broken, because they were very expensive. She was relieved to discover they weren't. So while she was upside down in the car, she was carefully removing the set screws that held the window in place. She was just about to remove the final screw when Eric came around the corner, saw her upside down, jumped out of his car in a panic, and ran to the car and kicked the window in. Much to his surprise, Pat came flying out of the car. What he had on his hands was a screaming, spitting hellcat, yelling, "You bloody idiot! I'm perfectly fine, you've ruined my window."

After they got married, they lived in Monte Carlo for a long time as many drivers did to avoid taxes. When I met them, they lived on the Moss family farm in Tring, northwest of London. Erik mucked out the horse stables and would always admonish Pat to stop swearing and stop smoking because it would set off these horrible coughing fits. She tended a massive flower garden and did the cooking, both activities with an eternal cigarette hanging from her lips. Erik would say, "That's right, pretty mom, light another cigarette." She would respond, "Sod you, Erik."

I spent a lot of time with Pat in the 1980s and early 1990s. By the time I met her, she had already retired from rallying and dedicated her life to driving her daughter and her daughter's horses to horse jumping events all over Europe.

At Home with the Moss-Carlsons

The first time Erik took me home to meet the family, I stayed at Erik and Pat's house. I slept in the den on a fold-out bed with orders to not bloody wake anybody up early in the morning.

Next to me was the bookshelf with all of the family scrapbooks. There was not a single photo in the scrapbooks that wasn't taken by a newspaper or professional photographer. Pat's, Erik's, and Stirling's lives were totally in the public domain. Everything they did was commented on and examined in the newspaper. They were the stars of the day.

Pirelli Classic Marathon with Stirling, Not Pat

I had a chance to drive with Pat in 1989, when Pirelli Tires asked me if I wanted to co-drive with her in a Pirelli Classic Marathon across Europe, from London to Cortina d'Ampezzo. I called her, and she said, "That bloody car didn't kill me back then, and I'm not going to give it another chance." I ended up doing the event with her brother, Stirling, which was the beginning of our nearly thirty-year friendship.

In retirement, Pat wrote two books: The Story So Far, which was a memoir, and The Art and Technique of Driving, which she co-wrote with Erik. Shortly before she died in 2008, she managed to get a speeding ticket while towing a horse trailer.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Researching and picking out a new car is an exhilarating process, but the buying process can be daunting. Cars are expensive, and there’s a general feeling that the odds of getting a good deal are stacked against the buyer. Huddy Skiba, sales manager at Hyman Bros. Mazda in Newport News, Virginia, says that when customers walk into a car dealership, they are "terrified that they’re going to be ripped off. We’re just trying to help."

We want to help, too, so we’ve put together a few pieces of advice to help unravel the mysteries of shopping for your new car. Doing your homework before you ever walk into a dealership can go a long way toward making you feel more confident, so this week we’ll be talking about what to think about before you finance a car. We’ve been breaking down a different part of the process for you each day.

Where Do You Draw the Line?

Today’s topic: how much car is too much car? We’ve got a few tips to help you avoid auctioning off a kidney to afford your monthly payments.

Buying a car can be a budget killer and represents a years-long commitment to set aside several hundred dollars per month for your wheels at the very least. Skiba says customers aren’t always realistic about the cars they can afford. "They want a $25,000 car for $250 a month, and the math just doesn’t work."

There’s a lot of competing wisdom about how much you should spend on a car. If you take Consumer Reports’ advice, you should spend no more than 36 percent of your gross income on debt. This includes a mortgage (or your monthly rent, if you don’t own your home), credit card bills, and any other monthly payments. To determine what you can afford to pay for a car, add up all your monthly expenses and subtract that number from the 36 percent you can spend on debt. What’s left over is what you have to spare for a car payment.

How Much Do You Plan to Spend?

For example: the median household income in the United States is just under $53,000. Using our 36 percent benchmark, that household can spend about $19,000 per year on debt payments, or about $1,600 per month. Just for the sake of round numbers, if you have a $600 housing payment and another $400 in other debt, you’re left with $600 for new debt, like a car payment.

Bankrate.com, a personal finance site, has a different rule of thumb. They suggest that you spend no more than twenty percent of your monthly income on your car, which includes payments for insurance, car maintenance, and other operating costs. This means that a household earning $53,000 (about $4,400 per month pretax) should spend no more than $880 per month on car-related expenses.

What About the Down Payment?

Deciding on the size of your down payment is also important. Skiba says that these days, since many dealers no longer require a down payment as part of a new-car purchase, "nobody’s putting any money down. You don’t have to." Putting little or no money down might make it easier to afford a car, since you won’t have to plop down a large lump sum before you get the keys, but it can also mean that you owe more than the car is worth almost immediately, since the value of a new car depreciates quickly once it leaves the dealer lot. It might be hard to come up with a sizable down payment, but it will lower your monthly payments and allow you to borrow less money to finance your purchase.

Also consider operating costs (gas and maintenance) and how much it will cost to insure a vehicle. You’re going to spend more to insure a sports car than a minivan and more to fill up a large SUV than a compact car. Once you have an idea of how much you can afford to pay each month and settle on an amount for the down payment, you can use an online calculator to determine what the total value of your new car should be. Make sure the whole picture fits into your budget.
Check back tomorrow for our final installment on financing, when we’ll talk about how to decide on the length of your loan.

pageElements.text: 2014 Cadillac CTS Sedan

Vital Stats

Base price: Expected to be about $48,000
EPA fuel economy: 17 mpg city/25 mpg highway with top 3.6-liter twin-turbo V-6 and eight-speed automatic transmission
Safety features: Forward collision alert, automatic collision preparation, lane departure warning, side blind-zone alert, rear cross-traffic alert, rear-vision camera, Cadillac's Safety Alert Seat (it vibrates to tell you you're about to crash), automatic seatbelt tightening, adaptive cruise control
Tech features: Magnetic ride control, active grille shutters for better aerodynamics (not on all models), ZF transmission with paddle shifters, Brembo brakes, optional 12.3-inch high-resolution LCD instrument cluster with a choice of four layouts, automatic park assist, twenty-way (count 'em) adjustable front seats
Chief competitors: Audi A6, BMW 5 Series, Infiniti M, Mercedes-Benz E350

Key Points

—This is the third-generation model of the CTS, based on the same rear-wheel-drive platform as the ATS
—Cadillac is going full bore against Mercedes and BMW with this sedan, and the luxury and tech features show it
—They cut way back on the bling, going for a more understated elegance in this new model
—Cadillac's Art & Science design philosophy goes longer and lower: new CTS is five inches longer, while the roofline is an inch lower
—Aluminum is a byword on this new Cadillac: in the doors, in the suspension, helping cut weight
—There will be eight choices of interior "environments" featuring wood, carbon fiber, and aluminum, plus optional full leather with handcrafted elements in it
—The new Cadillac comes with either a 2.0-liter turbo four-cylinder or a regular or twin-turbo 3.6-liter V-6. With the top twin-turbo V-6 engine, horsepower reaches 420
—Gadget alert! Motorized cupholder lid, adaptive remote start that also turns on your heat or A/C, an electronically locking glovebox, and a set of twenty-way adjustable heated and ventilated front seats

pageElements.text: I wanted Gerry McGovern to do a design walkaround of the new Range Rover Sport because he is a very accomplished designer. I love listening to designers who know exactly what they're doing and can describe it in exacting detail in their own language.

On one hand, it's hilarious to listen to him with his very British demeanor and choice of words. On the other, here is someone who is extremely competent, with a design vision that is precisely articulated both by him and by the car itself.

2014 Range Rover Sport Autobiography

Safety features: Adaptive dynamics, lane departure warning, traffic sign recognition, automatic high-beam assist
Tech features: Fuel-saving intelligent stop/start; air suspension that automatically varies between two heights; Terrain Response 2, which chooses the correct terrain program for you, including (on this car) Dynamic mode; color head-up display; comprehensive connectivity package with stolen vehicle tracking; installed Wi-Fi hotspot is an option
Looks: Sportier Sports Command driving position, with smaller steering wheel, vertical gear shifter, higher center console; Third-row “occasional” seating is available; wheels available in nineteen-inch through twenty-two-inch sizes
Chief competitors: BMW X5, Mercedes-Benz ML-Class, Porsche Cayenne

Key Points:

—Land Rover introduced this new model at the New York Auto Show because New York City is the city, and the U.S. the country, where the most Range Rover Sport models are sold
—However, Daniel Craig emphasized the strong Bond between Land Rover and the U.K. by driving the Range Rover Sport through Manhattan’s streets as part of the unveiling
—There are four engine choices: two supercharged gasoline engines and two diesels; the Autobiography gets the 508-hp V-8 gas engine; all are paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission
—A diesel hybrid is coming; you can order it in late 2013 for a 2014 delivery
—Weight is down 800 pounds, thanks to lightweight aluminum suspension
—Land Rover wants you to know that 75 percent of the parts on the Sport are unique to it, so it shares the big Range Rover’s name but has its own look and feel
—The all-new Range Rover Sport comes in SE, HSE, and Supercharged models in addition to the top-of-the-line Autobiography you see here
—Red brake calipers and badging help differentiate the Autobiography, as does a set of perforated leather seats available in more than eleven color choices —Even sportier Dynamic versions of the HSE and Autobiography are coming later, Land Rover says
—Perhaps the best conversation starter on the Range Rover Sport is its Wade Sensing feature: It gives you depth information when driving in water up to 33 inches deep
—But you, and most Range Rover Sport owners, will be mainly driving it around town, won’t you?

pageElements.text: Ralph Gilles, who has been head of design at Chrysler since 2008, is one of the coolest of the cool designers in the business. He was a relative unknown in the design world until he jumped to center stage as the design spokesman for the 2005 Chrysler 300. His claim to fame was creating the production car design from the radical Dodge Super8 Hemi concept penned by Freeman Thomas, now head of Ford’s advanced design department. Few had heard of Ralph Gilles until then.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/egArJLXaDBQ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

From the 300, Ralph designed the 2006 Charger sedan. It wasn’t as beautiful as the original Charger, but it had a lot of emotion, which was exactly what Chrysler needed in the dark days. After that, he came into his own and he has managed to swim to the top of Chrysler’s design food chain while maintaining his sparkling, off-the-wall personality.

He was such a golden boy that he was put in charge of the entire Dodge division (along with his chief designer duties) for a while, a very rare move that was pioneered by Cadillac when it installed designer Bryan Nesbitt as its chief for a short while. Neither of them lasted long in the Big Chair (the move from artist to businessman has just been a bridge too far in the auto world), although in 2011, Chrysler put Ralph in charge as president and CEO of its performance division, SRT. It totally suits his personality and his whole vibe, which includes walking around in black leather and maintaining a lively and controversial presence in the Twitterverse.
Follow him! @RalphGilles

2013 Chrysler 300SRT8

Vital Stats

Base price: $48,990 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 14 mpg city/23 mpg highway (with 6.4-liter Hemi V-8 engine and five-speed automatic transmission)
Standard safety features: Electronic stability control, traction control, electronic brake-force distribution, brake assist; optional SafetyTec group includes blind-spot, rear cross-path, and forward collision monitoring
Technology features: Comes standard with six-speaker Alpine premium audio, but there’s an optional nineteen-speaker Harman Kardon audio system; UConnect 8.4-inch touchscreen LED display with Garmin navigation
Chief competitors: BMW M5, Cadillac CTS-V, Lexus IS-F

Key Points

- The racy SRT version of the Chrysler 300 comes with a one-day SRT Track Experience, held at racetracks around the country to help drivers improve their skills on street or track
- Standard performance pages feature shows you 0-to-60 mph, eighth- and quarter-mile times, g-force, oil pressure, and more on a center color screen
- Luxury meets performance in a leather-wrapped steering wheel, heated and cooled cupholders, and LED ambient lighting, for example
- Class or brass: Black Nappa leather seats and Poltrona Foligno leather-wrapped instrument panel with French-seamed stitching are available, or you can go in a different direction and get red-and-black Nappa leather seats with perforated suede inserts and silver accent stitching

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. pageElements.text: We’ve known that Chevrolet was preparing an electric version of its tiny Spark for some time now, but details were hazy at best. Well, EV enthusiasts, the wait is finally over. General Motors unveiled range and efficiency numbers for its battery-powered electric vehicle today, and the news is good: with a combined city/highway rating of 119 MPGe, the Spark EV will be the most efficient electric vehicle for sale in the U.S. when it hits dealerships.

The Spark EV’s eighty-two miles of combined city/highway range is about what’s expected for an electric car this size, but the car’s newly released fuel economy ratings are something to write home about. Apparently not content that the Chevrolet Cruze Diesel, at 46 mpg on the highway, is the highest-rated non-hybrid passenger car for sale in the United States, Chevrolet has topped efficiency charts again with the Spark EV.

The tiny Spark EV wears essentially the same skin as its gas-sipping twin (although it sports wavy “energy” lines on the grille, à la the Chevrolet Volt, and a green EV badge on the rear), but under the hood, an internal-combustion engine is replaced by an electric motor that produces upward of 100 kilowatts of power—130 horsepower, in case you slept through physics class. The motor is powered by a 20-kWh, 560-pound battery pack that sits in front of the rear wheels, leaving cargo space untouched.
The Spark EV will go on sale in California and Oregon this summer.

pageElements.text: It’s the age-old story of car technology: what starts as an expensive option only available in luxury cars becomes standard equipment after a few years on the market. It happened with CD players, navigation systems, and power windows, and now it’s happening with four-door passive entry. Sexy, right?

The Chevrolet Malibu LTZ—a car for the everyperson, starting at $28,175 including destination—has four-door passive entry available as an option in the $1,000 LTZ Premium package. The technology allows drivers to unlock all four doors and the trunk without fussing with the key fob.

Just Get within Three Feet and Presto!

When the Malibu’s closed-loop wireless communication system verifies that the correct key fob is within three feet of the car, the driver door can be unlocked by pressing the button on the door handle once. A second press will unlock the rest of the doors and the trunk. Malibu engineers originally toyed with the idea of having the car unlock automatically when it sensed that the key was nearby but decided against that system to avoid accidentally unlocking the car every time you pass it.

Chevrolet hopes the technology will make life just a touch easier for Malibu owners. If you’ve ever fumbled with the keys while wrangling the kids or hauling an armful of shopping bags, you know that this could just be one of the seemingly minor technology upgrades that you end up deciding you can’t live without.

contributors.bio:

I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: We’ve been singing the praises of clean diesel cars for months. They have great fuel economy and durable engines, but they’re not loud or smelly the way old diesel burners were. Sounds great, but does the reality live up to the hype? I drove Mercedes-Benz’s new GLK250 BlueTec to find out.

The GLK is Mercedes-Benz’s entry-level small SUV. The base model GLK350 starts at $37,995, including destination, and earns 25 mpg on the highway—not bad for a car its size, but not stellar, either. It’s a touch small to be a family car—75 percent of GLK buyers are childless—but it’s plenty big enough to haul a weekend getaway’s worth of luggage to a cabin in the woods or to take four adults to dinner in the city.

BlueTec Mercedes Impresses in Highway Mileage

Better yet, the GLK’s new variant, the aforementioned GLK250 BlueTec, adds a diesel engine to the mix, giving the GLK both some added efficiency and extra torque. The 2.1-liter diesel engine makes 200 horsepower and 369 pound-feet of torque. It also earns a rather impressive 33 mpg on the highway, a number I easily matched on my drive despite putting the car in sport mode and employing my usual spirited driving style.

True to its promise, the diesel engine hummed along without emitting any offensive noises or smells. In fact, if it hadn’t been for the added torque aiding my accelerations, I might never have guessed it was an oil burner.

Black Ash and Steel Grey

The interior of my test car was comfortable and stylish, with dark seating and wood trim in a pleasing black ash. My test car’s equally pleasing Steel Grey exterior paint is a $720 option—less than the $750 buyers would have to pay for heated front seats or the $2,790 it takes to get the COMAND infotainment system with Mercedes-Benz’s mbrace suite.

The GLK250 will be Mercedes-Benz’s fifth diesel in their U.S. model lineup, and despite the technology’s lukewarm reception on this side of the pond, the carmaker is confident that the new addition to the Bluetec family will perform well. Bart Herring, Mercedes Benz’s general manager of product management, expects that diesel engines will make up ten to fifteen percent of GLK sales. Only about two percent of all U.S. vehicle sales are diesels.

Going Diesel Getting More Affordable

Part of the reason Mercedes-Benz expects the car to do so well is that they have done away with the significant premium that many diesels are burdened with. Starting at $39,495, the GLK250 BlueTec with 4Matic all-wheel drive is more expensive than the base model GLK, but less expensive than a GLK350 with 4Matic, which starts at $39,995. Sandwiched in the middle of the lineup, the GLK250 could just hit a sweet spot for diesel-curious shoppers.

They can't wait to learn how to parallel park, but in this episode, I make them work on the preliminary skill of backing up.

pageElements.text: I’ve been racking up to 100,000 miles a year since my late teenage years, when I was a taxicab owner/operator. There is nothing I love to do more than to teach kids the driving secrets I’ve learned over the miles. Damn. I wish had me around when I was their age. I would have told me how stupid it was to drive everywhere at 100 miles an hour. I would have learned emergency maneuvers long before I actually had to make one.
Of course, there is nothing like, oh, a few million or so miles behind the wheel, with a chunk of that at high speed on a racetrack, to give you a tad of well-earned confidence behind the wheel.
At least I learned how to drive a stick before I saw my first automatic.

So here I am, ready to serve. This isn’t a comprehensive driver’s ed class. I’m aiming with the No. 1 Ladies' Driving Academy to share the things I’ve learned wayyy outside the classroom. I want kids to know as many different ways as possible of getting out of trouble on the road. Like, say, avoiding it altogether.
I will keep making these videos as long as there are kids (and don’t take that Ladies thing seriously; boys Я allowed) with new questions about how to do whatever it is they are afraid of doing.
Ask and you will receive.

Love,
Jean

As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: There’s a lot more that goes into designing a car besides deciding what the body panels should look like. From drag coefficients to the shape of the seats, everything is considered.

Simone Gronewald is a woman with one of those jobs you might not know existed if you weren’t thinking about it, but that doesn’t mean it’s not interesting. Gronewald works in graphical user interface design for Audi Design in Ingolstadt, Germany.  She’s behind the graphics and instrument clusters in Audi’s concept cars, so she spends her days dreaming up the car of the future.

Since landing at Audi, she has worked on the Crosslane Coupé Concept, the Urban Concept, and the 2011 A2 Concept. I caught up with Gronewald on the very day that her most recent project, the Audi TT Ultra Quattro Concept, was announced as one of the show cars for Wörthersee, the annual Volkswagen and Audi car show in Reifnitz, Austria.

Can you explain what "design for graphical user interface" means?

[At] Audi, I’m doing the MMI system: the navigation telephone screen, radio screen, and also the instrument clusters. I’m strongly connected with the [interface] interaction. I work together with our human machine interface department. They are responsible for making all the concepts.

Were you always interested in designing for cars?

I was always interested in designing for cars. I once asked my mother when I started to be interested in design at all. There is a nice story that I was sitting [in] our car when I was eight years old and I told my mother, “I will be a car designer.”
Since I was very, very little, my father and my grandfather always drove Mercedes-Benzes. I was allowed to sit in the car and pretend to drive the car.

Tell me what led to your job at Mercedes-Benz.

My thesis actually didn’t have anything in common with the automobile industry. I decided to make a digital sketchbook. This was a very conceptual work. For me, a digital sketchbook should have all the advantages of the analogical world and the digital world. You should have a physical product that looks like a sketchbook, but you also have everything digital. You can copy and paste; you can see a timeline of the sketch. I was thinking about technology. I was thinking about e-paper. I didn’t have a prototype, but I decided to make a video, and that video was enough to get me an interview [with Mercedes-Benz].

How is designing for concepts different from designing for production cars?

First of all, for concept cars, you have a lot less time: you have just a few months. You are very happy if you have a year. For production, you have five years.

In these few months, you have to design your concept and [the engineers] have to build the design. In the Crosslane [right], we tried out transparent OLED displays that you cannot use in cars now because they’re not automotive yet. We used it for the climate control, and as they are transparent displays, we could position them one behind the other and switch between them. At the end, everybody is proud when they can see the car at the fair.

What is your goal when you get to work every day?

My biggest goal is [to have] the graphics integrated into the car. When I start the project, I try to see the model from the very beginning, see what the interior designer wants, and see what the exterior designer wants. I want to make sure that the graphics are very well integrated.

image.altText: Audi TT Ultra Quattro Concept INT 622

pageElements.text:
What are you working on right now?

At the moment I’m working on concepts and production. For production, I really can’t say because it’s all secret, and for concepts, it was the TT Ultra Quattro Concept—we will show the whole car at Wörthersee. [The instrument panel is shown at right; see the photo gallery for the car.]

Do you think being a woman has given you an advantage in your line of work?

I hope not. And I don’t think so. I think that if you apply for a job, you have to convince with your design. Sometimes it’s actually hard when you go into technical detail: you have to convince people that you can understand technology even though you’re a woman.

What’s your dream project?

I have one that’s not really related to the automotive industry: I’d love to publish a photo story.

pageElements.text: I first met Iron Maiden's drummer, Nicko McBrain, in 2003, when I wrote about him for the December 2003 issue of Automobile Magazine. We did a special section on Rockers Who Love to Roll, and I called Jaguar, since they're always tied up with celebrities. They told me about this crazy guy who loved Jags and bought all his own cars. They also told me that he had recently been arrested after he bumped a security guard with a Jaguar XJR while running late to an outdoor concert.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/gwmql32K8aw" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Iron Maiden was going to be playing at Madison Square Garden, so I concocted the idea that I would chauffeur McBrain around before the concert for his own safety (or the safety of the public), also in an XJR. I had no idea what kind of guy I was about to meet. Here's this outrageous headbanging group that has a crazy monster named Eddie as its mascot. I saw myself as more of a refined Pink Floyd-style headbanger.
I went to his hotel and arranged to meet him for breakfast. He set the time at 1:00 p.m. We were off to a roaring start.

When he appeared, he definitely looked like a rocker, or like Mickey Rourke in The Wrestler, with long, streaming platinum blond hair. He was wearing a Hawaiian shirt, and I realized it was an Iron Maiden Hawaiian shirt with Eddie embedded into it, and he had a tough-guy Northern British working-class accent. But he was also extremely well groomed, wearing elegant linen slacks, and he was a real salt-of-the-earth guy, game for anything. We hit it off immediately.

We took the XJR to the car wash, where I got a photo of him scrubbing the car. We drove around Harlem and in midtown Manhattan, where our crazy British photographer asked us to drive around the corner again and again in rush-hour traffic. When we got back to his hotel, there was a long line of people waiting for autographs. I ended up driving him all the way into Madison Square Garden, up the circular ramp to the stage, way above the main floor.

Since then, I had not seen Nicko McBrain until the Los Angeles Auto Show. I had no idea he was going to be there. I went to a Jaguar party, and I noticed someone I thought was a girl in a white suit from the back. Then he turned around, and before I even recognized him, he shouted, "Jeannie [pronounced more like "Jaynay"]! I was hoping you'd be here!"
Some people, no matter how famous or not famous they are, once you meet them, you're friends forever.

I really like the fact that he has bought all his own cars, and mostly secondhand. He's like a kid in a candy store, with a lifelong love of Jags that's real. He's humble and genuinely tickled that anyone at Jaguar would have any interest in his opinion at all. It was great to have the chance to talk to him again for this interview, in which he talks about his new customized Jaguar XKR-S, which, among other modifications, has Iron Maiden mascot Eddie's face in place of the Jag growler.

metaTitle: Our Favorite Road-Trip Memories - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The Jean Knows Cars staff shares our Favorite Road-Trip Memories, culled from childhood and adulthood. Read them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
My Summer of Love

I first ventured out of Michigan by myself in the summer of 1972 when the Rainbow People's Party called for a gathering of the tribe in Colorado. I found out about it when I longed to see my boyfriend, Ben, who'd hitchhiked from Ann Arbor with his friend PK to find J. Stevens, a mysterious Latvian friend of ours who went by the name on the shirt he'd bought secondhand at St. Vincent de Paul. J. Stevens had disappeared into the mountains somewhere above Aspen and was building an illegal shack on federal land. Ben and PK had the name of a guy who lived there who might know where J. Stevens was. So off they went, by way of Idaho and San Francisco, bar to bar to bar, in search of the elusive Latvian.

After one late-night, reversed charge phone call from the boys, I decided on a whim to go looking for all of them. I was eighteen years old. It took one ride to get from Ann Arbor to Colorado, where every campground was bulging at the seams with half naked, totally stoned, and barefoot flower children and their psychedelic school buses. Being from a tiny farm town of 5,000 people at the base of Michigan's thumb, I was overwhelmed by this rich tapestry of life. Actually, I was overwhelmed that I'd actually hitchhiked halfway across the country without being murdered and was in Aspen. Now what?

Going on the same single clue that the boys had, I found J. Stevens working away on a pile of ancient scrap lumber salvaged from an abandoned cabin in a small clearing, a mile straight up Little Annie on the backside of town. I set up my tent and sleeping bag and was immediately immersed in the routine of sorting scrap wood, hiking a half-mile across the mountain to fill and carry back water jugs from the stream, and hiking down the mountain to do laundry. I would hitchhike from the bottom of the hill to town, do the clothes, spend the night in a local campground with the Rainbow People, then hitch to the base of the mountain for the return hike up. On one such foray into town, I got out of a truck on the side of the highway at the exact moment Ben and PK were emerging from a truck that was dropping them off on the other side of the road!

I'd been there a month already, so I hung out with them for another week and then decided to head for home. It took two rides. The first was from Aspen to Boulder in a Jeep with two guys in front, a German Shepherd in the back, and a box of eight-track tapes. I squeezed in with the dog. They dropped me at the top of an entrance ramp to Interstate 80 looking down over a rail yard.

I was there for a couple of hours, in such a state of despair that I was seriously considering jumping a train. At one point, a police car raced past me to pick up a guy hitching farther down the ramp. Before I had to make a decision to run, two hippies in an old red-and-white station wagon backed all the way up the ramp and saved me. A guy and his sick girlfriend were on their way to Chicago. She was laid out in the back, so I rode up front with him and helped with the driving.

We drove through the night, hitting the outskirts of Chi-town at 2:00 a.m. I was nervously awaiting the moment when they would kick me to the curb with not a dime in my pocket, 200 miles from home. But we kept driving east on I-94. "We decided back in Nebraska that we couldn't let you out in the middle of the night," my Good Samaritan said.

They took me to my door, where we together discovered that my roommates, confused by my one-month absence, had moved everything from my room, put it in the basement, and rented my room out even though I had paid the rent through the month.

We all slept for a few hours on the floor, they went back to Chicago, and I moved across the street.

Have a great summer!
Love, Jean

Laura Sky Brown's First-Time-on-the-Road Nostalgia

I was born just a tiny bit late to the Sixties party, meaning that at the age when any self-respecting hippie would have been hitchhiking to Woodstock or at least to San Francisco, I was a young preteen still linked firmly to family and home. The protest marches, Summer of Love, and Chicago Seven trials were things I watched on TV after middle school homework was done. I did my best to make up for lost time by going across country in the summer of 1976, when I was eighteen. I headed out from Michigan to Washington State. The plan was to meet up with a friend in the Earth-shoe enclave of Washougal, Washington, then drive together back to Massachusetts.

In the way that teenagers used to do—maybe they still do, but I’m glad mine haven’t (yet)—I dug up some stranger from the University of Michigan North Campus Co-ops and headed out West in his car with him. All I remember about him, besides his dented Datsun hatchback, was that he had scraggly, curly black hair and he smiled a lot while settling in each night to sleep under the stars in a sleeping bag several feet away from mine. We stopped in small towns like Blue Earth, Minnesota, and we waved at cows whenever we passed them—a joke then, but now a habit that’s almost a superstition, which I have not broken to this day and have now passed along to my children.

He dropped me off in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, at the foot of the Grand Tetons, where I felt so grown up reserving my first solo hotel room. From there, I took a Greyhound bus through Idaho and into Washington.

The trip back was a whole other story, but I do want to mention that it was the Bicentennial that year, and right after I arrived, my friend and I went to see the much ballyhooed Largest Fireworks in the U.S.A., which for some reason were in Vancouver, Washington. I wore a bizarre variant of red Converse All-Stars sneakers that extended all the way up to my knees, in honor of the occasion. After it was over, the traffic jam on the way home kept us out on the road, unmoving, until well into July 5. My friend had a brand-new car of which she was so proud (and later was unable to unload at any price): a Chevrolet Vega wagon. We were shortly to head off on a manic trip that took us to San Francisco, where somebody told us about this new thing called disco; across the South, where I had my nineteenth birthday dinner at a Chinese restaurant in Tennessee; and all the way to her parents’ home in western Massachusetts, where her mother promptly got into a screaming fight with my friend and tossed me out. Back to the Greyhound bus for home.

Does anything equal that first trip that you plan (or fail to plan) all by yourself without parental input? Sure, most trips you’ll take later in life will turn out a lot better, but your first try stepping out into the world alone is intoxicating. If I close my eyes, I can still remember the scent of that summer. I may prefer the Hampton Inn to the sleeping bag on the ground these days, but it’s satisfying to remember that there was once a time…

Molly Jean's Family Values Camping

I am a second-generation camper, and I went on my first camping trip when I was six months old. We had a truck camper, and my dad built a crib into one end of the area above the cab of the truck. We crisscrossed Michigan in that old, 1950s-era aqua Ford pickup. Obviously, I don’t really remember it, but the stories have been told so many times that I feel like I remember being put to bed in my footy pajamas high up in the air.

At some point we moved from the truck camper to station wagons, and by the mid-'60s, we bought a Chevrolet Suburban and named her Green Glory. It was the very best vacation vehicle ever made. So much room that you could bring every last teddy bear you owned.

Now that I have my own family, we have kept the tradition alive and spend at least one week a summer enjoying the rustic beauty of our state. We are the campers who bring everything. When we pull out of the driveway and I look back at our house, I always think, if anything happens to my house I have all of my favorite things with me. That includes my parents, who are closing in on eighty but are still right out there with us on almost every single vacation we take.

Christina Lawson's Relative Adventures

I’ve only taken three summer vacations: two to Florida when I was seven and nine and one trip to Arizona right before I started seventh grade. I’d have to say that despite the illnesses afflicting my mother and me for the week-long vacation, my family’s Arizona trip was my favorite.

But what made the trip truly enjoyable wasn’t the scheduled trip to the Grand Canyon or the ruins of a Spanish mission we saw on our first day or the drive my mom and I took to Gilbert, Arizona, to visit an old friend. It was the little things that made my mom and I laugh, like when she and my aunt, the daughters of a germ-fearing mother, explained to my uncle why hot tubs were always a bad idea, or when my mom and I pretended that we weren’t with my uncle while he caused a commotion while attempting to secure my then-infant cousin’s carrier into a plane seat. His movements as he yanked at the seatbelts caused the plane to sway in place; the loud crying of his son, who didn’t like to travel (and, thirteen years later, still doesn’t), only made things worse. And then there was the situation with my uncle’s three insulated canteens, each filled to the brim with water, and his ever-present tripod and video camera. My mom and I helped him carry them until my aunt realized that her husband had turned her older sister and niece into uncomplaining human pack animals and promptly took the gear from us. My mom and I giggled as we listened to her employing very colorful words as she told my uncle that he should have left the canteens and the tripod at home. Now, many years after that trip, the words "tripod" and "hot tub" still send my mom and me into fits of snorts and giggles.

Now that I’m done with school, one of my dream trips is to actually go to Mackinac Island instead of spending years talking about it; the other is to go to England. I almost had the chance to fly to England this July as a chaperone on a six-week-long trip, but I turned it down. The best I’ll be able to do is to plan to go to Mackinac before another ten or fifteen years passes by. But without my uncle along, it won’t be nearly as hilarious as it could be.

Annie White's Rooster Epiphany

I’ve done my fair share of distance driving, but not much in the way of true road trips. During my stint on the East Coast, my travels carved a triangle with Boston, Ann Arbor, and Washington, D.C. at its corners, but those frequent drives were undertaken alone and at breakneck speed, with only the destination in mind and no thought for the journey. My favorite real road trip was the one that took me from Portland, Oregon, to the redwoods in California, to Yosemite National Park, to San Francisco, back to the redwoods, and finally back to Portland. You can read about it here, but here’s a DVD extras tidbit: it was on this trip that I learned how truly horrible it is to wake up to a rooster crowing. Don’t believe the back-to-nature crowd. Humans made a huge leap forward when we invented alarm clocks with off buttons.

The road trip of my dreams would take months to do right and would go from coast to coast and north to south, hitting every possible major city and national park. This summer I’m setting my sights a little lower and hoping to fit in a camping trip to Lake Michigan (the poor man’s Atlantic Ocean) in between my frequent jaunts to Big Long Lake in Indiana (a very poor man’s Lake Michigan).

Scott Allen's Bad Influence

My fondest memory of road trips as a kid was driving to Florida every year with my parents and my brother. It was two long days of driving to get there. We always listened to Graceland by Paul Simon, and I hated it because I didn't understand it. It's funny that it's now one of my favorite records of all time.

When I was about thirteen, we brought my friend Andrew to Florida with us in our new Honda Odyssey van. This was before there were rear-seat TVs. We plugged a little boxy twelve-inch TV/VHS player into the cigarette lighter and I brought Taxi Driver without my parents knowing. We watched it in silent mode because we were too afraid they would hear what we were watching. We didn't understand until later what was going on in the movie.

My favorite part of the trip always came when we were about four hours from the Florida line. The freeway on either side felt like you were engulfed in trees. Usually it would be super foggy at night.

On that year’s trip, Andrew and I would sneak out in the golf cart that my grandfather owned and go driving around the golf course super fast and kind of out of control. We got it stuck in a sand pit, and we were freaking out because we thought we were going to get in so much trouble, so we ran back to the house and were honest and said what we did. My grandpa was pretty pissed, and I thought my dad was, too, but just recently, he told me he thought it was funny. Andrew is in Thailand now, teaching kindergarten kids.

pageElements.text:
2013 Mercedes-Benz SL63 AMG Roadster

Vital Stats

Base price: $146,705 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $177,280 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 16 mpg city/25 mpg highway (with 5.5-liter biturbo V8 engine that makes 557 horsepower and 664 pound-feet of torque, plus seven-speed AMG automatic transmission with shift paddles)
Safety features: Electronic stability control, active blind spot and active lane keeping assist, Pre-Safe braking, carbon-ceramic brakes (a $12,625 option!), brake assist and adaptive brake technology, Attention Assist, rear-view camera, active parking assist with Parktronic,adaptive high-beam assist, LED daytime running lights
Tech features: Active ventilated multicontour seats, AMG performance steering wheel with Dinamica side grips, Comand system with navigation, Harman/Kardon Logic7 surround-sound audio system, mbrace2 telematics system with MB apps
Chief competitors: Aston Martin V8 Vantage, Jaguar XKR-S

Key Points

• Luxury abounds: sun-reflecting leather upholstery, heated Magic Vision Control, a retractable panoramic roof, and the famous Airscarf neck comfort system
• So does power: the AMG performance package ($9,000) includes a power increase from the “base” 530 hp to 557 hp, but you’ll want to add the optional AMG carbon-ceramic brake system ($12,625) with that
• Top speed with the AMG performance package is 186 mph
• This gorgeous roadster also has an Eco start/stop system, because you are thinking about fuel economy, of course
• Could there be any car that makes you feel more entitled and special?

pageElements.text: When you get a new car, you resolve to keep it sparkling fresh at all times. Am I right? Then, a few years later, you open the door one day and are revolted by how trashy you've let it become. Here are a few small, inexpensive products I've found around the Internet that can help with that. As they say in Weight Watchers, "If you fail to plan, you plan to fail." So plan to have the equipment you need to keep those messes from accumulating in the first place.

1. A hook for your purse that is just as cute as your purse. What are you doing with your purse now when you drive? You could toss your purse into the back seat, where you can’t reach it to pay for your drive-thru coffee. You could set it on the passenger’s seat next to you, where it will roll around. You could put it on the floor of the car with all the attendant dirt and grime risks. Some people’s extra-large purses could be a danger if they were to fly around loose in an accident.

image.altText: want a tidy car 5 must haves

pageElements.text: So, how about a handbag hook that looks like something the Queen would use? It snaps on to the bar of an adjustable headrest and hangs down over the passenger’s seat in front or rear, keeping your bag stylishly and neatly suspended while you drive. It holds up to fifteen pounds! Price: about $30, plus shipping, from Car-Go Handbag Hooks.

image.altText: want a tidy car 5 must haves

pageElements.text: 2. Car hooks for more prosaic functions. Here's a set of simple chrome hangers, good for everyday needs like hanging up baseball caps or plastic grocery bags on the way home from the store. Price: $4.99 for two, plus shipping, from the Container Store.

image.altText: want a tidy car 5 must haves

pageElements.text: From the same seller, a dry cleaner hook that has little notches in it to keep the wire hangers from sliding together. Carries up to fifteen wire hangers at a time. It slips into the window opening, so it’s something to put in place only while you’re using it. $3.99, also from the Container Store.

image.altText: want a tidy car 5 must haves

pageElements.text: 3. A trash receptacle that stands on its own. Bonus: This one’s waterproof. Made by Talus, this trash holder comes in sizes up to two gallons and has a weighted base and grip strips to keep it rom rolling around in the car. Side pockets hold disinfecting wipes or tissue. Where to put your nearly (but not quite) empty Styrofoam cup of coffee or juice box on a trip? Here’s where. It costs $15.99 for the big one, plus shipping, on Amazon.com.

image.altText: want a tidy car 5 must haves

pageElements.text: 4. Or, a trash receptacle that’s little and cute, so it won’t interfere with your sense of style and will encourage emptying frequently (before the items inside get too ripe). These are handmade litter bags from The ModMobile that hook over a headrest, in a variety of attractive cotton fabrics (forty-four choices, available to browse online). $19 plus shipping, on Etsy.com.

image.altText: want a tidy car 5 must haves

pageElements.text: 5. Personal-care products you can actually reach while driving. I have a dented, torn box of tissues on the floor of my car. Not recommended for hygiene! That’s what makes the unfortunately named Kiss-U Tissue Holder such a good idea. It’s sized like a Pringles can, so it fits in your car’s cup holder slot. The company also makes wet wipe containers in the same shape. The cylinders are attractive, with decorative patterns, and refillable using the company’s own refill packs. Downside: expensive. A set of four tubes and a refill (each of which has seventy tissues inside) costs $22.99 postpaid, and the wet wipes cost $27.99 for three tubes and three refills. The products are available in larger quantities for a smaller per-tube price, though. Order direct from Kiss-U Corps.
