pageElements.text: Always wanted to travel out into the universe but never knew whom to call to arrange near-space travel? We have the answer, but you’ll have to move to Paris first, okay?

French automaker Citroën is holding a promotional drawing to celebrate the launch of its redesigned Citroën C4 Picasso small crossover. It's named the Technospace, and that's exactly where the carmaker is sending the winner of the contest....into space, riding in a MiG-29 fighter jet.

A little historical context here: Citroën is known for quirky cars and, as a proud French company, it wears its weirdness as a badge of honor. The C4 Picasso Technospace is actually pretty mainstream, and the advertising for it may be the most out-there thing about it. (Watch the commercial, in which astronauts fold up the Earth into the shape of the car.)

Available in five- and seven-passenger configurations, the redesigned model features a revised front fascia, an open, breezy cabin, and available technologies like blind spot monitoring, lane departure warning, and a backup camera.

Ground Control to Citroën

The link between a compact family hauler and a trip to the edges of the atmosphere may be tenuous, but we’ll play along as long as Citroën is footing the bill for the jet fuel. The winner of the grand prize will go 14.2 miles up into the atmosphere in a MiG-29, far enough to see the curve of the earth and the blackness of space. On the return journey, the lucky winner will get to experience loops, barrel rolls, and other maneuvers before landing safely back on the ground.

We mentioned that small detail about moving to Paris. Sadly, the Citroën C4 is not available for sale in the United States, and contest entrants must live in France. Still, it's fun to watch the video and look at the contest rules here.

Contest entrants who don’t get picked for the flight to the stratosphere will still have other chances to win. Consolation prizes include a jump in a skydive simulator, a telescope, and a home planetarium projector. Bonne chance à tous!

header.title: Id 345286 ask a dealer pre car buying steps

homepage.title: Id 345286 ask a dealer pre car buying steps

pageElements.text: So you’re ready to head out to your local dealership and start car shopping. Congratulations! We’d love to help. Since it’s always a good idea to get information straight from the source, we went to a very successful saleswoman right here in our town and asked her what she’d like her customers to know before they walk in the door.

Beth Bashert (right) has been a top salesperson at Dunning Toyota in Ann Arbor, Michigan, since her first year there, in 2006. She describes her profession as “relationship based” and says up to 70 percent of her customers are repeat clients or are referred by satisfied customers. Since Beth also told us she’s on track to sell more than 200 new and used cars this year, we figured she knows what she is talking about.
Here are her five tips for you, if you are getting ready to walk into a dealership in pursuit of your next vehicle.

1. Do the amount of advance research you feel comfortable with.

Beth says she finds the average customer has already done eleven hours of Internet research before coming in to the dealership. “That’s the tool the Internet has given people. Do as much or as little research as you want before you come in,” she says, but understand that your salesperson is “actually there to help you. We have a fair amount of information that augments the research you’ve already done.” Having said that, she points out that she always invites her clients to confirm whatever information she gives them, if they want to. “I want my customer to feel comfortable at the end of the process.”

2. Get referrals from people you know and trust.

“Ask your friends. Where did they buy their car, who did they buy it from, and would they go back there again? Even if you’re new in town, you know somebody you can ask: coworkers, neighbors, your dentist. If they wouldn’t go back to the same dealer, that’s a useful answer, too.”

3. Focus on getting the salesperson you want.

“Eighty percent of new contacts are now e-mail initiated,” Beth explains. “A lot of times, unless you initially ask for a salesperson, you’ll get round-robined to whoever’s turn is next in the queue. Sometimes there’s a business development center in the dealership that handles e-mail queries and does initial contact until you make an appointment. At any time in there, if you have a preference—male, female, age, a used-car expert—you can specify. People are often thinking, ‘I want a blue car,’ not ‘I want a certain kind of salesperson to help me through the transaction,’ ” Beth says. Remember what stage of the transaction you're in and get that job done.

Next? “Once you get to the appointment, unless the salesperson warrants it, it’s not necessary to treat them like the enemy. You need to be willing to share with me, which means you have to trust me,” she says. But, she adds, if you find that your salesperson is not treating you well, or just isn’t going to make you feel comfortable, get up from the desk and ask for a different one. “Trust me,” Beth says, “we have thick hides.”

Not comfortable speaking up? If the relationship is not going to work, one way Beth has seen clients handle it is to end the appointment, then call the dealership from home to ask for a different salesperson. “That works!” she says.

4. Understand your financial situation and be ready to consider various options.

Beth remarks, “A shocking amount of what I do with people is financial planning.” Look at the salesperson as an informed resource who can help you find the best solution for your needs, she says. “Some people come in with a plan in place about how they’re going to buy the car—X money down, Y payment, Z equipment, pay off over A number of years—and sometimes I can help them see different ways of going about it that make it possible not to have to wait to have that down payment, or to pay a lower interest rate by getting a better car and saving money down the line.”

5. Don't stress out and ruin the experience.

“Don't be in your head 100 percent,” Beth says. In that, she is definitely on the same page with JeanKnowsCars.com. Like us, she sees that buying a new car is a treat, and you should let yourself appreciate the indulgence. “The numbers have to line up—size, fuel economy, specs—but don’t let that be the only factor. Let the salesperson help you enjoy the big purchase. Part of a purchase is emotional. If you don’t enjoy it, you’re not going to get the most out of it.” How to do that? Beth advises, “Relax, follow your instincts, and buy from someone you feel good about working with.”

title: Who's Afraid of the Interstate?
subTitle: Here's why you're wrong
promoTeaserSmall: Are you one of those people who fears the highway and sticks to the back roads?
promoTeaser: Are you one of those people who fears the highway and sticks to the back roads?
metaTitle: Who's Afraid of the Interstate? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Who's Afraid of the Interstate? Interstate highways
metaDescription: Who's Afraid of the Interstate? Debunking the belief that it's safer to drive on surface streets than on the highway. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Do you have an elderly relative who has stopped—or never started—driving on interstate highways? Do you know people who refuse to do highway driving because they think it’s more dangerous than taking the surface streets? Or, have you, perhaps, forbidden (or have been forbidden from) highway driving? We just saw a nanny blog talking about that issue: apparently there are people who ban their children's caregivers from driving on the highway. Let's lay their worries to rest right now.

Why Some People Hate Highways

It's true, driving on the highway can be a blessing or a curse, depending on your point of view. Highways allow us to go long distances quickly and with minimal risk of getting completely and hopelessly lost, but the limited access, high speed limits, and necessary lane changes can make taking the freeway feel like a dangerous proposition. For drivers who are nervous about taking to the interstate, driving on surface streets and back roads might seem safer, since speeds are lower and traffic congestion less prevalent. But is it really safer to stay off the entrance ramp?

And Why They're Wrong

Short answer: no. Federal transportation statistics say that, in 2007, there were just 0.54 fatalities per 100 million miles driven on urban interstates. Urban highways and arterial (main) roads saw 0.92 fatalities per 100 million miles driven, and local surface streets had 1.32 fatalities per 100 million miles driven. Rural roads, despite their low traffic and lower posted speed limits, are also measurably more dangerous than highways.

Rural Roads Are 2.5 Times More Dangerous, Actually

That same year, data from the National Highway Transportation Safety Administration reported that the fatality rate in rural areas was 2.5 times higher than the fatality rate in urban areas, regardless of road type. That may seem counterintuitive, since the high speed limit on a freeway can feel like a recipe for disaster, but there are several factors that make highway driving a relatively safer choice.

What's So Great About the Interstate?

Everyone is headed in the same direction at roughly the same speed. There are no pedestrians or bicyclists and no confusing intersections. In other words, highways have fewer unpredictable variables that can lead to accidents.

The back roads that nervous drivers may favor over interstates are more likely to have intersections with low visibility, unmarked railroad crossings, and traffic from pedestrians and bicyclists. It’s possible that those factors contribute to the higher fatality rate on those road types.

If you’ve been sticking to surface streets because highways seemed like the riskier route, now could be the time to brave the interstate. The fact of the matter is that driving always assumes a certain amount of risk, but the numbers don’t lie. It may be time to conquer that freeway anxiety once and for all.

pageElements.text: Are you excited about the prospect of a car that can park itself? Then today is your lucky day, because Volvo has introduced its new Autonomous Parking technology and showed off the way it can find an open parking space and park your car, all without your input or even presence in the car. Like all the most fun new things, the technology works by commands from your smartphone.

Just pull up to the entrance of a parking structure, click, and walk away while the car finds its own spot. So far, Volvo has only rolled out the technology in the video demonstration shown below, but a live demo is scheduled to happen before the end of the month.

pageElements.text: Volvo combined the autonomous driving technology with detection and auto braking. That's to ensure your car doesn't barrel into a space while endangering other cars or pedestrians in the parking lot. It works using sensors and "Vehicle 2 Infrastructure technology," which means it communicates with transmitters set up along the roads. Obviously, the infrastructure is not yet in place to make this feasible on a large scale, but just wait.
Only a few months ago, Volvo announced its cyclist detection technology, one more in a long line of safety technologies the Swedish automaker has made its name with.

Coming Sooner Than You Think

Impatient to try it? Volvo will roll out autonomous steering on its all-new 2015 XC90, coming in late 2014. This is just a preliminary step in Volvo's campaign to make cars that are capable of driving themselves. So stand by!
Do you like this idea or hate it? Perhaps you're deeply conflicted about it? Comment below.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Looking for an eco-friendly vehicle for quick trips around town that’s even more eco-friendly than a bicycle? Or are you interested in solutions to the transportation needs of people in developing countries? Look no further than Cardboard Technologies, which has just launched a campaign to crowdfund a bicycle made mainly out of cardboard. This ultra-low-cost bike has the potential to "change the world," says the Israel-based company.

If you think a functional bike made of cardboard sounds impossible, you’ve got company. The first engineers that inventor Izhar Gafni talked to about the project told him it couldn’t be done. But Gafni didn’t take impossible for an answer and developed techniques that allowed him to build a bike that could easily support the weight of its rider and stand up to riding on actual road surfaces. The bike is coated with a water- and fireproof varnish for durability. It is a single-speeder. And it can hold up to 300 pounds, which is not bad for a twenty-eight-pound bike.

Cheap Wheels

The ultimate selling price of the cardboard bike is expected to be around $30, with the cost of parts under $10. It's easy to picture people all over the world making this bicycle the first personal transportation they've ever owned. Even in Manhattan, where a one-week pass for the heavily publicized new Citi Bike rental fleet (right) costs $25 plus tax, that $30 bike looks pretty good.

The team at Cardboard Technologies hopes that the cardboard bike will lead to other cardboard products; plans for baby strollers and wheelchairs are already in the works. The company believes its innovative manufacturing techniques will help build a world in which transportation is cheaper, more accessible, and more environmentally friendly. "It's strong. It's durable. It's cheap," says Gafni. And yes, even the seat is made from cardboard, but it looks fun to ride on anyway.

The cardboard bike campaign is hosted on Indiegogo.com, a website that helps connect entrepreneurs with funding sources. Cardboard Technologies is looking to raise $2 million for the construction of the cardboard bikes, and the project had pulled in more $7,000 in funding from backers by the end of the first day.

Pledge levels start at just $1, and rewards for larger donations include organic T-shirts, posters, and a mini push bike for kids. For $250 plus $40 for shipping to the United States or Europe, backers can own one of the first 5,000 bikes to roll off the production line. The bad news? That production line doesn’t exist yet, and bikes won’t be delivered until 2015.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $66,290 (sedan) and $69,230 (wagon) as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter direct injection V-6, 302 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic with shift paddles
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/29 mpg highway (sedan); 19/26 mpg (wagon)
My favorite standard feature: Attention Assist—monitors the driver for fatigue
Option I can’t live without: Lane Tracking package—includes blind spot assist and lane keeping assist ($875)
You might also be considering: Audi A6, BMW 5-series, Infiniti M, Lexus GS
See more specs on E-Class models in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

I have owned a range of vehicles, but my favorite by far was a 2001 Mercedes-Benz E-Class wagon. In 2010, my husband and I drove it around Lake Superior on a camping trip with two other adults and a dog. We were stuffed in like sardines, and when we returned home, I demanded that we buy a bigger vehicle before I would go on another driving vacation. So we did, and I have regretted that decision every day since.

When Mercedes invited Jean Knows Cars to drive the 2014 E-Class sedan and wagon, I jumped at the chance. The E-Class has received extensive updates, both on the inside and the outside, but most notably in their assistance systems. They shared with us a PowerPoint presentation that highlighted the new standard technologies, such as a collision prevention system that actually senses impending accidents from both the front and rear and prepares the interior of the vehicle for impact. I immediately thought, “How could I not buy this car to protect my daughter?” I could cash in her college fund and pay for the E-Class in cash—she wouldn’t have a college degree, but she could live in this car and be safe.

I drove the E350 4Matic sedan with a 3.5-liter V-6 engine. It has a combined fuel economy of 24 mpg and requires premium fuel or E85—however, be aware that using E85 will lower your fuel economy by as much as thirty percent. I remember cringing every time I filled my tank during the halcyon days of owning my E-Class. However, there is good news on the fuel efficiency front for the E-Class: the 2014 models will also be available in diesel (E250 BlueTec) and hybrid (E400) form.

The E-class is offered in two distinct versions. The sport model’s badge is integrated into the grille and is nearly the size of my head, while the luxury model’s badge is the distinctive hood-mounted version. The bumper design is new and has a chrome-colored edge that seems to scream, “I will need to be replaced multiple times.” Both versions have beautiful new five-spoke wheels and LED headlights and taillights. They generally have a much more aggressive stance than the 2013 models.

Obviously, much has changed in the twelve years since my E-Class was born. But the 2014 has not forgotten its heritage. The far back seat of the wagon remains the same, with the addition of squared-off chrome handles that reveal the hidden seat; the middle seat has the same basic feel. As the driver, I felt like I was coming home. The instrument panel was the same but with modern materials and a much sleeker appearance. The steering wheel in both the sport and luxury models has been redesigned and has the flat bottom that gives the driver a smidge more legroom, and it looks great. There is a keypad integrated into the instrument panel that seems outdated. I wonder how safe it is to take your eyes off the road long enough to actually dial the phone with those small buttons that are almost out of reach?

Enough already; let’s talk about how it drives. In a word, it drives like buttah. The entire time I drove this beauty, I was grinning. The route we took highlighted why the Mercedes-Benz holds the number-one slot among luxury brands in R.L. Polk's 2012 brand loyalty study. Our drive took us on a surprisingly twisty route for southeastern Michigan. The lane keeping assist would vibrate the steering wheel whenever I would wander slightly out of my lane. Note to self: this car would keep an eye on my daughter when she is out of my sight.

The seven-speed automatic transmission with shift paddles made the drive even more enjoyable and allowed me to experiment with the paddles to eke even more power out of the engine. If you love to drive a manual but would like the luxury of not having to apply the clutch, paddle shifters are fantastic. And just in case you weren’t aware, 4Matic means all-wheel drive. Yankees, take note: this is a great winter driver.

Mercedes had cleverly driven us through about a two-mile patch of the worst road you have ever experienced, and then we came upon a road crew that was actually repaving the road. Mercedes claimed this was a happy accident. Although it was noticeable when the surface changed, it also highlighted the smooth ride regardless of the road surface, which is a real plus on Michigan’s pothole-riddled roads. The steering felt sporty and responsive and allowed me to really enjoy driving.

Two weeks after I drove the sedan, Mercedes dropped off a wagon version for our whole staff to test. My drive was much shorter and not over the same twisty roads, but the wagon was fun to drive and made me long for one to have at home in my driveway again. It felt a little heavier and was not quite as fun to drive as the sedan, but that could be due to the difference in the roads we drove on more than the vehicle itself. If I were in the market for a wagon, this would be the one.

The Verdict:

Obviously, I have a sweet spot for the E-Class, but it would be difficult to match the sporty yet luxurious ride with the available safety upgrades in another marque. Its competitors all have a lower base price, but only the A6 offers a diesel engine.

If I already owned an SUV, I would go for the sedan version of the E-Class. Otherwise, I would probably look at the wagon for its cargo-carrying ability. If you are in the market for a mid-size luxury sedan or wagon, then this is a vehicle you should consider.

Peanut Gallery:

Note: the Peanut Gallery had a go with the wagon, so we speak to that version only.

Annie: I'm a big fan of the E-Class's 2014 redesign, and I found the wagon to have just the right mix of power and comfort. But I can't quite stomach the nearly $70,000 asking price, especially when I imagine hypothetical children grinding Cheerios crumbs into all that beautiful leather.

Laura: The E-Class wagon is an old-money car. You would buy this to keep it twenty years. You'd be right at home driving it to the Philadelphia International Flower Show, or along Seventeen-Mile Drive at Pebble Beach, or just enjoying negotiating the curves on the way to your weekend place. It's not ostentatious, not trying too hard, just perfect. If you aren't old money, well, you've got to start building the image with something. How about with this?

Jean: An E-Class wagon? Always a classic, and I've loved them since the first one I ever drove: to the 1981 Daytona 500 with my first husband. I met Miss Linda Vaughn there, and we became fast friends. My husband lost control of his cigarette and burned a hole in the seat. Before I gave it back, I ran it through a car wash to make up for the burn, and it emerged clean, but without its three-pointed star hood ornament. Horror!
I've driven the old 500E Hammer wagon, and the new modern version at the Abu Dhabi Formula 1 circuit, Yas Marina. There continues to be nothing like one. I'd buy one in a heartbeat.

metaDescription: The new, bigger Fiat 500 is the 2014 Fiat 500L. I drove it in Baltimore and learned about its history and design philosophy. Read the whole story at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text:
Looking Back and Moving Forward

I was dashing out of the building, on my way to grab an espresso before heading to the airport. Of course, it was the perfect moment to run into a friend whom I had not seen in months. We know each other from Espresso Royale, one of Ann Arbor’s longtime coffee shops, where we both used to spend endless hours writing. He was launching an online literary journal; I was working on articles about Rome. We now spend more time behind desks than at coffee shop tables. “I can’t stop,” I said. “I’m on my way to Baltimore.”
Baltimore?
“Yes, Baltimore. I’m going for the launch of the new Fiat 500L.”
Fiat 500L?
“A new Fiat. A five-door car. A bigger sibling, as it were, of the Cinquecento.” That look crossed his face. I was going to have to stop.

That look: the face softens, a slight and wistful smile develops, and the eyes become dreamily unfocused. I call it “Fiat nostalgia,” and it is usually accompanied by a tale from those magical days of being a poor graduate student in Europe.

“Ahhhh, a Fiat,” my friend said. “I once pushed a Fiat up a mountain in Greece. There were four of us, and the engine couldn’t handle us and our luggage. We took turns pushing it up the road. One would drive, and three would push. It was 1997 in a 1977 Fiat.  It was sage green…”

It sounds like a scene that could have been in Mamma Mia—four strapping graduate students pushing a 500 up mountain with the Aegean shimmering in the distance. I kept returning to that image and the issue of Fiat nostalgia in general as I flew to Baltimore. The Fiat 500 consciously tries to evoke a sense of longing for a European way of life—small, sexy cars, mountain roads, and beautiful vistas. This romantic image leaves little room for the hassles, if one cares to see them that way, inherent to that way of life—cars too small to carry more than two or three people, no place for luggage or groceries, an engine lacking power to see you over the next hill. I was curious to see how this new introduction to the Fiat lineup, the 500L, was going to attempt to maintain the ethos and history of the 500 while addressing the limitations of a three-door vehicle.

Baltimore might seem an odd place to introduce an Italian vehicle to a disparate group of writers, but the city was the port of entry for the Fiat 500 when it was first introduced to this country in 1958, as well as the port of entry for the 500L, so the locale seemed appropriate for the introduction of this new member of the Fiat brand. At dinner the first evening, I happened to sit with the lead product engineer. He quickly surmised that I was not exactly an automotive journalist of the usual sort and wouldn’t (well, couldn’t, actually) grill him on specs, torque, and suspension. My interests were in the history of the vehicle and its design—how does one maintain design continuity with a vehicle that fundamentally differs from the initial iconic product? The response: “You must meet Fabrizio.”

A couple of hours later during after-dinner drinks on the terrace, a similar conversation with another engineer: “Have you met Fabrizio?” At the bar at the Four Seasons, another Chrysler/Fiat engineer and “Let me introduce you to Fabrizio.”  This Fabrizio was quickly becoming legendary.

Fabrizio Vacca, an interior senior designer from Fiat, is a tall, lithe, dark-haired, and soft-spoken Italian, flown over from Turin for the event and for his first visit to the United States. When we finally did meet, our initial conversation was not about cars, but rather about the history of the Italian landscape. Another journalist, upon discovering that I had lived in Italy, was asking advice about his honeymoon. His touring plans were ambitious—Venice, Florence, Rome, Sicily, and Greece in two weeks leaves little time for … sleep. We turned to Fabrizio, and I was struck with the manner in which he could extol the virtues of different Italian cities with a sensitivity to language that captured their individual essence while painting a vibrant visual image. I suspected that this was a designer deeply immersed in history.

My intuition proved correct the next morning, as Fabrizio presented the trajectory that drove the design of the 500L. The marketing pitch for this car focuses on hip and urban, directed at those in their twenties and thirties with friends or young families who want the Fiat association but need more space for their way of life. The names of the different models—the Pop, the Easy, the Trekking, and the Lounge—evoke a certain joie de vivre and an active urban lifestyle. The tie to the ethos of the 500 could become tenuous if the marketing folks are not careful.

However, it is the history of the Cinquecento and of modern design that seems to have influenced the conception of this car. Acutely aware of the implications of introducing a new vehicle to the Fiat brand, Fabrizio opened his presentation with the very first Fiat 500—the Topolino (right). Produced in 1936 under the dictatorship of Benito Mussolini, the Topolino was meant to be a car for the masses and a form of affordable transportation for Il Duce’s modern industrial nation. It was, in fact, the precursor to Germany’s Volkswagen, which means “people’s car.” A term of endearment—the name Topolino means “little mouse” and is what Italians call Mickey Mouse—the name was meant to evoke association with the advanced modern society of America and the American way of living.

In an interesting turn, the American way of living is also the basis for the articulation of the 500L. Spatial considerations, not hard edges, shaped the outlines of the vehicle. Such an approach toward space and design drove the design of the Italian palazzo and villa for centuries—utilitarian spaces on the ground floor; spaces for living and socializing on what is called the piano nobile, the broad and spacious first floor; and then more utilitarian spaces above on the second floor. The Italian palazzo essentially evolved from the inside out, and so, too, did the design of the 500L.

Recognizing that the car is a space for more than driving, the designers began with consideration of the interior spatial activities: how does one use the inside of the car? How does the interior space relate to and reflect lifestyle? These are distinctly Italian questions. There, the car is not just a means of transportation but also is often considered an additional room and exterior space to the house. Indeed, the inspiration for the spatial organization of the 500L was not a past vehicle, but the modernist iconic interpretation of the Italian palazzo/villa design, Le Corbusier’s Villa Savoye. Built in 1928 in France, the Villa Savoye sought to reduce the villa design to its fundamental elements and translate that expression with the most modern of materials. The emphasis focuses on the piano nobile and articulates that space of living with steel and glass, the modern materials allowing a panoramic view that takes in the countryside around it.

When Fabrizio put up the slide of the Villa Savoye, the overall design of the 500L suddenly made sense. While the slightly quirky and bulbous exterior of the 500L pays homage to the exterior lines of the Topolino, the interior draws directly from the history of modernist architecture. The frame alludes to the steel structure, and the rest is filled with windows. Their glass wraps the car, providing an exceptional panoramic view that mimics the living spaces of the Villa Savoye.

How does the thought given to design translate into the driving experience? I drove a black 500L through the streets and highways of Baltimore. The exterior takes getting used to, but, like the Cinquecento itself, its quirky lines quickly became charming in comparison with the prosaic lines of so many other vehicles on the road. The spatial effect of the interior conceptualization struck me immediately. The panoramic view opens the space and is, in fact, quite liberating. One does not feel constrained in a “small car space,” and I found my viewpoint from the driver's seat equal to the spatial experience and open field of vision one gets sitting high up in an SUV. That delighted me, as a small woman who can rarely see the hood of the car she is driving.

I was worried that the size of the gearshift, designed to maintain proportion with the voluminous interior, would be far too big for my hand, but instead it was remarkably comfortable, and I could shift with ease. Having always had five-speed manuals, the six-speed dual-clutch transmission required me to adjust my driving patterns, but I did so quickly. My driving partner and I have quite eclectic tastes in music, and the Beats audio system responded so sonorously with all genres that it made me realize that it might be the guilty pleasure in which one must indulge, particularly if we agree that the car is an extension of the house.

To continue that theme, how many of us have had to chastise a teenager for putting dirty feet on the sofa? Although it is not safe to put your feet on the dash, my dashboard is scuffed from teenage transgressions. The dash in the 500L is covered with a fabric that echoes the fabric of the seats. The fabric may be tough, but could it withstand snagging and scuffing from heels? Like the modernist aesthetic that drove the design, the interior has a crisp, clean feel. But it’s fair to say that the modernist aesthetic often ignores the realities of teenage living, and this is no different. It’s an impractical spot for fabric. Fabric in general is impractical with children, and were I to get the 500L, leather seats would be a must. These are niggling complaints, though, for what otherwise is a car that brings a certain flair and difference to this particular segment of the market.

It would seem, then, that the 500L brings the history of the Cinquecento full circle. At its price points, starting at $19,900 for the Pop and going to $24,995 for the Lounge, it is not exactly a people’s car. However, it is priced aggressively to bring in the young urban buyers looking for the ease and convenience of a small car but wanting a vehicle that sets them—and their lifestyle—apart from the usual car-buying public.

From a practical standpoint—drive, interior layout, audio systems, seating, and manipulation of space—this car works well. From a sense of style and history, it certainly distinguishes the driver from the rest of the pack. The 500L continues the entwined relationship between Italian and American culture: Italians evoking the American lifestyle and Americans evoking their own Italian associations.

But what of the Cinquecento itself? How will this bigger sibling fit in to the picture?  The year 2013 is a different time and era. I expect less tolerance in general for the romantic and nostalgic moments of a car that can’t get a group of graduate students up a mountainside, and the 500L answers that need. In terms of the bigger picture, however, the question is, have we moved forward, or is the sense of nostalgia a sense of loss of a different time and era?

title: Protect Kids from Hot-Car Tragedy
subTitle: Take the time to think about heatstroke danger in cars. Yes, it can happen to you.

homepage.title: protect kids from hot car tragedy

pageElements.text: If there’s anything more gruesome or upsetting than the idea of a child dying of heatstroke, unattended, inside a parked car, I don’t want to know what it is. But the fact is, it’s a problem we all have to face and think about. It’s the number-one cause of non-crash vehicle fatalities for children fourteen and under, and it is something that happens with upsetting regularity around the United States—even when temperatures are what we might think of as reasonable.

In the first half of 2013 alone, twenty children died in this terrible way in the United States. One of them died within thirty miles of where I am sitting right now. Are you sure you know enough about the issue to make sure it never happens to you or anyone you know?
On days when the outdoor temperature is a pleasant 72 degrees, internal vehicle temperature can reach 117 degrees within sixty minutes.

Think about this for a minute: Even when the weather outside is 60 degrees Fahrenheit, the temperature inside your car can reach 110 degrees, and cracking a window does very little to stop that rise in temperature. The American Academy of Pediatrics published a study showing that on days when the outdoor temperature is a pleasant 72 degrees, internal vehicle temperature can reach 117 degrees within sixty minutes, with most of that increase happening in the first half hour. Don’t allow yourself a false sense of security if it doesn’t feel hot outside to you.

You may ask, who would leave their baby in a car and just walk away? We’ve all heard the stereotypes about irresponsible parents who abandon their kids in the car to go play video poker. But this tragedy has also happened to many caring people who made a terrible mistake. So what you can do as a parent is put your cell phone, your purse, or your computer right back there next to the child riding with you. That way, you will always look into the back seat before exiting the car.

What you can do as a citizen is look at the back seats of vehicles when you are walking through a parking lot or structure. If you do see a child in distress due to heat, call 911 immediately and get that child help. 
Safe Kids says to spray the child with cool water to cool him or her down quickly. Children’s bodies have less ability to regulate temperature than those of adults, and they heat up three to five times faster than adults’ bodies.

Here’s something else to think about. Last July, a two-year-old in Wisconsin got the key to a car, opened the trunk, climbed in—and died of heatstroke. So, teach the children in your life not to play in or around cars. Keep your keys out of children’s reach. Show them where the trunk release latch is on your car in case the unthinkable happens and they close themselves into a trunk. If you can’t find your child, immediately look inside every car in the area, and open up the trunk, before you go any farther afield.
It should (but won’t) go without saying: Do. Not. Leave. Your. Kid. In. The. Car. Ever. Talk about this issue with the parents, grandparents, and caregivers you know.

pageElements.text: Today at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, as April ends and the racing world prepares to turn its attention to the Brickyard, the track is being put to a very different purpose: a nice 2.5-mile walk around the oval featuring 5,000 or more dogs and their human friends.

We love dogs at Jean Knows Cars, so we were fascinated to learn that the Humane Society of Indianapolis’s major fundraiser is one where people can take their dogs out to the world-famous track and walk around it together. It’s happening today, Saturday, April 27, and the participating individuals and teams are hearing the announcement, “Ladies and gentlemen, start your paws” over the loudspeaker.
Who wouldn’t want the opportunity to walk the track, even if it weren’t for such a good cause?

We’ve got one thing to say: Next year in Indianapolis! We’re already mentally putting together our team of dogs and friends. Plan to join us in 2014! Meanwhile, the people at IndyHumane will be happy to take your donation online right now and send you an Indy Mutt Strut T-shirt.

metaTitle: Range Rover Driving App - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Range Rover Driving App is a new iPhone/iPad app that lets you experience a virtual drive through eight stages in the big Range Rover. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Land Rover North America wants you to know, really know, what it’s like to get behind the wheel of the new Range Rover. You don’t have to drop $83,000 to get the feeling; you can dial up an all-new app, The Trail Less Traveled, for free on your iTunes account for the iPhone or iPad. This is the first Land Rover app, but we’re betting it won’t be the last.

The Trail Less Traveled is part advertisement, part game. It takes you on an eight-stage interactive journey that will almost make you feel you are inside the big SUV. The action is shot from four synchronized camera angles, each of which you can select to change your point of view. It lets you virtually try out the iconic SUV both on and off road, inside and out. Want to see the view from a wide-angle camera? Prefer a tight closeup? How about the view from behind the wheel? Choose which view you want on the main screen, and continue to follow the others in smaller images on the side.

You can also choose music—electric, acoustic, or symphonic—while you drive through water, climb to the top of mountains, clamber through dunes, and overlook scenic vistas, all on the way to a luxury resort in the final stage. Following cues embedded throughout the game, you can swipe the screen for information and video clips showing various features of the Range Rover. At the end of the last stage, when you do get to the resort, you can go check in or keep driving.
It’s “an authentic Range Rover driving experience,” says the company. It’s also one hell of an advertisement for the SUV and the lifestyle that goes with owning one.
One quibble: That vehicle sure does look clean at the end. Where’s the dirt? Because I’d need that to feel I was getting all the fun out of the Range Rover.

pageElements.text: My story began in the winter (Part One), when I first started considering whether I could justify replacing my Honda Odyssey with a Fiat 500. It continued in Part Two, when I overcame envy of others driving Fiats and made my own shopping list. And the saga continues:

Part Three: Into the Showroom

It was hard enough to find the entrance to the Toyota showroom, given that the dealership was under construction. “Poorly marked” does not begin to describe the signage to the door. I was in that efficient maternal mode, prone to frustration, as I was trying to squeeze in three test drives while the children were at play rehearsal. Moreover, I was a touch resentful that I was spending the first sunny Saturday in weeks car shopping. Mother Nature seemed to be telling me: “You know you want the Fiat. Don’t waste your time with other vehicles.” My conscience, however, was driving me to due diligence. Thus conflicted, any impediment to my efficiency was not welcome, particularly with a car that was lower on my list.

Slightly frustrated, I wandered in through a side door, down a dark hallway with offices off the corridor occupied by middle-aged men, and into what was supposed to be a showroom, yet with nary a car in sight: lots of desks and paper and clutter, but no cars. Cubicles, some occupied by salesmen and customers and some empty, rimmed the center of the room. I stood there a few minutes, looking to see if there was someone with whom I could speak. No one seemed interested in acknowledging my presence. Finally, I noticed a gentleman behind a desk in what appeared to be the Scion display area.
“Excuse me,” I said as I made my way up the three steps toward him. “I am interested in looking at the Scion iQ and perhaps test driving one.”
He glanced up. “We close at three.”
Not “Hello, may I help you?” or “I’m sorry, we’re about to close.” Simply, “We close at 3:00.” It was 2:55 p.m. I was taken aback.
“Oh, well, do you have a brochure on the Scion iQ?” I asked.
“We don’t have any. You can get it on the web.”

A number of inelegant retorts sprang to mind instantly, but given that none was ladylike, I resisted and turned to leave. I walked slowly, taking the labyrinthine path out, just to see what would happen. Not a single salesman spoke to me. The Scion iQ was dropped from the list immediately.
“We close at 3:00.” I was incredulous—at both the time of closure and the complete lack of interest in a potential customer.

When Am I Supposed to Go Look at Cars?

A not-so-fun fact about the state of Michigan: a law that dates from 1953 prohibits the sale of automobiles on Sunday in areas with populations of 130,000 or more. Those populations can buy liquor starting at 7:00 a.m. on Sundays, but not cars. While the impetus for the law was founded in a particular Protestant work ethic and notion of the day of rest, the continuation of the tradition seems to stem from the dealerships’ resistance to change.

Michigan is not the only state with such a law. That said, in the twelve other states that ban vehicle sales on Sundays, the approach to sale hours is far more sensible. Some dealerships outside Michigan stay open until 9:00 p.m. on Saturday; some are only open until 6:00. In Ann Arbor and other Michigan cities, most dealerships close at 3:00 or 4:00 on Saturdays. There are other dealerships that even close at 5:00. As for hours on the weekdays, Monday and Thursday are often the only nights with hours that last until 9:00 p.m.

While I applaud the resistance to Sunday hours reluctantly, I might suggest that the pattern of dealership hours harks back to a different, idealistic era of the workforce and American life, when the men were at the office, the wives were at home cooking, dinner was on the table by 5:30, and the family could visit the dealership on the way to Dairy Queen. How quaint and 1950s-esque. Perhaps dealerships might take notice of the new reality. I’m lucky if I’m home by 6:30. Dinner on the table before 8:00 is a rarity, which does not exactly leave time on Mondays and Thursdays to pop out for a test drive. And Saturdays? Throw in one hockey game or another typical Saturday children’s event, and it doesn’t exactly leave a large window between 10:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. I’m not quite sure when parents are supposed to car shop in this town.

Perhaps My Gender Has Something to Do with This?

However, I wondered if gender were coming into play at the Toyota/Scion dealership. As I embarked on my test drives, I was curious about how the process would go as a woman shopping alone. All the other times I’ve looked at cars in my life, I’ve been with my now ex-husband, who was quite happy to take the lead in the “man’s world” of car shopping. Would the experience be different this time, and would my reception be gendered?

To be sure, certain moments, such as the Scion iQ experience, could have come straight out of a documentary. I am fully confident that had I been a man in a suit, as opposed to a small woman in black jeans and a fleece jacket, the experience would have been different. I felt the same at the Ford dealership earlier that afternoon. I wandered around for ten minutes without anyone speaking to me. I noticed, however, that when a couple or an older gentleman walked in, they were greeted immediately. I finally went to what seemed to be the front desk and asked, only slightly sardonically, if I had to sign in, as one does at the doctor’s office. There was a sudden scramble to find a sales associate. Could it be that, from a distance, I look about twenty years younger than I am? If that is the case, should it matter?

The time spent at the Toyota/Scion and Ford dealerships gave me the opportunity to analyze the spatial arrangement of the two dealerships in which I was virtually ignored. Neither dealership’s layout is conducive to customer interaction. The low ceilings and crammed central spaces ringed by messy offices result in a claustrophobic atmosphere that makes leisurely browsing unwelcome. In the case of the Ford dealership, it was easy to get lost among the cars, signs, and people jammed into the central area. Given my size, it is quite possible that it was easy to miss me.

As an architectural historian, I should note that spatial arrangement has a profound effect on customer perception and quality of service. At the Mazda and Honda/Volkswagen/Audi dealerships, the vehicles occupy the showroom floor, and the offices are set to the back of the building. One has space, literally and figuratively, to examine the models on display, and the salesmen have the space to observe and approach an unattended customer. The Chevrolet and Fiat dealerships—both owned by the Suburban Group—took consideration of space one step further. Spatial fluidity drives the showroom arrangement. The vehicle display blends with open and inviting desk spaces. “Inviting” seems to be the mode, as both dealerships had salespeople who greeted each customer who walked in the door. And that is how I met the striking, if not quirky, saleswoman at Suburban Fiat.

An Italian Aesthetic, Minus the San Pellegrino

No dealership exploits spatial expressions of brand image better than Suburban Fiat, where Italian architectural design meets Italian auto manufacturing. To be fair to the other dealerships in town, this space was purpose built and brand-new, having been open for only a short time. Moreover, the entire space is given over to one car and one car alone: the Fiat 500. Yet the spatial branding is so well done. Drawing from glass-box mid-twentieth-century modern design, the building has a façade of plate glass windows with ceilings twenty-five feet high. One enters a showroom in which a row of five or six Fiat 500s are neatly aligned. Sleek display cases house Fiat brand merchandise (everything from key chains to coffee mugs to polo shirts) on the back wall to the left, while the right-hand back wall contains an interactive display where one can select and watch videos of the 500 in action. The cabinets in the office area continue the modern aesthetic: mod and Fiat red with minimal hardware. The theme of sleek Italian design even carries to the restrooms, sparsely articulated with slick fixtures. Imagine an Italian auto dealership fit for Dwell magazine, and you have Suburban Fiat.

Space alone, however, does not create an Italian ethos. Activation and associations of a space depend on the personalities and the rituals within. In every way, Suburban Fiat embodies the Italian ethos. Just to the right of the door to the dealership is a low, modern built-in desk with chairs of taut black leather and chrome. A woman greeted me as I walked in. It dawned on me later that she was the only female salesperson I encountered at six dealerships. Tall and model thin, she sported  short, cropped hair and an elegant, flowing outfit accentuated with arresting jewelry. “Hi. Welcome to Fiat. Are you interested in the 500? Have a seat. Would you like an espresso or a water?” This is my kind of car shopping.

The Kirkland brand water that she handed me, straight from Costco, as opposed to the bottle of San Pellegrino I was expecting, was the one slightly jarring reminder that I wasn’t in Italy. I took a seat, and she asked what brought me in. I went through the narrative—recently divorced, daughter about to turn sixteen, tired of the gas mileage on my Odyssey, and wanting a small, fun vehicle. Just as I was finishing, a couple returned from a test drive. He was tall and dark, attired in jeans and a black Patagonia down vest; she was slight, athletic, and wearing jeans and a rust-orange Patagonia jacket—a fairly stereotypical Ann Arbor couple. “We really liked it.”

“Did you check out the turning radius?” the saleswoman asked. “No? Take it back out and do a couple of spins in a parking lot.” They dutifully headed back out. The saleswoman and I continued. What other cars were under consideration? I recited “the list.” She smiled and pulled out a handy-dandy chart that Fiat has prepared for people like me: line-by-line comparisons between the Fiat and every car I mentioned.
“Plus, the Fiat is more fun than any of them,” she added.

Comparison Testing

It turned out that she was right. I dutifully test drove five cars: a 500, a Ford Fiesta, a Mazda 5, a Chevrolet Spark, and a Volkswagen Beetle. It was, at times, a bit of a trick convincing salesmen that I really wanted to test drive a car with a stick shift. A woman interested in a manual transmission would appear to be a rarity. More than once, I had to counter the “We don’t have many on the lot; it will take time to find one” response with quiet insistence. Imagine my amusement when the Mazda salesman declared, “Wow, you really know what you’re doing!”

In the case of the Ford Fiesta, once I started driving, I immediately understood the salesman’s reticence to pull a stick shift around. Its five-speed transmission shifted like a child’s awkward toy when you pushed the lever up into the slot: clunk, clunk, clunk. The stick shift was too large for my hand and set too high in the car, the audio/radio display on the dashboard was incomprehensible, and the car shimmied at 70 mph on the highway. The Fiesta was off the list.

As for the Mazda 5, it had the tightest and most fluid transmission of all the cars I drove. The gearshift was the right size for my hand, but the vehicle is prosaic and devoid of personality. It struck me as the type of car a middle manager in the Dilbert comic strip would drive. Scratch.

The Chevrolet Spark lacked, well, spark, despite the arresting design personality. Its price point, however, was considerably lower than the 500's. Were one able to fit more than two small Target bags in the trunk (in spite of the fact that the Spark boasts more cargo space on paper), it may well have been a contender, but it failed the hockey bag test. The Spark: off the list.

Indeed, the only rival for the Fiat was the Volkswagen Beetle. The new Bug has been “masculinized,” and many of the features that played on the Barbie-car association, such as the flower vase, have been removed. The new interior has crisp lines that reflect Bauhaus design and the sensibility of form, function, and German aesthetic. The lines are so architectural that I compared the space to driving a modern penthouse. Needless to say, the salesman was slightly puzzled by my analogy. The manual transmission shifted efficiently, and the drive had a lovely fluidity about it. What’s not to love, aside from the price, which would have topped the $20,000 limit? The seats. The seats were designed for a large man in a small car. The base was so long that my knees just made it over the edge; the side bolsters projected so that every time I shifted, the back of my arm hit them. I had a tender spot on that arm for two days after the test drive, bringing new meaning to the term slug bug. I asked if the car came with a pillow to place behind the backs of short women. At that, even the salesman concluded that the Fiat would be a better fit for me. We agreed, and so the Beetle, too, had to go off the list.

image.altText: fiat lust part three test drives

pageElements.text:
Back to Suburban Fiat

So it was that I found myself back at the Fiat dealership for a second visit, this time with my three children in tow. I needed to make sure they could all fit, and we had numbers to discuss. We rushed in on a Saturday afternoon, squeezing in a visit between play practice and a hockey game and mindful of Ann Arbor’s crazy car hours. My saleswoman was just finishing up with another typical Ann Arbor couple, two handsome males sporting black jeans and matching black North Face fleece jackets. Outdoor chic seems to be the attire for Fiat drivers. She greeted me like an old friend.
“You brought your children! Look at how blond and beautiful they are. Your son looks just like you! Hi, I’m....” And the introductions began. Just like in Italy.
I, however, was concerned about efficiency. Was there time for a test drive?
She smiled. “Certainly! We close at 5:00.”

pageElements.text: The warm months are here, and with them the first news reports of children left in hot cars, often with disastrous consequences. Have you ever wondered why somebody doesn’t come up with a child seat that tells you if you’re about to accidentally walk away from a sleeping infant in a car? The thought has occurred to us.

So when we learned about The First Years’ True Fit IAlert car seat, we were intrigued. This is a convertible car seat that syncs with a smartphone. Using a monitoring sensor integrated into the car seat, this seat can alert you when a child is left in the car when it’s not moving—or if a toddler manages to get out of a seat when the car is moving.

At $399.99, the IAlert seat is priced way higher than traditional convertible seats, but it does offer the first commercial application of this kind of safety technology in a child seat. The seat is expected to be available at the end of June but can be pre-ordered at Amazon.com now.

There are three situations in which your smartphone will receive visual and audible alerts from the IAlert seat:

    • The child is left in the seat and the car is not moving.
    • The child manages to get out of the seat while the vehicle is moving.
    • The Bluetooth connection is interrupted between the smartphone and the seat.

IAlert also helps in two other ways:

    • Showing the angle orientation of the seat so you can achieve the correct angle when you use the seat in the rear-facing installation for children under age two.
    • Constantly monitoring the temperature in the back seat in real time and displaying it on the IAlert app.

When you install the app on your phone, you can choose to set up an even greater security measure that makes the phone send an e-mail or text to your friends, caregivers, or family members if you do not acknowledge certain alerts as you receive them. We’re guessing that’s a setting for worried parents to use when a babysitter is the one transporting the child.

The Danger Is Real

How necessary is this new technology? According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), heat stroke, or hyperthermia, is the leading cause of non-crash vehicular deaths in children under the age of fourteen.

On a moderate day, the interior temperature of a car can climb twenty degrees in ten minutes. On an 80-degree day, the cabin of a car can reach 100 degrees in the time it takes to pick up a package of diaper wipes at your local convenience store. The fact is that a child’s body can heat up five times faster than an adult’s. In other words, a child can die from heat stroke on a 72-degree day.

This kind of technology has been looked at before. Just last year, NHTSA researched eighteen safety devices meant to alert parents or caregivers that a child has accidentally been left behind in a hot car.  The tested products were found to be inconsistent and unreliable.

The researchers found that many of the products required too much setup work. Also, the restraint-based inventory didn’t address the 20 to 40 percent of kids who are killed in hot cars when they enter a vehicle without adult permission. That question still hasn’t been solved.

NASA Had This Idea Years Ago

NASA came up with an early concept, the Child Presence Sensor (CPS), in 2002. The device, inspired by aircraft flight test technology, senses when a child is seated in a car infant or booster seat after the driver has left the vehicle.

Designed to hang on the driver's key ring, the CPS has an alarm that sounds ten warning beeps if the driver moves too far away from the vehicle. If the driver doesn't return within one minute, the alarm beeps continuously until he or she returns to the child safety seat and resets it.

The CPS never got off the ground. The device still exists as a prototype because it has not been licensed to a commercial manufacturer. When we got in touch with Chris Rink, public affairs specialist at NASA, he suggested that we take a look at a similar invention—the IAlert seat.

Good Tips to Remember

But whether you want to pay $60 or $400 for a car seat, it’s important to know the basics. The following are tips from NHTSA’s national campaign, "Where's baby? Look before you lock."

• Never leave a child unattended in a vehicle.
    • Do not let your children play in an unattended vehicle.
    • Never leave infants or children in a parked vehicle, even if the windows are partially open.
    • Keep a large teddy bear or other stuffed animal in the car seat when it's empty. Move the teddy bear to the front seat when you place the child in the seat as a visual reminder.
    • Make a habit of looking in the vehicle—front and back—before locking the door and walking away.
    • If you are dropping your child off at childcare, have your spouse or partner call you to make sure the drop went according to plan.

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: Andy Warhol’s splashy red, green, blue, and yellow 1979 BMW M1 art car was on display at the inaugural Paris Photo Los Angeles fair this April. Warhol’s pop aesthetic has endured on the number 76 racing car that ran at the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1979. A film depicting Warhol’s process was on view at the photo fair held at Paramount Pictures Studio, which focused on the art of the still and moving image. BMW has been a partner in the fair for ten years in Paris, where it is held at the Grand Palais. This inaugural Los Angeles event featured sixty international art galleries and public conversations with artists, curators, and Hollywood luminaries.

image.altText: warhol s bmw m1 art car visits la

pageElements.text: Warhol, whose films and Polaroid pictures are a substantial part of his body of work, painted the car by himself, allowing the immediacy of his strokes to guide his expressive work. The car was intentionally made to look blurred, capturing what he felt was the action of speed. “I love that car. It has turned out better than the artwork,” Warhol said of the M1.

BMW has commissioned seventeen art cars for its collection since Alexander Calder made the first one in 1975. The French racing driver Hervé Poulain originally approached Calder to customize his car, which led to the creation of the collection.

The Koons car, like the Warhol car, raced at Le Mans. The BMW art cars are widely regarded as important works of art and include a range of vehicles that capture the essence of an era in automotive design. The art cars have traveled the world and been presented in major exhibitions in the Louvre Museum in Paris and the Guggenheim Museum in New York. The permanent collection is housed in the BMW Museum in Munich, Germany.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
“Seldom has so much automotive charisma been carried by a mere handful of letters and numbers.”—Karl Ludvigsen, The Mercedes-Benz Racing Cars


This article was originally published in the December 1986 issue of Automobile Magazine.

Why are we bringing it back right now (other than because it's a great story)? Because Mercedes-Benz USA CEO Steve Cannon and I will be back in a Gullwing next week for the historic Mille Miglia in Italy. Pictures and stories to come!

Essex, Massachusetts, fall 1986—Alex Finigan doesn’t own a Mercedes-Benz 300SL. Few people do: only 1,400 of the spectacular Gullwings were built from 1954 to 1957. But Finigan has been restoring them for a decade, most recently for Paul Russell at the Gullwing Service Company, thirty-five miles north of Boston in Essex.

There are two parts to Alex Finigan: he is the worst sort of car freak, one who has a photographic memory and who has twenty car magazines delivered to his house every month. And Finigan is a full-blown nut case. Sha Na Na on speed. “We never see Alex down,” say his coworkers. “In the shop, he’s a howl. If he hears a song he likes on the radio, he puts it up real loud and sings at the top of his lungs. Alex really enjoys life.”
“I’m a fourteen-year-old,” says Finigan, eyes crossed and tongue out, “with forty years’ experience.”

You need to know a little of Paul Russell’s philosophy on the art of Gullwing restoration to understand why customer Nick Jones loaned Alex Finigan his rare $150,000, aluminum-bodied 1955 Gullwing (number twenty-eight of twenty-nine aluminum Gullwings made) to drive to Monterey. The Gullwing Service Company is not a museum. When the guys come to work and look around the shop (today the work bays hold a 1957 Gullwing, a 1957 Roadster, a 1953 170S, a 1961 Roadster, an aluminum Gullwing belonging to Ralph Lauren, a white 1956 Gullwing, and a chassis believed to be the first Gullwing), they see cars. And their job is to put those cars back on the road in perfect running order—in most cases, better than new.

On the subject of concours-quality cosmetics, Paul Russell says: “It seems nasty to have a guy with white gloves on stick his finger up your tailpipe.” Not that the Gullwing Service Company won’t or can’t do a concours-winning restoration. But to the guys in Essex, the matter of restoring the greatest of Mercedes-Benz production cars goes much deeper than the number of lacquer coats on the car’s sensuous skin.

In its day, the 300SL was revolutionary. “With its unsurpassed speed, its acceleration still strong up in the three-figure region, and its exotic good looks and technical features, the 300SL hit the motoring world with the impact of a sledgehammer,” wrote Karl Ludvigsen. Mercedes-Benz had never intended to build a production Gullwing. But Max Hoffman, the man responsible for bringing the greatest European marques to America in the 1950s, was enthralled by the 300SL that won the 1952 Carrera Panamericana. He convinced Mercedes-Benz to put the car on the street by promising cash for the delivery of 1,000 production 300SLs.

The car made its debut before the public at the 1954 New York International Motor Sports Show, showcasing the industry’s first production fuel injection system. The 240-horsepower in-line six-cylinder engine used an overhead cam, and the injection pump housed a built-in altimeter and thermostat to compensate for air density changes. An aluminum intake manifold sprouted ram pipes to each of the cylinders, the brake drums were steel-lined aluminum, vacuum-boosted, and finned for cooling, and the chassis was a tube frame. Mercedes-Benz also advertised optional rear axle ratios that would deliver up to 162 miles an hour at the top end. And it was beautiful.

“For some people, these cars work as art objects,” explains Finigan. “For us, they’re almost like industrial machine objects. We build our cars to be driven. We pull apart every last nut and bolt; the cars are almost remanufactured. Most of our customers want cars that work, that they can drive 120 miles an hour all day long. If our cars can’t do that, they’re failures. We don’t build cars, put them on stretchers, and haul them to shows.”

The Gullwing Service Company is the kind of place where real people rebuild honest cars for genuine car enthusiasts. Paul Russell’s customers believe in his work, pay him by the hour, even. There’s a two-year waiting list. And the Gullwing Service Company has the kind of customers who would say, “Sure, drive the car to Monterey for the races.” It had, in fact, two such customers: Nick Jones and Manfredo Lippman.

So, in honor of the Mercedes-Benz One Hundreth Anniversary celebration at Pebble Beach and Laguna Seca, Alex Finigan, accompanied by his good pal me, coworkers Jack Daly, Peter Bulkeley, and Bruce Marston, and our fearless f-stop Martyn Goddard, lined up the aluminum Gullwing and a red 1958 Roadster for a week’s worth of 500-mile days.

By the morning of our departure, our two-car caravan had grown to include: a white 1957 Roadster that we would drive as far as Chicago; attorney John Perenyi and his black pearl 1955 Gullwing; and the company van, which was hauling a covered trailer full of spare parts sandwiched around a 1960 Roadster that would be delivered to its owner in California. And Finigan had published our route in the 300SL newsletter as a challenge to any other sporting types to put their cars on the road to Monterey.

We had one rule that we promised to abide by: we wouldn’t drive the aluminum Gullwing over ninety miles an hour if its side glass was removed, to avoid the possibility of blowing out the Plexiglas rear window. There wasn’t too much else to worry about. Let’s face it—when you can start with bushel baskets full of parts and finish with a pristine $150,000 Gullwing, you’re not going to be racked with worry about the car breaking down.
