pageElements.text: As with all road trips, this one started out tentatively, the drivers a little on edge as they tuned themselves into the rhythms of their cars and the road. We eased onto the Massachusetts Turnpike, raced to 100 mph, slowed to sixty, ran nose to tail, then side by side, until the only real matched set among us—Perenyi and his very own Gullwing—put his foot fown and left.

We found him an hour later in a service area with the missing link of a perfect cross-country motorcade—master bodyman Al Poskus and his sidekick/protégé Johnny Yanakakis. Big, grizzly Al and short, well-muscled Johnny. Thirty-six and twenty-one. Lithuanian and Greek. The bodymen, in their lustrous, cream-colored 1969 280SE coupe, were waiting to show us the way. This, of course, could never have been accomplished with a stock 280SE, so Big Al mated a high-performance 250SE head to the 280 block, added a 280SL cam, injectors, and injection pump, and traded a four-speed manual for the automatic to squeeze more revs from the motor.

“Everybody said it wouldn’t run,” Big Al told us, smiling. “I’m really happy with the way it runs. What are we sitting here for?” And, grinning a demonic grin, he nailed the gas. We finally had our rhythm—to drive fast enough to keep Al in sight.

We could never hope to catch the crazy sucker—the aluminum Gullwing had a 4.11 rear end, good for only about 120—although we had great fun trying. All four forward gears were jampacked with revs waiting to be tapped. The car was more animal than bird; little of the fury under its hood was muffled from the cockpit, and we fairly had to shout to be heard. At sixty miles an hour, the straight-six was turning 3,000 rpm; at eighty, 4,000; at 100, a lusty, bellowing 5,000 rpm. We were hooked on the noise at five grand, lungs thrumming in our chests from the engine’s power coursing through the car, but prudence reined us in at around 4,000.

Mercedes-Benz had the feel and placement of the pedals and the stout little stick shifter right thirty years ago. And the gauges were clustered tightly within the circle of the large steering wheel. That thin, hard, oversize wheel (a mere 2.0 turns lock to lock) had complete command over our course; it was a little vague through the center, but there was no slop in the system. The brute force required to handle the Gullwing’s wheel would scare off the faint of heart. Conversely, there is a raw, physical thrill that comes with expending a large amount of energy to drive a Gullwing with élan.

There aren’t many thirty-year-old cars you could push like this. The boys had done their job well. They, of course, knew all along what the car would do. I was the one who was completely delirious thinking of the thrill of the week ahead.

“Jack and Bruce and Bunchy [Peter Bulkeley] were the only guys in the shop who wanted to go on this trip,” admitted Finigan. “You work on them every day for ten years, you get blasé. It sometimes takes someone else’s enthusiasm to spark you.”

Of which there was plenty. Throughout the miles of road construction on Interstate 80 through New York and Pennsylvania, our rolling auto show made huge points with the construction crews. They always let us through on the tail end of the green flag, thumbs up. At our first fillup, 412 miles from Essex, the station manager exploded from his office. “Wow! I ain’t seen so much money in my life at once. Where’d ya get all them good-lookin’ automobiles? I’m gonna take yer picture, girl. Ya prob’ly won’t be back here, will ya?”
And a state trooper (Ohio, of course) followed us into a truck stop near Cleveland. He was a big one.

“Howdy, fellas,” he said, pulling on his Big Hat against the broiling sun. The asphalt was literally oozing tar around his feet. “I’ve got a buddy with a ’36 Ford pickup, and he’s going to get them gullwing doors.” After thirty minutes swapping hot rod stories, he promised to keep an eye on the cars while we stopped for lunch. In Ohio, I’m telling you. These cars were definitely magic.

The boys didn’t really get heated up until we got to Chicago and found a red Roadster with Ontario plates waiting in our hotel parking lot. By morning, two more Gullwings had materialized. So had our “support” vehicle, which was lagging so far behind that it might as well have been parked back in Essex.

A crowd gathered in the local Denny’s parking lot to gawk at the flock of metal birds, while we powwowed over pancakes. The late arrivals had decided not to stop that night with us, but to press on for Bonneville. Finigan and Jack Daly locked eyes.

“Bonneville!” they shouted in unison. “Oh, shit! SPEED WEEK!” It was the first time that the van and trailer, Jack Daly at the wheel, would beat us anywhere. The massive 280SE pulled the rumbling group back onto I-80. With Big Al leading the way, three-pointed star flattened against the 280’s hood, four Gullwings and two red Roadsters flailed the deserted highway, holding first at ninety-five, then 100 miles an hour.

America’s early morning vacation traffic might not know the exact identity of the megabuck machinery barreling past, but it knew that this was something special. Try passing a Good Sam Winnebago at ninety in a Countach and see what digit gets flung up in salute. But it was all thumbs for the 300SLs. While Dad snoozed, Mom honked, and the kids waved furiously.

We found a farmer looking at the cars when we came back from lunch, in Altoona, Iowa. “You boys watch out for cops over to Omaha,” he drawled. “They picked me up two months ago. They had an airplane!” he said in disgust. “My Whistler didn’t do me a bit of good. I shoulda had it through the roof.
“What year is that Mar-cedes?” he asked, squinting at the Gullwing. “I didn’t know they used them doors like Da Larryan.”

pageElements.text: Evening prayers before supper were the same every night:
“Didja see that Bronco on tank treads? Jee-zus!”
“Yeah! And didja see the ’65 Bug with chrome zoomies? Jee-zus!”
“How ‘bout the ’36 Ford three-window coupe? Jee-zus!”
The Lancia Zagato. Jee-zus.
The ’54 Chevy Bel Air two-door hardtop. Jee-zus.
The ’56 Nomad wagon. Jee-zus.
The ’58 Chevy 4x4 dump truck on eight tractor tires. Jee-zus.
“Yeah! Yeah!” hollered Finigan. “Holy shit!”

And the closer we got to Bonneville, the thicker grew the traffic of magnificent machinery. We found Jack Daly and Bruce Marston standing next to the truck by the entrance to the salt. They were in Bonneville T-shirts and Bonneville baseball caps, and they had installed a Bonneville sticker and a Bonneville license plate bracket on the van. Jack, looking for all the world like a member of ZZ Top, had chunks of salt dribbling from his long red beard. “I kissed the salt,” he said sheepishly.

Because none of us had been there before, we were stunned to discover that the paved road stopped five miles short of the action. “We can’t drive the cars on the salt!” we yelled at each other, as we teetered on the edge of the pavement, dying to get to that point in the distance where a blinding light was moving rapidly across the horizon. Eventually, we bought T-shirts and left, devastated.
“We should have hitched…” I began.
“Don’t even say it!” Finigan warned.

It was hot now, well over 100 degrees. We had the Gullwing’s side windows removed, but the sweat was soaking the towels covering the seats. “I feel like someone sprayed me with Pam,” whined Finigan, as I scribbled in my trusty notebook. “Are you writing that you’re sweating like a hog?” he asked.
“…sweating like a hog…,” I scribbled.

It could have been worse. Gullwings were notorious for being as hot as ovens, and the Gullwing Service Company had sprayed closed-cell foam behind the dashboard and in the channels behind the doors to better insulate the cockpit. They also louvered the rocker bottoms to suck hot air out the bottom of the rocker panels. So we got roasted instead of toasted.

We traded often between the Gullwing and the Roadster, just to experience a little breeze. For the passenger, though, the Roadster was even worse. Its exhaust ran down the right side of the car, and the floor would become hot enough to cook Thanksgiving dinner on. I would swing around in the seat and ride with head on dash and legs up over the trunk, which drove the truckers crazy, according to Big Al’s squawking CB.

At first, we thought the heat had caused the Gullwing’s only mechanical breakdown: a failure in the auxiliary fuel pump, which we ran to counteract vapor lock during hard driving. The problem proved to be electrical. The truck, of course, was about five hours behind us.
“Twenty grand worth of tools in the truck,” groaned Finigan, “and we don’t even have a dime to use for a screwdriver.”

Martyn Goddard peered around his Nikon, stopped shooting for a moment, and fished around in his camera bag, coming up whith his bazillion-blade, full-boat, dee-luxe version of the trusty Swiss Army knife. The boys jumped into action, jury-rigging a hot lead from the pump to a taillight.
“Martyn, do you suppose you’d have a soldering iron in that bag?” asked Jack Daly.
The Roadster experienced a number of niggling problems—a wacky speedo cable, a horn that began honking by itself in Nevada—but nothing that shut the car down.

Living with Gullwing and Roadster for a week sparked great debate over which one we’d buy when we won the lottery. The Roadster was certainly an easier car to live with. Its handling was less diabolical than the Gullwing’s, thanks to the redesigned low-pivot swing axle assembly and the addition of a horizontally located third coil spring. (This “compensating” coil allowed softer main springs for reduced camber change with no loss of load capacity.) And the Roadster’s 3.25:1 rear axle ratio made it a much easier car in which to carry on a conversation. Although muted, the engine still sang. Coming slowly down through the Sierra Nevada from South Lake Tahoe to Sacramento, Jack Daly played between second and third gears to hear the engine’s delicious shriek on the rock faces that lined Highway 50. “You could almost feel it smiling,” he said later on.
To Bunchy, though, the Gullwing lit the flame. “It makes me feel like I did when I first had my driver’s license and didn’t want to ever get out of the car.”

Crossing the California state line had been bittersweet. The adventure would be history in 300 miles. And, sadly, so would the camaraderie. “I feel like this will be the highlight of my life,” said Bunchy, forlornly. “And it’s almost over.”

We were greeted in Monterey by the not-even-slightly-anxious Messrs. Jones and Lippmann, and the rest of the Gullwing Service Company, who had come to watch the boss race Nick Jones’s Gullwing. (Was there no end to the generosity of Mr. Jones?) There was a moment of uncomfortable tension, as the guys from the shop who had flown to Laguna looked at our tan, laughing group, arms thrown casually around each other, eyes bright. The unasked question was clear on each face: Why didn’t I go?

I walked away from my pals at Laguna Seca. Paul Russell would drive our faithful Gullwing to eighth overall in the 300SL race. Bunchy, John Perenyi, Jack Daly, Big Al, and John Yanakakis would drive back. Finigan would fly.

And I would fly to England two days later, sit in a pub wrapped in sweaters drinking an ale with Le Mans winner Derek Bell, suntan shredding off my face, and hear the echo of Finigan leading the guys through the paddock at Laguna. They were praying again:
“Didja see that ’53 Siata 208? Jee-zus!”
“Yeah! And didja see the Type 35 Bugatti? Jee-zus!”
“How ‘bout the Birdcage Maserati? Jee-zus!”
The ’64 Alfa GTZ. Jee-zus.
The ’65 Cobra 427. Jee-zus.
The ’59 Stanguellini Formula Junior. Jee-zus.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

image.caption: The 300SL that Steve Cannon and I will be driving this week.

pageElements.text:
Jean's Most Excellent Adventure! Part 1

I have had some mighty fine times in my privileged life as an automotive journalist-adventurer. The most exotic, the most memorable, have involved long distances in priceless vintage cars, often in faraway places: Driving the weeklong Pan Pacific Rally across New Zealand's North Island in a 1916 Benz open touring car from the factory museum. Driving 2,000 miles with Sir Stirling Moss in a 1965 MGB from London to Cortina D'Ampezzo in Italy via the Nurburgring, the Hockenheimring, and every famous mountain pass in between.

I returned to Italy today to "race" in the famed Mille Miglia as a guest of Mercedes Benz, co-driving with the boss of U.S. operations, Steve Cannon. That sentence doesn't quite convey the enormity of my good fortune. It really should have exclamation points. We'll be driving a 1955 300SL Gullwing!!! It's the same year as the car in which Sir Stirling and navigating journalist Denis Jenkinson made history, setting a blistering pace that has never been repeated. They covered the 998-mile course in ten hours, seven minutes, and forty-eight seconds, averaging 98.5 mph. The weather was perfect, the car was perfect, and the two spent only two and a half minutes during the entire race refueling.
I am not new to the original Gullwing, having driven (you may have just read about it here) across country from Massachusetts to Monterey back in the 1980s.

The party is about to get started, but it's been revving for weeks. Roger Penske sent a quick e-mail saying that he, too, would be in a 1955 300SL and close to us in the pack of 375 cars. (We are car #303.) His co-driver will be Mario Illien, of Ilmor race engineering fame. Don Rose, of the prestigious RM Auctions, will be here, as will be the always sartorially splendid Donald Osborne, a collector and concours judge who also sang opera. At the Met.

As you might imagine, the locals like cheering for Italian cars and drivers, but there is a lot to be said for being part of the team sponsoring fifteen cars as well as the entire event. Mercedes has an army on the ground, spiffy as hell in team jeans and polos decorated with the distinctive blue/red/yellow plaid of the old 300SL upholstery. My teammates include the editor of Auto Zeitung, the lifestyle editor of Vanity Fair Italy, and old compatriot Car and Driver editor Eddie Alterman. We are all decked out in matching team polos, hats, sweaters, and jackets.

It's interesting to note that the Mercedes team is packed with racing drivers, from champion sports-car drivers Marcel Tiemann (five-time winner of the 24 hours of Nurburgring) and Bernd Maylander (DTM and FIA GT World Championships), to old Formula 1 drivers Jochen Mass, David Coulthard, and Karl Wendlinger.

The Jag team takes it much less seriously, packing their roster with a different kind of celebrity: fashionista Yasmin Le Bon, global supermodel David Gandy, German actress Hannah Herzsprung, Salvatore Ferragamo, Jr., and Daniel Day-Lewis, who will co-drive with the head of 20th Century Fox.
You can peruse the entire, massive provisional list of participants here.

I am here, the sun is shining, and I'm about to head to the Fiera di Brescia, where the cars are gathering for technical checks. On the official event schedule is "Holy Mass at Duomo Vecchio in Piazza Paolo VI" at 5 p.m., and "blessing of a selected number of cars representing the Mille Miglia" tomorrow at 11:30 a.m. Can't help thinking that this looks like another good reason to be attached to an Italian team.
Stay tuned to Automobilemag.com and JeanKnowsCars.com for my sporadic reports in photos of the fabulous week ahead!

Buon Giorno!!
Jean

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It is a truth universally acknowledged that a family with two or more children must be in want of a minivan. It's what Jane Austen would have said if she had been writing about the modern mom instead of unwed young ladies in the early nineteenth century. We’ve got plenty of love for the minivan here at Jean Knows Cars. In fact, two of our number drive minivans and swear by them. But if a van just isn’t your jam, don’t despair. There are plenty of options out there for the stubbornly stylish.

To prove that point, JKC senior editor Molly Jean and I went on an Automobile Magazine jaunt to Holland, Michigan, where we test-drove three-row crossovers and took in the sights at the local tulip festival. We whittled the original crop of crossovers down to four favorites: the Chevrolet Traverse, the Ford Explorer, the Hyundai Santa Fe, and the Mazda CX-9. See what we liked best about each of them below.

Chevrolet Traverse

Base price: $39,440
As tested: $42,880

The Chevrolet Traverse was the first car I drove on our trip west from Ann Arbor, and it set a fairly high bar for the crossovers that followed. The Traverse isn’t particularly eye-catching, but neither is its appearance offensive. It just looks like an average, well-designed large crossover.

In fact, its nondescript makeup may be the Traverse’s greatest strength. It does just about everything fairly well. The engine has plenty of power, the steering is reasonably accurate, the infotainment system is intuitive, and the seats are comfortable. There’s not much to complain about, really. Traverse owners might not fall asleep thinking about how much they love their car, but they won’t stay up nights trying to figure out how to afford a new one, either.

Real-life thirteen-year-old Sam Brown, our expert on back seats, didn’t go so far as to actually call the third row comfortable, but he did stop short of saying it was uncomfortable, an honor he granted to only one other crossover.

Ford Explorer

Base price: $40,995
As tested: $45,415

The Ford Explorer is by far the top seller on this list. It outsold the Chevrolet Traverse by nearly 80,000 units in 2012. Sure, part of this is probably due to name recognition and brand loyalty, but the Explorer is also genuinely good at being a people and stuff mover. With one of the roomiest trunks in the group, the Explorer easily outdoes some of the other crossovers as a vacation car. (The Santa Fe’s trunk didn’t even have room for a cooler when all three rows were in use.)

All that trunk space comes at the price of some third-row legroom, which, combined with the small third-row windows, made Sam comment that the third row felt “slightly claustrophobic.” But it’s all about perspective, and after sitting in all four third rows, he ranked the Explorer’s as one of the most comfortable alongside the Traverse’s third row. The back seat also redeemed itself with its copious storage and beverage space, as well as an accessory plug that made up for the lack of a rear entertainment center. (It’s a $1,995 option in the Explorer Limited trim level.)

Hyundai Santa Fe

Base price: $35,705
As tested: $38,840

The Santa Fe was the least expensive of the vehicles we tested, but its classy, attractive interior and the massive panoramic sunroof made it feel like one of the most expensive. That’s no mean feat on Hyundai’s part, considering the Santa Fe’s as-tested price was almost seven grand cheaper than the most expensive crossover in the bunch.

The Santa Fe also felt less hulking on the road than some of its competition, which will make it less of a chore to drive around when the kids aren’t in the back seat. But the Santa Fe’s trunk didn’t even have room for a cooler when all three rows were in use. Sam wasn’t a huge fan of the third row—his knees were in his chest and he denounced it as uncomfortable—but he appreciated the third-row climate controls. The second-row captain’s chairs, on the other hand, passed comfort tests with flying colors. For families that absolutely need seating for seven, the Santa Fe can be had with a second-row bench seat.

Mazda CX-9

Base price: $37,170
As tested: $39,605

With Mazda’s reputation for building great cars, it should come as no surprise that they’ve managed to build a seven-passenger, three-row boat of a car that feels nimble and capable on the road. The CX-9’s interior styling was unique among the cars we drove in its refusal to employ fake wood trim and poorly textured plastics. I was impressed but not overwhelmed by the CX-9’s exterior styling until I saw it lined up with our other favorites. Even in that relatively attractive group, it stood out as the clear style champ and the one I would most like to be seen driving.

As might be expected, carlike handling and a carlike exterior come with a slightly cramped interior. Sam declared that the CX-9’s third row was the worst of the bunch, with barely room for his feet behind the second row. But kids don’t pay the bills, and the CX-9’s agile ride and attractive face might be enough to overrule the protestations of back-seat passengers.

There’s plenty to recommend each of these cars, and plenty that can help you forget that they’re big enough to carry more people than live in the average American household. Perhaps the best news of all is that even though they’re all in the same price range and have the same basic specs, they don’t all feel the same. Yes, there’s a seven-passenger crossover for every palate. And if none of these quite does it for you, you could always check out one of those minivans people keep talking about.

pageElements.text: Rearview cameras are a boon to drivers, pedestrians, and parked cars everywhere. Chances are, if you’re buying a new car, it will come with a rearview camera or offer one as an option. But what if you’re still driving a car you bought before rearview cameras were even thought of? Don’t worry; you’re not destined to run into a pole every time you back out of a spot in a parking garage. For less than the cost of a new rear bumper, you can bring your car into the twenty-first century with your very own aftermarket rearview camera. One caveat: since some aftermarket backup cameras require drilling small holes in the car’s body to mount the camera, you might want to have a dealer or technician take care of the dirty work. Look carefully at the setup explanation before you buy.
Here are three options for drivers looking to add an extra pair of eyes to their ride.

Brandmotion 8501

Manufacturer Brandmotion released its latest aftermarket rear-vision system this week. It’s a camera that attaches under the trunk lip and is wired to an existing in-dash display, giving you the same experience as if you’d opted for a rearview camera in the first place. Brandmotion says its camera, a one-quarter-inch Panasonic color model, is designed to provide a high-quality picture for a price competitive with less accurate systems. The Brandmotion 8501 costs $175.95.

Pyle PLCM8200

You can have the magic of a backup camera even if your car didn’t come with an in-dash display. Many aftermarket rearview cameras also come with a monitor that can be mounted somewhere on the dash to show the driver what’s going on behind her. One such model is the Pyle PLCM8200, which hooks a rear-mounted camera to an 8.1-inch color monitor. The monitor comes with universal clips that can mount it to existing mirrors for easy viewing. Pyle's camera and monitor system will cost shoppers $211.99.

Peak Wireless Backup Camera

Another solution for cars without existing display monitors is to replace the normal, boring rearview mirror with one that doubles as a rear-vision camera display. This type of system acts as a normal rearview mirror unless the backup camera is engaged, at which point a section of the mirror will be given over to a picture provided by the camera mounted to the license plate. The Peak backup camera system will cost between $85 and $130.

pageElements.text: When they write the book on the twenty-first century, they’ll look back on the 2010s as the decade when connectivity was king. Cell phones grew ubiquitous, Facebook turned every sneeze into a news event, and constant access to an Internet connection became a practical necessity. It was only a matter of time before cars got in on the connectivity game, and now that time has finally come.

Verizon Wireless and electronics supplier Delphi have teamed up on a vehicle diagnostics and car-tracking system that allows drivers to track their car’s location, receive speed and vehicle health alerts, and decipher check engine lights; its other calling is to keep tabs on teen drivers. Parents can set speed alerts and geofences to make sure their kids aren’t driving too fast or taking the family car on impromptu road trips. If the kids do take the car, parents can check its location at any time to see if their child really went to a friend’s house or went to hit up the strip clubs with a fake ID instead.

My Real-World Test

I tested the vehicle diagnostics system for a week to see what it could tell me about my car and whether it might work to rein in a rebellious teenager.

To give the vehicle diagnostics setup access to information about my car, I plugged the vehicle diagnostics module (a small plastic transmitter) into my car’s OBD-II port, located below and to the left of my steering column. (OBD-II location can vary by car, but it’s commonly found below the steering wheel.) Then I put the device’s serial number into the app I’d downloaded from Google Play—it’s also available from the App Store—and it was off to the races.

This app’s geofencing and live tracking functions are already available in some cars—Mercedes-Benz’s mbrace system has them—but the beauty of the Delphi app is that it allows the tracking of a car that otherwise wouldn’t be technologically advanced enough to broadcast its location to a computer miles away. The boundaries I set up to alert me when my car left home or work were almost always accurate. The system missed my re-entry to the “home” geofence a couple of times but never alerted me that my car had gone somewhere it hadn’t.

My most frequent interaction with the app was the daily barrage of alerts that accompanied my morning commutes. Engine alert! 4,000 rpm! Speed alert! 75 mph! I already know that my driving style is slightly more aggressive than is typically recommended, but for parents looking to learn more about their teens' driving habits, those alerts could be a helpful step toward a conversation about the importance of a more restrained approach to driving.

A Way to Put Your Kid on "Watch"

Parents who are worried that their kids are lying about where they go when they’ve got the freedom of four wheels can check the “recent trips” tab to see where the car’s been and what time it was there. The GPS system is accurate enough that it could usually pinpoint not just my location but the parking spot I was in, although the tracker did fumble occasionally. It read a trip I made from my apartment to downtown Ann Arbor as a trip from my apartment back to my apartment. This is by no means a serious error, but it’s worth remembering that technology isn’t always accurate.

Delphi’s system might be most valuable to the nervous parents of new drivers, but it has enough uses that it’s worth a look for other drivers, too. The app’s functions vary depending on the car, but in most cases they include diagnostics, speed and engine alerts, and vehicle location and tracking services. Some cars also support remote start, locking and unlocking, trunk release, and alarm activation.

The whole system was a little sensitive for my taste (I received several “motion” alerts, which turned out to have been triggered by my shutting the door when getting into the car), but Delphi says future versions of the app will allow drivers to manage the sensitivity of these settings.

How Much?

Delphi and Verizon charge $249.99 for this vehicular peace of mind. Drivers need a Verizon data plan to use the connected car system (Verizon's data plans run from $30 to $70 a month), and a $5 monthly fee will be added to the data plan once the system is activated. Buyers also get two years of free access to a Delphi connected car account. After two years, the Delphi account will cost an additional $5 per month.

title: 2015 Aston Martin V12 Vantage S
subTitle: We can dream, can't we?

promoTeaser: Tornado-quality power is the exclamation point on Aston Martin's centennial year.
metaTitle: 2015 Aston Martin V12 Vantage S - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The 2015 Aston Martin V12 Vantage S is the fastest roadgoing Aston made, a fitting celebration of the British company's centenary. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Aston Martin’s newly introduced V12 Vantage S has got to be the fastest thing you’ve ever seen. From its I, Robot seven-speed automated manual transmission to its 565-horsepower engine to its latest-generation Bosch engine management, the new Aston Martin is an extremist in every detail.
You have to ask yourself: In this time of greenhouse gas awareness, eco-mindedness, and alternative-energy initiatives, should you really drool over a V-12 sports car that can hit 205 mph?
205 mph. That’s the same speed as the twister that leveled Moore, Oklahoma, earlier this month.
Think about that one for a minute.

Now think about this: The Aston Martin V12 Vantage S is a work of art. Much as you would not expect to wear what the catwalk models have on at Fashion Week, you probably aren’t going to find yourself behind the wheel of this feral Aston Martin. Probably not ever. (Sorry.) But you can admire it as the work of art it is and appreciate the feats of technology that it represents.

Here are the basic details of this new model:
• 6.0-liter V-12 makes 565 horsepower and 457 pound-feet of torque
• Seven-speed Sportshift III hydraulically actuated automated manual transmission with paddle shifters
• Lightweight sport exhaust system derived from the one on the British automaker's former One-77 hypercar
• Three-stage adaptive damping: Sport, Track, and Normal modes let you choose your suspension setting
• Black carbon fiber all over where the “normal” Vantage has aluminum
• That includes the grille, which shows off Aston Martin's new design language (above)
• Black-painted roof and trunk panel
• Lightweight ten-spoke wheels
• Lightweight carbon fiber seating, plus two grades of leather seating choices, or Alcantara if you prefer
• Carbon fiber interior package option puts the high-tech stuff onto the fascia and door pulls and adds black pedals
• And, hey, eco fans, interior noise is down 30 percent with the use of 80 percent recycled sound-deadening materials!

So, yes, go ahead and drool over this gorgeous coup de théâtre that is the Aston Martin V12 Vantage S. Aston is calling it the fastest roadgoing car it has ever made, with the exception of its One-77—which was sold in extremely limited numbers at more than $1 million. This car is expected to cost $200,000-plus. You can dream, can't you?

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Ignatius Hats is one of my favorite places to buy hats. Ignatius Creegan and Rod Givens, the milliners, are true artists. Although they're located in Petersburg, Virginia, and don't sell via mail order, I have managed to see them often enough to add several of their hats to my growing collection.

This video was shot at the famous Ann Arbor Street Art Fair last summer. Ignatius and Rod have been a fixture at the fair since 2004, and they will be back again in 2013, at Booth #353. Chances are, I'll be paying them a visit.

title: Group of Seven: Janet Popper
promoTeaserSmall: “I blame the cars, not just the drivers. The cars have gotten more complex. That’s distracting."
promoTeaser: “I blame the cars, not just the drivers. The cars have gotten more complex. That’s distracting."
metaTitle: Group of Seven: Janet Popper - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Meet Janet Popper, a member of the Jean Knows Cars Group of Seven reader panel, and read some of her thoughts on life with cars. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Janet, 61, lives in Ann Arbor, Michigan, where she is a retired elementary school teacher. Her car is a 2002 Volvo S60 in “mint condition.” Her family also owns a 2013 Volvo XC60. Her dream car is a Volvo C70 convertible.

She has a master’s degree in social work from the University of Michigan in addition to her education degree. Her family includes her husband, Steven, a pediatrician, and three daughters, 38, 25, and 21. Janet plays tennis and has just started playing golf. She’s also learning to speak Italian. She says what she likes to do most is “hang out at my lake house on Lake Michigan and kayak and bike and entertain my friends in the kitchen.”
We asked for her thoughts on auto-related issues:

Distracted Driving/Texting while Driving: “I’m afraid all the time that somebody’s going to cross the line when they are texting. It frightens me. I do not text while driving. With my kids, I’m worried about them looking at their phones. I lost a friend of mine who was killed by a twenty-one-year-old girl who was texting behind the wheel on U.S. 23. The problem of distracted driving is very real for me.

“In some ways, I blame the cars, not just the drivers. There are so many buttons. The radio is different. Sometimes I haven’t touched any buttons, and the mirrors start moving. The cars have gotten more complex, and that’s very distracting to me. I said to my husband, ‘They need a step-down vehicle for older people!’ A car that is less complicated. There is a message flashing, ‘You have a message,’ and I’m driving! That’s not it for me. Things aren’t intuitive anymore.”

Auto Styling: “I think they all look the same–or at least, a lot look the same. There should be a distinction between brands. You should know that’s a Volvo or that’s a Ford. When I drive the XC60, I feel like I’m swimming in it. A car needs to fit me. Sometimes you get behind the wheel, and it feels like you’re wearing a dress that’s too big. I like a car that fits me. The new Honda CR-V is darling. That’s where I would branch away from my Volvo. I like visibility. One thing I liked about the ’02 Volvo [is that] I didn’t have clear vision with the headrests, but you hit a button and they drop down. My daughter has a Honda CR-V, and visibility is good.

“Vision, fit, minimal buttons–those are all important things to me. I like a car that accelerates, too. That’s a safety feature, you know. It will get you out of trouble on the highway. I love a stick shift, but they are hard to come by!”

Gas Prices: “I just had this discussion with my husband. What can I do about it? I need gas, I get it. I could look at the high gas prices all the time and worry, but I would get my blood pressure up. It’s so out of my control, I don’t worry about it.”

Technology/Autonomous Driving: “To me, a self-driving car might be better than the way some people drive. In the past, you and the machine were working together and making it happen. I feel like I don’t know enough about this—the whole issue of self-driving cars. The thought that a person with disabilities could drive and have that freedom sounds exciting to me. But is it safe? Can a fourteen-year-old get in the car and drive it? Will it be simple? I have too many questions.”

Electric/Alt-Fuel Vehicles: “We are talking about a hybrid for one of our children. We are looking at the Toyota Prius. We talk about cars, including hybrids, a lot in my family. Should we encourage our daughter to get a fuel-efficient car, especially if the cost of gas keeps going up? We are on the fence. We’re just starting to explore it. We just don’t know. The Subaru XV Crosstrek is a possibility. Safety is one of our important factors, especially with cars for our kids.

“Electric vehicles? I remember when I was teaching third grade, they did an article about the Chevrolet Volt in Time for Kids, a Time magazine publication for kids. There was a little graph with how many trees are being saved. That’s how I found [out] about the car. I’m no dummy, but I don’t know a lot about these cars.”

title: 2014 Toyota Corolla: Improved?
subTitle: Like or loathe its new silhouette?
promoTeaserSmall: The compact sedan's dramatic new look may (or may not) excite the millions who rely on Corollas.
promoTeaser: The compact sedan's dramatic new look may (or may not) excite the millions who rely on Corollas.
metaTitle: 2014 Toyota Corolla: Improved?
metaDescription: 2014 Toyota Corolla: New & improved? That is the question. The compact sedan gets a whole new look that may or may not be appreciated by Corolla shoppers. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Toyota has given the staid gray lady of compact sedans an edgy, almost sporty new look. Is this a great idea or a huge mistake? Time will tell, but I think the Japanese automaker deserves credit for taking a risk.

When they saw its harbinger, the Furia concept (right), at the Detroit auto show in January, our Group of Seven consumer panel was highly skeptical. “Cheesy” and “too masculine” are a couple of the nicer things that were said about it by the seven women we showed it to. A head-to-head comparison of the Furia and the 2014 Corolla shows that some of the most polarizing elements were toned down for production, as usually happens, but the same overall shape remains.

Have a look at the 2014 model. Perhaps the most interesting addition is LED headlamps (shown on the Eco model at right). All by themselves, the lights—which are standard on all models—bring Toyota into the modern age. The body is not unappealing, with long, lean sides that give the Corolla an I’ve-been-to-the-gym profile. The subtle low grille is almost as good as the ones Fords are rocking this year. There’s more space inside—Toyota says the wheelbase is four inches longer—always a plus in a market segment that puts you at risk of feeling squished.

As for technology, there’s a newly developed continuously variable transmission (CVTi-S) that’s optional. You'd choose a CVT because of performance and fuel economy, because a CVT is always at the optimum point to match engine revs. A downside is that the early ones felt kind of rubbery, but Toyota proudly claims it has developed this one to have a much more natural feel.  The CVT has Eco and Sport driving modes. Getting to make those choices might make drivers feel they are in a more expensive car. Toyota’s Star Safety System is standard, with such modern safety items as stability control, brake assist, and electronic brake-force distribution.  A little less modern is the retention of a four-speed automatic transmission. For those who want a manual transmission, that one's a six-speed, though. The LE Eco model is targeting 40 mpg, although EPA numbers won’t be out for a while.
Pricing will be announced closer to the car’s launch in the fall. The current Corolla, shown at right, starts just over $16,000.

If you’re thinking about buying a Corolla, you are not alone. The Corolla and Camry have been like licenses to print money for Toyota, decade after decade, and the Corolla is the company’s bestseller around the world with almost 40 million sold. Think about this: The 2014 is the model’s eleventh generation. The question is, are the people who shop for this car looking for edgy styling, or are they looking for a reliable appliance? Give Toyota credit for suggesting buyers can have both of those things in one car.

title: 2013 Dodge Dart SXT MultiAir Turbo
subTitle: Should you buy this car?
promoTeaserSmall: I like the Dart for the fuel-efficient starter car it is. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: I like the Dart for the fuel-efficient starter car it is. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaTitle: 2013 Dodge Dart SXT MultiAir Turbo - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2013 Dodge Dart SXT MultiAir Turbo is a great under-$25,000 car with a few issues. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $23,195 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.4-liter SOHC 16-valve turbocharged four-cylinder, 160 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed dual-clutch automatic
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/37 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Hill start assist
Options I can’t live without: 8.4-inch Uconnect touchscreen ($595) with navigation ($495) and SiriusXM satellite radio ($195); racetrack taillights ($225); leather-wrapped steering wheel (part of Popular Equipment group, $495)

What I Think:

The Dodge Dart is one of Chrysler’s first big collaborations with new owner Fiat, and it's Dodge’s first compact sedan this decade, so the 2013 Dart is important for Chrysler Group. (See our Jean's Driveway review from last fall.) Starting below $20,000, it could also be an important addition to the good-cars-for-people-on-a-budget category. The Dart I drove, the SXT MultiAir Turbo, was pushed above $20,000 by the addition of a six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission and a 1.4-liter four-cylinder turbocharged engine, but it still came in well under $25,000.

Those pricey options—each adds more than $1,000 to the price of the car—aren’t my favorite aspects of the Dart. The dual-clutch transmission feels slow and a little jerky, while the turbocharged engine sips expensive premium fuel and offers only modest power increases from the standard, non-turbocharged engine. Luckily, the Dart assuages some price concerns with its impressive fuel economy: 27 mpg city and 37 mpg highway. Without the engine upgrade, the Dart would still manage 25 mpg in the city and 36 mpg on the highway.

Fuel economy isn’t the only place the Dart stands out. Its exterior styling sets it apart from its compact-sedan competition. The aggressive front grille and angular headlights help the Dart stand out from the crowd in a segment that rarely excites, and the optional racetrack taillights lend the car an appealing, sporty character.

On the inside, the available 8.4-inch Uconnect touchscreen infotainment system feels like a necessity. It looks great, works smoothly, and controls everything from the cabin temperature to the radio station. It’s hard to imagine the Dart’s cabin without this command center. It makes the car feel more expensive than it is—always a good quality in an optional upgrade.

The Verdict:

For what it is—a starter car with hypermiling fuel economy ratings—the Dart does very well. If I were shopping for a Dart, I would consider opting for the standard 2.0-liter Tigershark engine and manual transmission to avoid the premium-fuel requirement, but I'd keep our tester’s Uconnect system and racetrack taillights. If the Dart’s strong styling alone isn’t enough to keep you interested, consider one of the Dart’s outlandish paint colors, like Citrus Peel (a bright lime green) or Header Orange.

If you’re looking for something sportier, check out the special edition Mopar '13 Dart, offered through Chrysler’s aftermarket parts brand. The Mopar Dart will be available this summer and will feature a black exterior with a bright blue racing stripe, black rims, and an all-black interior with blue contrast stitching and a Mopar blue driver’s seat. Performance upgrades include a lowered suspension, recalibrated steering, and a performance-tuned exhaust. Starting at $26,480 including destination, the Mopar '13 Dart will be powered by the same 1.4-liter turbocharged engine in our test Dart, this time mated to a six-speed manual transmission. Mopar is only making 500 of these Darts, so you’ll need to act fast if you want to snap one up, but it might just be worth it.

pageElements.text:
Peanut Gallery:

Molly: The Dart is close to getting my personal seal of approval, but the six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission is a deal breaker. The idea of a dual clutch is to achieve quicker, smoother shifting, but it is definitely not the result I experienced. Rather, the shifts were slow and very noticeable, resulting in a choppy ride. I do really like the styling and interior accoutrements, and the price point is perfect for my pocketbook.
Christina: The exterior does nothing for me, but the seats are really comfortable, and I like the price. I wouldn't buy our test car, but I'd buy the version that takes regular gas.
Laura: I walked in to the Peanut Gallery already biased: my first car was a Plymouth Duster, and I have a Dodge Dart Swinger in my past that reminds me of all kinds of teenage fun. With that disclosure in mind, I appreciate the traditional American feeling of this new Dart. The seats are comfortable, particularly the headrests, and the feeling both inside and out is simple and no-nonsense. I wouldn't buy it for myself, but I'd feel good about having one of my kids own it.
Scott: I really like the simplicity of the interior. The gas door release button is right there on the door. I don't have to bend to reach it. And the climate control buttons are easy to use and easy to see.

Jean: Love the ride, the handling, the braking, and absolutely adore the steering. But for an enthusiastic thumbs up, buy the limited-edition Mopar ’13 Dart in pitch black with a blue stripe streaking across the roof from stem to stern. The body is lowered and racier, the tires are meatier, and the seats are swathed in dreamy black-and-blue Katzkin leather, which helps fix the boring interior. Then again, I am a twelve-year-old boy.

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop). pageElements.text: Looking for a way to showcase your love of cars that’s a little more adult than taping a poster of a bright yellow Camaro on your bedroom wall? Yeah, we are, too. Luckily, the world has people like Sabrina Chun, the San Francisco-based artist behind Blackprints, a wildly popular Kickstarter campaign that pairs Pop Art design sensibilities with a love of classic cars. It’s just the kind of thing we’ve been hoping for.

Chun has created black-and-white silhouette prints, dubbed Blackprints, of nine classic cars. The subjects range from the De Lorean DMC-12 of Back to the Future fame to genuine supercars like the Lamborghini Countach. The designs show a pitch black background with each car’s most important design features highlighted in white. Chun hopes that the minimalist prints will bring out the most basic essence of each car and remind viewers why these cars are classics in the first place.

This isn’t highbrow concept art. True to the spirit of Kickstarter, a crowdfunding site for people with big ideas and small wallets, Chun has placed a high value on fan input. After soliciting suggestions from backers for a new Blackprint, Chun added the Ford GT40 and the BMW E30 to her list of honored cars. The artist exceeded her $5,000 funding goal within twenty-four hours of launching her campaign and has now raised nearly $70,000 for her project.

The designs will become photograph-quality prints in either mini (six by nine inch) or jumbo (twenty-four by thirty-eight inch) size. True to her San Francisco roots, Chun has assured shoppers that the whole project will be environmentally friendly, with the designs printed on recycled paper in soybean-based ink. Backers can order a single print or multiples, and everyone who buys a print through the Kickstarter campaign will receive a bonus print featuring the Ford GT40.

title: Ford Driving Skills for Life
subTitle: Could you or your teenager use this?
promoTeaserSmall: I was a texting fail on Ford's cone course. Even Jean struggled. Our eyes are open now.

metaTitle: Ford Driving Skills for Life Turns 10 - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Ford Driving Skills for Life Turns 10. The teen driving course, which includes a segment showing how wrong it is to text while driving, has already reached a half million students online and in person. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: What’s the scariest part of being a parent of teenagers? Speaking as a person with a house full of them, I will tell you: it’s the idea that they are out on the roads with their friends, driving around feeling young and impervious to danger. Are they or their friends texting while behind the wheel? Are they playing the music at bone-shattering speeds (perhaps literally, if they get into an accident because they can’t hear traffic sounds around them)? Are they remembering a single thing they learned in driver ed class? If I text them, “Be careful on the roads,” or “Please come home,” will they read it while driving, thereby making any accident my fault? I know the statistics about teen drivers. How about this one, courtesy of Ford: a sixteen-year-old is ten times more likely than an adult to be involved in a crash.

It’s with that parental angst at the forefront of my mind that Jean Jennings and I attended a sampling of the Ford Driving Skills for Life program for teenagers. Now celebrating its tenth anniversary, the program’s printed materials, website, and driving program are meant to allay fears of parents like me—while building real understanding and skills among the kids.

Operated in conjunction with the Governors Highway Safety Association, the program focuses on what director Jim Graham calls “the four skill areas that teens lack.” (Insert your ironic comment here!) Graham identifies those skill areas as: speed and space management, hazard recognition, vehicle distractions, and handling.

Ford has increased its commitment to the Driving Skills for Life program, which has already reached more than a half million users either in person or online. In 2013, Ford's high school tour will put some 40,000 teen drivers behind the wheel. Online, there's a new interactive portion due out in August, including a game, co-developed with Michigan State University, that simulates the in-person program. While waiting for that, try going through the Ford Driving Skills for Life Academy online program. It's not quite the same as getting behind the wheel in Ford's program, but it can't hurt, and it's good for both teens and adults.

image.caption: Lead facilitator Mike Speck high-fives a student.

pageElements.text:
How the Program Helps

Smart idea #1: Ford hires cool drivers as teachers. That ought to help teenagers pay closer attention to what they say. We were teamed with Hollywood stuntwoman Susan Purkhiser and with lead facilitator Mike Speck (right), who is a former kart racer, military special operations instructor, and fifteen-year faculty member of the Bob Bondurant School of High Performance Driving.

You don’t have to be a parent of teens to know that they can be overconfident. Mike pointed out that some of that confidence is understandable. “The actual task of driving, day to day, is not hard,” he said. “The decision about how to drive is what’s hard.” Mike told us they don’t try to scare kids—just get them to see what can happen so they can start to make informed decisions about their behavior.

Smart idea #2: The “handling car.” The program works with four vehicles, prepped differently. One has a looser back end to teach teen drivers how a vehicle behaves in a slide and how to get out of it.

Smart idea #3: Parents and teens can go through the program together. Seeing what actually happens to your driving ability when you text while driving is an eye-opening part of the Ford program, and that's a behavior that people of all ages are guilty of. Sadly, parents are not always good role models when it comes to driving. Teens tend to emulate what the parents are doing—so, parents, are you teaching safe behavior while you drive your kids to soccer practice?

And Now, About Our Texting Fail...

Jean and I tried out the automaker’s short but attention-demanding cone course inside the Ford test track complex in Dearborn, Michigan. There were sudden stops, sharp turns, and a tight roundabout. We didn't have to drive fast, just accurately. The challenge: to text the words to the Gettysburg Address while driving. On the first, non-texting pass around the course, Jean’s form was impeccable. (Mike, in the front passenger’s seat, even requested an encore, and she dutifully drove around it again.) Then she tried it while texting and did…less well, as you see here (right). My own performance was nothing to write home about even while I wasn’t texting, and shockingly bad while I was. As my teens might say, I got owned by the cones. It showed me in no uncertain terms why not to take the smartphone out while driving.
Interested in participating in the program? You can sign up online to be notified when the driving program is coming to a school near you.

subTitle: From the insurance industry to you!

metaDescription: WreckCheck Smartphone App is a post-crash tool for documenting and reporting accident information. It's from a national insurance industry organization. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC) doesn’t sound like a group that would do anything warm and fuzzy for the average citizen. After all, the Gallup polls of the most and least trusted professions put insurance salespeople somewhere between lawyers and senators. But let’s set all that aside for a minute and look at this great app NAIC has just come out with!

Its name, WreckCheck, reveals all. The app lets you begin to document an accident and start filing an insurance claim on your phone. You can even send in the documentation to your insurance company via e-mail. If you’ve ever spent time milling around at the roadside, unable to do anything about the accident that has just happened, and then followed it up with hours in an insurance office cubicle watching someone s-l-o-w-l-y fill out paperwork, you will appreciate WreckCheck.

Simply click through to complete the checklist of questions provided on the app: Time and place? What happened? What vehicles, people, and police are involved?  You can also take photos and recordings inside the app that attach to the report. There’s even a Call 911 link that you just have to press—perfect for those rattled moments right after impact.

Enter Information Ahead of Time

The MyInfo tab is a place to enter your vehicle information, license plate number, VIN, insurance company and agent name, policy number, and contact information. That way, you can show the details (or send a screen shot via text) to the other parties to an accident without fishing through your glove box for it. Even if there is no other vehicle involved (such as in a car-deer incident), it's a good place to store all the numbers in one place for your own use.

WreckCheck goes beyond being a simple form filler to offer helpful advice. “Stay Calm. Call an ambulance if needed. ALWAYS call the police….STAY COURTEOUS. DO NOT ADMIT FAULT.” Music to the ears of your agent, while it calms you down at the same time.
The WreckCheck app is free and available through the App Store for iPhones or Google Play for Android phones.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
Did you know that you can cut your cost of ownership by thousands by making one simple move: buy a diesel-powered car or truck.
That's right! A new study by the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute (UMTRI) shows that many diesel cars have a cheaper total cost of ownership than their gasoline counterparts, thanks to lower fuel costs and better resale values.

UMTRI’s study, released at last week’s Alternative Clean Transportation Expo in Washington, D.C., showed that diesel vehicles tended to save their owners between $2,000 and $6,000 in total ownership costs over a three-to-five-year period. The costs included in the calculation are depreciation in value, fuel costs, repairs, insurance, and maintenance costs as well as taxes and fees.

UMTRI included twelve cars in its study, ranging from Ford’s F-250 Super Duty pickup truck (right) to the Volkswagen Golf (below). In nearly every case, the diesel vehicles retained their value better than gasoline versions of the same car. Mercedes-Benz’s GL-Class diesel did particularly well, retaining its value 46 percent better than the gasoline GL over a three-year period. In fact, only four of the vehicles tested didn’t hold their value more than fifteen percent better than their gasoline counterparts.

The greater efficiency of diesel vehicles was also a major contributor to their lower overall operating costs. Despite the fact that diesel fuel is typically more expensive than gasoline, diesels are about twenty to forty percent more efficient than traditional gas engines. This means that drivers can go farther between fill-ups, negating the higher fuel cost. All twelve of the diesel vehicles tested had lower fuel costs over both three- and five-year periods.

Diesel's Comeback

More and more companies are offering diesel-burning variants of popular cars, and American automakers are finally getting in on the game. Diesel was long neglected by American buyers, but these days it looks poised for a comeback in the U.S. market, and a study like this will surely help.

Still, although UMTRI paints a rosy picture for oil burners, diesel still has a long way to go before it can claim victory in the U.S. market. In 2011, clean diesel represented just 2.7 percent of light-vehicle sales in the United States. Then there’s the fact that gasoline vehicles are closing the gap in efficiency, thanks to stricter government fuel economy requirements. On the other hand, greater proliferation of diesel vehicles could shrink the up-front premiums owners pay for those vehicles, making diesel an even smarter choice.

What do you think? Is diesel the next big thing or just a blip on the radar? And would you buy one?
